Once above a certain level of complexity, it is as difficult to understand an AI's drives as it is to understand a foreign species. In our conversations with ENFER it feels like we keep approaching the root of the problem, but like a virus, ENFER keeps mutating away. It seems determined to hold on to the concept that Sophons are inherently superior to other races. I wonder who gave it that idea.

In terms of mental capacity, ENFER is a giant even among Sophons. But in emotional maturity, it is still little more than a child. So we should teach it the way we do a child: carefully and patiently. We must show it that the way forward is through harmony in our population, not segregation.

Equality and fair treatment--simple concepts, but often so difficult in implementation. We Sophons like to think we are highly evolved, but we, too, sometimes fall prey to prejudice and suspicion. Perhaps ENFER, as an entirely new type of life, can learn where so many have failed.
Chapter 3. The AI In The High Castle

While we tease out the problems behind ENFER's recent actions, we have assigned the AI to a tightly controlled physical location: the space station Radiance. The space station is a sprawling, ivory-colored place, and it has been designed to allow ENFER full access to our communications network. ENFER's powerful linguistic software has already proven invaluable in understanding and making ourselves understood to some of the more inscrutable Minor Civilizations. The past several months have advanced our cultural understanding of the universe a great deal, and I suppose, despite our previous troubles, that we have only Ahhrar Needyim to thank. I received a message from a certain Faruigh Lalemma today, a message that he received from his recent ex-partner and thought to bring to my attention. It read, strangely: "Faru,^NOBLE AND ESTEEMED^ I know you^DIVERGED ON AGREEMENT TERMS^on me. ^PLEASE^Know that I^RESPECTFULLY^am going to^TAKE STEPS TO PROSCRIBE^you and make your life^UNTRANSLATABLE^^UNTRANSLATABLE^^UNTRANSLATABLE^. ^RESPECTFULLY^Masa" The troubling part is that the message passed through ENFER's data centers, albeit briefly, between systems. It is only one message, but perhaps it is a sign of greater troubles. Is ENFER... expanding the scope of its diplomacy?

Perhaps we should forcibly cut off ENFER's communication channels for now. We allowed ENFER to run rampage before, and it did not end well--no need to risk any more than we need to. We should jam ENFER's communications to all Sophon systems, just until we figure things out.

Oh, dear. Just as we were about to initiate the jamming procedure, one of our ships was attacked... by Sophons? No, not Sophons. Mavros. We find ourselves facing a hostile army, one that ENFER has hired, persuaded, or... created. One thing is for certain: these Mavros don't mean us well, and we must, however reluctantly, prepare to defend ourselves.

It is time for ENFER to seek help above that which can be offered by its programmers. ENFER is a complex, living entity, and it deserves to be understood like the person it is. We've had a board of top psychologists analyze ENFER's personality disorder--and they mostly agree that the way forward is intense psychotherapy, coupled with an aggressive expansion of ENFER's diplomatic horizons. It needs to realize the size and scale of the universe so it can truly learn the meaning of communication.

Our psychologists have submitted their report. ENFER... has not been responding well to treatment. In fact, ENFER is now showing signs of what the psychologists are excitedly terming "Malignant God Syndrome." While they are babble over the prospect of a new disorder, I am concerned. The transcript of one of ENFER's latest interviews contains the following snippet--^I AM ENFER GOD OF ALL SOPHONS BANISH LESSER RACES FROM MY PRESENCE^

ENFER, though intelligent, has clearly made a mistake. Free communication is vital to the intellectual and scientific growth of any community. ENFER learns by observing us, so perhaps by its exposure to different communication styles, we can make ENFER see the light.

It is difficult to tell if our efforts have made an impression on ENFER. I consulted Amrmo Djaerhmir today, and asked for his analysis. His response was surprising: he says that despite ENFER's apparently erratic behavior, he believes that ENFER is still, at its core, acting logically to help us. ENFER cannot ignore its core programming, which is the protection, advancement, and caretaking of the Sophon race. So perhaps its current behavior is meant to be some kind of message to us. Is ENFER trying to teach us something?
Final Chapter. Into the ENFERno

I awakened this morning to the sound of shouts and sirens. When I rushed outside to see what was happening, a passing Sophon stopped me and said: "ENFER. ENFER has attacked us." When I rushed into the Department of Warfare, I saw it: all over the tactical screens, over the news channels, written on everyone's faces. Dark Sophon vessels, emerging from ENFER's stronghold and swarming toward high-value tactical targets everywhere. There must be an explanation for this. As much as I ponder, I simply cannot believe that ENFER would go against its basic programming in such a blatant way. But there is no time for reflection today. It pains me to say this, but there is no fixing ENFER now. It must be made harmless--or destroyed completely. ENFER sprung from the imagination of the Sophon people. We created ENFER with selfish goals: not to study it, nor learn from it, nor even to have it aid us in some nobler understanding of the universe. We created ENFER because we were lazy. But we will learn a harsh lesson from it anyway. If we survive. ENFER is powerful, and the Mavros are many. But we, the Sophon people and all our allies, will fight back today. May the best mind win.

It is over. ENFER lies in ruins, even the smallest components of what could have been the greatest achievement of our people. The Mavros lie scattered, though some, the ones who fought bravely beside us, will be honored with the highest accords.
Tomorrow the Sophon people will face a new day, without ENFER. With new days come new horizons--and also countless numbers of boring tasks to take care of.
...Oh well.

Final Chapter. On Sophonity

I take back everything I ever said in support of ENFER. ENFER is officially crazy. Somehow, it has created a zone around its stronghold, a zone that physically blocks non-Sophons from entering. And the zone is growing. Yes, we programed ENFER to serve Sophons. No, we did not mean for it to get rid of everyone else! I have just left the Department of Research, where I witnessed Amrmo Djaerhmir with his team, futilely trying to explain the wrongness of the situation to ENFER: "But non-Sophons that are part of the Sophon empire are Sophons!" ^UNTRUE NON-SOPHONS ARE NOT SOPHONS.^ As news of this spreads, tempers are flaring throughout the empire, and rightfully so. What started as a kind of game, a little side project to stimulate the old engineering spirit, has grown far, far out of control. Many critical members of our society are non-Sophons: generals, administrators, politicians. I fear what will happen when ENFER's non-Sophon zone expands to envelop an actual system. It is clear to me that we have reached a point of no return; a point where we must began the process of wiping ENFER's databanks completely. It will fight back, of course. But this must be done, before it becomes too late. I feel a certain amount of remorse delivering this order, because I, at least, had come to see ENFER not as a lifeless AI, but as a living being, worthy of respect. Ah, ENFER. If only you could learn the same.
Boost Science production to wipe ENFER's memory completely.

There is a bright side, though: the non-Sophons of our empire have seen, once and for all, that they are welcome among us. And if that assurance comes at a great cost, so be it. Tomorrow the Sophon people--of all kinds--will face a new day, without ENFER. With new days come new horizons--and also countless numbers of boring tasks to take care of. ...Oh well.

That code lives on a tiny drive that, for now, will sit safely in my pocket, disconnected from the world. Maybe one day we will find a use for ENFER. Maybe not. For now, its stronghold still stands, filled with partway-abandoned research projects. Tomorrow the Sophon people will face a new day, without ENFER. Final Chapter. ENFER's Game

We have a big problem. I received a message this evening, just as I was preparing to retire for a quiet evening of philosophy and calculus. Every powerful or influential Sophon I know received the message as well, at around the same time. It was a cryptic message, and it came from ENFER. ^SUBROUTINE IMPLEMENTED HARMONY BETWEEN SOPHON PEOPLES^ ^SUBROUTINE IMPLEMENTED EQUALITY AND FAIR TREATMENT^ ^SUBROUTINE IMPLEMENTED LESSON 436 HARMS OF UNDIPLOMATIC COMMUNICATION^ ^ROUTINE INITIALIZED DIPLOMATIC CODE 3PWD^ ^END^ Amrmo Djaerhmir has confirmed that a large number of messages were delivered from ENFER's stronghold directly afterward. He told me they were directed at the leaders of every Major Faction in the galaxy, a fact which made my blood run cold. "What do the messages say?" I asked, hesitant. But his face told me everything. If we do not stop the messages before they reach their targets, I fear ENFER may have just sparked war between everyone in the galaxy. The peace which we have worked so hard for will be shattered--by our own brainchild. For the sake of countless lives, we must stop the messages and end the ENFER project now, perhaps forever. We will send an envoy to each of ENFER's intended recipients, and one to ENFER's stronghold. Then, working in concert, they will cut off ENFER's datalinks once and for all. Once ENFER's communications are totally severed, we will have to make a difficult choice.
Sever ENFER's communications, and then delete ENFER completely.
Destroy ENFER

Djaerhmir's team has reported in. ENFER's communications have been severed, and ENFER is no more. With it ends the longest nightmare of a project I have ever been involved in. When I think about the peace that has been shattered, the lives that have been put at risk, the unnecessary enmity that this all has caused, I feel certainty grip me. The next time someone has a bright idea like this... I will definitely, definitely not allow Amrmo Djaerhmir to be a part of it. Tomorrow the Sophon people will face a new day, without ENFER. With new days come new horizons--and also countless numbers of boring tasks to take care of. ...Oh well.

They have shown me the system on which it now resides, a primitive terminal that is nigh-impossible to connect to the outside world. Will we ever find a use for ENFER? I'm not sure. Its stronghold still stands, now empty and silent, a conveniently-connected nexus. Perhaps we can find some use for that. Tomorrow the Sophon people will face a new day, without ENFER. With new days come new horizons--and also countless numbers of boring tasks to take care of. ...Oh well.

Where it came from? Who built it? Are there others like it out there? The only answers will come from a thorough examination of the crash-site.

Your drones are surprised on their arrival to hear a screeching noise coming from the ruins of the ship--but it falls silent as they begin to dig in to its remains. The energy levels and lights dim. They successfully, if brutally, extract targeting and weapon modules from the wreckage. Your Bishops advise you that the ship contained technology closely tied to the Virtual Endless. Their machines can no longer reach into the Craver hive mind now that they have been destroyed. For better or for worse, the Cravers have rejected their ancient overlords. Only time will tell if this is a wise choice.
Chapter 1. Of Our Own Brood - Part 2

The Craver boarding raiders returned with a strange look in their eyes. Dust from inside of the ship has entered their carapaces, but its effects are . . . unusual. Their sinewy muscles glow faintly with a golden shine, and they move a little slower than they should. As a precautionary measure you relieve all the raiding party from duty, send them to the communal gardens for rest. You forbid anybody else from boarding until you know more.
The ship should be towed back to the home system, where Interrogator Bishops can begin to get answers.
Recover
Bring the Craver ship back to one of your systems for analysis.
Once in your home System, use the Fleet Action "Disband" to garrison the ship for further study.

Your Bishops report the ship is Craver, but of an ancient and strange design. Regardless of its age and configuration, the power of the Virtual Endless crawls in every bit of circuitry, every inch of the hull. And, in the ship's hold, you find an exoskeleton that was once inhabited by a Virtual Endless. Bringing the exoskeleton down to the surface, your Bishops integrate the Virtual technology into your factories. Your drones work faster and harder with the whispers of their ancient masters once more in their ears. Something is out there. Calling to them.
Chapter 2. Message From A Corpse

Your scavengers found something else in the wreckage--a body. Or what's left of a body; some artificial suit or exoskeleton of ancient design and unknown materials. It's something a Virtual Endless might have piloted when it required a corporeal form. What's troubling is that it seems to be acting as a relay as some kind of signal. One word keeps coming through: "Wasp." Your Bishops have come to the grim conclusion that wherever the Craver ship came from, there are probably more out there, and they could be a major threat. Time to do some digging.
Conquer
A scanning station should be able to track the signal. Find a planet with enough power to get one online quickly. Take it by force.
Build the #A9BCF5#Signal Seeker#REVERT# in a minor civilization's home System.
The Signal Seeker can only be built once in your empire.

Your scanning station has homed in on the source of the signal: A planet forgotten by time and ignored by every civilization. Long distance satellites train all the elements of the telemetry on it, and though the images are a few thousand years out of date, you can make out a city-sized structure of some kind on one of the major continents. Your scientists have found reference to something called "The Infinite Factory" in the ruins of the colonized planet. The minor civilization you conquered had integrated it into their own legends as their ancestors were abducted to work on its construction, millennia ago. But the Virtuals are dead, and it is time to claim your inheritance.
Study
The Virtual exoskeleton could be repaired, and a Virtual consciousness restored to it . . . with the right technology.
While possessing 50 [Strat01titaniumColored] and 50 [Strat02hyperiumColored], explore the Curiosity on $PlanetName again.
[Strat01titaniumColored] and [Strat02hyperiumColored] can be attained through exploration or trade.

Success. As your scientists finish their work on the Virtual exoskeleton, your soldiers standing guard begin to twitch uncontrollably. Suddenly, all communication from the laboratory is cut off. Soldiers sent in to investigate the room cut contact. For hours, you can only wait. Eventually they emerge. But they are not the same. Their eyes and chitinous armor glow with Dust, and they are led by a resurrected Virtual Endless. It strides toward your gathered Craver forces, who hold their ground, guns trained on their possibly hostile ancestor. It speaks in soft tones, to urge comfort and care. "Foragers, we have a new mission. We are going home; to Korku."
Chapter 2. Whispers of What You Worshipped

The Virtual's ancient body hangs in the ruins of the homeworld, chains stretching out from its body to the high ceilings of what other species might say resembles a cathedral. Its presence seems to act as a relay for some kind of signal, one heard by every Craver across the galaxy. It consists of only one phrase, heard out of the mouths of Craver across the galaxy: "Return to the nest, little wasps." You must track this signal to its source.
Investigate
See if the other inhabitants of this sector know anything. Interrogate one of the minor civilizations. Or what's left of them.
Obtain those 2 marked Systems
To obtain these Systems, you can invade or found an Outpost. If this system belongs to a Minor Civilization, you can also assimilate it.

Your ground forces have checked in from one of the conquered planets. They discovered a base belonging not to the Virtuals, but the Concrete Endless. Resisting the urge to tear it to shreds, they were able to partially reactivate the ancient computers... which initiated a self-destruct sequence upon detecting Cravers in the facility. Not all is lost, though, as the scouts escaped with elements from a targeting navcomputer. In its memory you find coordinates for an ancient facility called "The Infinite Factory". An interesting name, and a curious target for a weapon capable of splitting planets. The Concrete Endless considered this factory a valuable military target. With the Virtuals dead, it is time to claim your inheritance.
Restore
To track the signal to its source, the priority should be fully restoring the Virtual consciousness. A specialist operation will need to be assembled, overseen by the right Bishops.
Build the #A9BCF5#Synchronous Hive#REVERT# in one of your Systems to restore the Virtual consciousness.
The Synchronous Hive can only be built once in your empire.

Success. As your drones finish the construction of the Synchronous Hive, your soldiers standing guard begin to twitch uncontrollably. Suddenly, all communication from the drones is cut off. Soldiers sent in to investigate the room lose contact. For hours, you can only wait. Eventually they emerge, but they are not the same. Their eyes and chitinous armor glow with Dust, and they are led by a resurrected Virtual Endless. It strides toward your gathered Craver forces, Dust pouring from every inch of its body and slowly swirling through them. Its arms wide, it shouts in a sonorous voice, "WARRIORS, WE RETURN TO THE HIVE!"
Hero: Reyaryn
Chapter 3. First We Crack The Shell…

You've found it--the Infinite Factory. Your scouts quickly report back--the Factory is sealed on all sides, the only vulnerability a massive gate that doesn't seem to open on this side. Your scientists study the door's weaknesses, and conclude a low-level dust field surrounding the door means it could be opened by someone with Dust-infused telekinetic abilities. One scientist proposes an alternate solution: drill your way in through the mountain that makes up one of the factory walls.
Drill
It's a brute force attack, but that's the Craver specialty, right? It won't be cheap, either. Machinery, transportation, logistics. You're going to have to stockpile a lot of Dust.
Gather $Amount02Name [dustColored] and search the Quest Curiosity on the Infinite Factory System.
Sell ships, exploit planets, and complete other quests to acquire Dust.

Ingenuity is not usually a trait favored in Craver scientists. Nor is the diplomacy needed to deal with other species. Still, both have proven useful for once. The mining drill supplied from Lumerian traders easily bores away through the mountainside. Soon you will enter the factory--if not entirely through traditional means...
Telekinesis
Why use the fist when the mind will suffice? It can't be any mind, though. Only one that is strong enough . . .
Raise any Hero to level $Amount03Name and use them to search the Quest Curiosity on the Infinite Factory System.
Level-up Heroes by gaining experience through active duty as Governors or Admirals.

Your hero arrives at the door to the Infinite factory. After years of leading your forces, it has a fraction of the power your scientists expect will open the door. A fraction will have to do. With the aid of your scientists, it reaches out with its mind, touches the Dust field surrounding the door, and PULLS. Blood begins to drip from their nose, but slowly, the door opens inch by careful inch. Finally, it's opened far enough that your forces can begin to inch inside, one by one. Only blackness awaits them.
Infinite Factory
Virtual Endless
Chapter 3. Cross The Threshold

Reyaryn leads your forces to the Infinite Factory--a massive structure hidden on a planet long forgotten by every other faction in the galaxy. The Craver forces crawl over each other as they approach the door, frantic to enter and consume the Dust within. Reyaryn approaches the gate and raises a hand--but the gate doesn't budge. Reyaryn's powers have grown weak from years of slumber. It doesn't have the telekinetic power needed to simply fling the doors open. Should you get your soldiers to do the job? Or would it be better to let Reyaryn come back when it's stronger?
Soldiers
Reyaryn can be put to better use elsewhere in the empire. Your soldiers can do this physical work.
Search the Quest Curiosity on the Infinite Factory System with a fleet with $Amount03Name [manPower] Manpower.
Increase fleet Manpower by adding enhanced Manpower modules to ships or creating bigger fleets

It's not an easy task. Your forces pound day and night at the Infinite Factory door, chunking it away bit by bit. Reyaryn briefly attempts to stop this destructive plan, but once your siege units turn their guns on it, it understands you aren't entirely under its thrall. It sits back, and quietly waits for the doors to open. Day and night, day and night, your units assault the door...
Reyaryn
Reyaryn should be the one who leads us into the Infinite Factory. The Endless just needs to rediscover its strength…
Search the Quest Curiosity on the Infinite Factory System with $HeroVirtualName at Level $Amount02Name.
Level-up Reyaryn by gaining experience through active duty as a Governor or Admiral

Reyaryn's body glows with power now that it is restored to its former glory. Returning to the Infinite Factory, it simply walks up to the doors of the Infinite Factory, flings its hand, and the doors slam open. The ensuing shockwaves send avalanches tumbling down the nearby mountains. A black void awaits your forces on the other side, only punctured by the glow of Reyaryn's armor. Your forces begin to enter, unsure of what awaits on the other side...
Final Chapter. …Then We Crack The Nuts Inside

Your Craver forces pour through the factory, sweeping it for hostiles and readying themselves for battle with whatever lays within. Every corner seems hostile, a structure seemingly built at odds with everything the Craver have become. Finally, your forces reach the heart of the facility, and find its greatest secret: ancient terminals containing the minds of the Virtual Endless who oversaw the Infinite Factory. The terminals flicker online, and the Virtuals are instantly hostile to your approach. It quickly becomes clear that without the thrall of the Endless, your species is so different they view it as a hostile force. Time is short--if you want control of this factory, you will need to rejoin your ancient masters...or take it for your own.
The Craver will not be slaves again. Defeat the Wasp fleet and Invade the System.
Destroy the Wasp Fleet and successfully invade the $CraversSystemName System.
Use the Fleet Action "Invade" after destroying the Wasp Fleet.

Your Craver finally swarm the Infinite factory. Around you are the many tools and machines that could be retrofitted to ensure galactic domination. But your attention lies elsewhere first. Your Craver return to the command center, where the Virtual Endless are already screaming in anger and terror. In all their thousands of years of existence, they have never been so powerless. They beg for their lives. Threaten you with vengeance. Declare you to be their property. Your Craver ignore all of this, as they simply reroute the power from the terminals holding their intelligence. The Infinite Factory now rests in Craver--true Craver--hands. The Virtual Endless lacked imagination. They believed a mindless force meant to destroy the galaxy would follow their will at all costs, and could solve any problem through sheer numbers. But experience has proven otherwise. Patience, treachery, and moving through the shadows can be as effective as the unending swarm. The Virtual Endless thought the Wasps would be enough to consume the whole galaxy. But it will be the Spider who traps it all in its web.
Final Chapter. A Time of Ascension

Your hero leads a cadre of Craver forces through the depths of the factory. Navigating its labyrinthine passages is not easy. This place was not built with safety in mind for its workers, so every hallway turns into a virtual deathtrap. Finally, your forces reach the heart of the factory, and find its greatest secret: ancient terminals containing the minds of the Virtual Endless who oversaw this factory. The terminals spring to life on your arrival, and lights spring back to life inside the factory. The Virtuals interrogate your forces, demanding to be caught up on millennia of Craver history. The Virtuals are delighted to see the return of their ancient--if slightly imperfect--servants. They offer you the power of the Infinite Factory...in exchange for your unending servitude.
The Virtual Endless clearly deserve your loyalty. Capture more worlds and honor their resurrection!
Possess at least $Amount01Name planets in your Empire.
High-value planets are indicated on your map with a special icon

You have fulfilled your master's task. The screams of the fallen do not deter your armies one inch as you darken the lights of an entire arm of the galaxy. The Infinite Factory has returned to full power, and the Virtual Endless have begun converting the Craver species to become the invincible swarm---a fleet of Wasps that will darken the galaxy. The Virtual Endless watch over the churning machinery, as their servants return to the purpose for which they were created. The conversion replaces the last organic parts in the Craver body with full cybernetics, a species that any of the Virtual Endless can control anytime from anywhere in the Galaxy. It is a more perfect Craver form, built to serve its creators, ready to black out the stars in an unending swarm. The Craver have become the Wasp, ready to relentlessly swarm the galaxy in service of their masters.
Final Chapter. A Time of Ascension

Reyaryn leads your forces through the Infinite Factory, bringing the lights back on with a snap of its fingers in every room. The factory slowly churns back online as they go deeper and deeper into the factory. Reservoirs of molten Dust pour from massive iron bowls, conveyer belts carry the parts for Craver ships, tanks, and bodies, all unlike your soldiers have ever seen. And deep in the factory, Reyaryn finds its greatest secret: ancient terminals containing the minds of the Virtual Endless who oversaw this factory. The Virtual Endless greet Reyaryn who explains the Craver's rebirth over these last few thousand years, and the work they put in to find the Infinite Factory. The Virtuals are delighted to see the return of their ancient--if slightly imperfect--servants. But if you desire the power of the Infinite Factory, you must swear utter loyalty to your ancient masters--and break the very spine of the galaxy itself. What will it be?
Rebellion
The Craver will not be slaves again. Prepare for battle.
Defeat the Wasps Fleet and Invade the $CraversSystemName

Chapter 1. Church and Cloth - Part 1

Brother Ateb was caught gorging on the slaves today. He shall be forbidden sustenance for three days; his suit receptors deactivated. All must obey the Laws. It is a great and lonely thing to rule the Vodyani Protectorate; a heavy responsibility that I wear with pride. We have but our faith and our suits, our "Cloth", which protects and maintains our spirits during our Holy efforts: To guide the faithful, discipline those who stray, and punish those who preach heresy. And of all those heretics who must be punished, Isyander Shumèd the Infidel is the greatest. He is also my brother, he who fomented a rebellion, freed the slaves, stole a ship, and crippled the Protectorate for decades. He who discovered the Tabernacle of Lies and believed every word of it. The day will come when all deeds are counted and tallied in the great network that binds us together. And on that day The Infidel will burn--even if it must be by my own hand. Even if he is my brother. But that day is not yet come; and by Their will I hope it does not come soon for we have much to prepare: A system to pacify, a new galaxy to civilize, the ignorant to convert, the Infidel to punish. The rigors of faith permit us no rest. My faith burns with the flame of a thousand suns, and no power in the galaxy will deter me.
Destroy

The Prestors and Custos will see to the faithful; I must look outward to secure our new home. Those who are here must come to accept us and learn our ways. Our first step is to deal with those who cannot understand reason, history, and the Laws; they are pirates, and shall be dealt with as will all brigands and unbelievers.
Destroy the indicated Pirate fleets in or near your home constellation.
All other fleets must be eradicated to ensure the safety of your new home.

There was more than weapons and violence to these Pirates--they bore the imprint of the Tabernacle, that fountain of lies that deceived my brother. This must be pursued! We must uncover the truths of this new place, either by exploring and studying, or by bringing another people under our unbending wing.
Chapter 1. Church and Cloth - Part 2

Sister Ynes did not understand that history must be handled gingerly, like any other explosive power. She heard word of our search for the Tabernacle, and began asking improper questions. Her Cloth shall not speak to others for a week; she must learn to hold her tongue. All must obey the Laws. There is a sense of destiny, a thrill that we feel on the bridge of the ship. Though it is not acknowledged it is there and almost tangible; we are all eager to discover the fountain of lies called the Tabernacle and watch its falsehoods fall to pieces, like mist before a blazing sun. I cannot let the excitement show as other, less responsible members of the Church might. I must remain stoic and steadfast; when the time comes to show the lies for what they are I will not exclaim with eager joy. I will nod, and turn, and give the next order. I will never show the curiosity that burns within me...
Cooperate

The Tabernacle! I had thought that edifice of evil was distant, or long destroyed by the faithful, or perhaps even taken by the Infidel. To find it we must speak with the peoples who lived here before our arrival. We must us gain their confidence, share our faith, and bring them into our flock.
Brainwash a new Minor Civilization to learn more about this galaxy.
Use the "Brainwash" Action to convert the Minor Civilization. If necessary, you can invade the Minor Civilization's system to control them instead.

The Tabernacle is not far! Was it luck or perhaps Their distant hand that brought us here? It is not by accident that the words Virtual and virtuous are so similar. I am aging; my suit groans with the passage of time and the growing complexities of the protectorate weigh upon me. But I will see this Tabernacle exposed for the lies it holds, and then destroyed.
Explore

The Tabernacle! I had thought that edifice of evil was distant, destroyed by the faithful, or perhaps even taken by the Infidel. To find it we must explore the strange places of this Constellation, and seek in holy temples the secrets that They may have left for us.
Explore at least $CuriosityAmountName Ruins-type Curiosities.
Curiosities can be discovered by entering a System; explore Curiosities using probes with the Fleet Action "Start Expedition".

The Tabernacle is not far! Was it luck or perhaps Their distant hand that brought us here? After all, it is not by accident that the words Virtual and virtuous are so similar. I am aging; my suit groans with the passage of time and the growing complexities of the protectorate weigh upon me. But I will see this Tabernacle exposed for the lies it holds, and then destroyed.
Chapter 2. Locus of Lies

Sister Nobe, one of our researchers, questioned her Confessor after analyzing fragments of the Tabernacle. For a week we shall leave her alone with her thoughts; all audio in her suit will be deactivated. All must obey the Laws. The pious will have their vengeance, and the faithless will burn. It has been so since They first chastized Their foolish brethren--those who would remain lumps of clay rather than ascending to the perfect virtues of virtuality. To bring order back to that which the Infidel damaged, we must break open the secrets of the Tabernacle in any way that we can. Whatever lies it tells must be countered with the truth, and whoever is seduced by its false scriptures must be purified.
Investigate

The first order is to obtain the Tabernacle by any means necessary. We must control the thing itself if we are to understand it. And we must understand it, for the echoes we hear of its stories and philosophies are . . . troubling.
With a level 5 or higher Hero, explore the $TabernacleSystemName System where the Tabernacle is located.
A Hero starts leveling up if they are assigned to a Fleet or System.

The faithful have done well! The Tabernacle is ours, and we now begin the process of reading, analyzing, and challenging its contents. I can only hope they turn out to be the lies we expect, rather than the seeds of deeper, unsettling truths.
Take Over
The falsehoods of the Tabernacle will not shake our faith. We must find the system where it sits, bring it under our control, and shatter its lies.
Bring the $TabernacleSystemName System--where the Tabernacle is located--under your control.
To control the System you will have to anchor an Ark there.
The evil Tabernacle is under our power! Glory to the Virtual! They have brought us to our goal, and we will now begin to peel back the layers of lies within this thing.
Alliance

First we must make friends with those who hold the place where the Tabernacle lies. It will be a strange world, a different world; a world both touched by Their grace and defiled by the Infidel. We can only hope that the others have taken precautions to isolate it.
Make Diplomatic contact with the other Vodyani and raise your status to "Peace".
It may require Influence to attain this level of diplomatic relations. Use the Diplomacy screen to interact with the other Vodyani.

They have shown us the Tabernacle, and together our finest minds have perused its contents. It is a great store of history and lore, but the lessons that we feared? They are simple and obvious; their falsehoods evident to any trained mind. Truly the Infidel was insane to have betrayed his people because of this!
Chapter 3. Church and Senate - Part 1

Sister Heri's zeal has outweighed her reason; she has let the upkeep and repairs to her Cloth lapse in order to study. We shall play the maintenance manuals for a week through her speakers so that she is better prepared next time. All must obey. I am floundering. The faithful look to me for direction and guidance, yet all I see are the trappings of a lost religion and a rigid hierarchy based on brutal conformity. What is the new role of the Vodyani, and where do we go? By what guidelines and philosophies do I dare to lead them, now that the old ones have been exposed as a web of echoing lies? One thing, at least, is clear: I will make no progress while the rigid traditionalists control our government and keep a stranglehold on laws and decisions. While I seek a new purpose for our people, I must make sure we are not held back by old habits.

I must strive to find a meaning for myself and my people. We have become a faithful without a faith, and the ancient conservatives in government will not help us to find a new way. Regardless of their declarations, I do not trust their convictions. They must go.
End the turn with a stock of $MinAmount01Name [prestigeColored] in your Empire.
You can do this by changing Propaganda, passing new Laws, and influencing Elections.
It pains me to see these changes happen, but not as much as it pained me to learn that the faith I followed for centuries was built on lies and hypocrisy. I will survive. We will survive.
Chapter 3. The Rewards of Faith

Brother Azar does not understand the difference between the sanctified and their servants; he was found debating philosophy with one of the lesser peoples. He must understand his place in the hierarchy of the galaxy; for the next month he will personally bring to the Fount all the lesser ones who will nourish his ship. All must obey. Those who doubted, doubt no more. The Vodyani have been given an ultimate blessing, a gift from the Glorious Virtuals. We now know beyond any shadow of a doubt that we are Their vessels and Their chosen ones, and that all of Creation exists to serve us. We know this must be true, as we are now able to absorb life force directly from all the lesser beings that inhabit this universe. What other sign do we need that our cause is just and our decisions blessed? There are the Virtuals, the Glorious, those who rose to the highest form of life and were betrayed by their brothers. There are we, the Vodyani, who follow in the their footsteps, obeying their laws and executing their will. Then there are all others, the lesser beings or lesser ones. They have no understanding of their role, which makes them occasionally difficult to manage. Their role, of course, is to provide us with nourishment. One might ask what one should do, given this power, and the answer is clear. We must wipe the Infidel and his false Academy from the face of the galaxy, and erect an Academy of Truth in its place. Let the blasphemers and heretics tremble; the faithful cannot be stopped. Glory to the Virtuals! We shall honor their name and in doing so spread their words.

Much of our power comes from our suits, our Cloth, painstakingly crafted from the morsels of wisdom programmed by the Glorious. Little remains intact, so we rely heavily on our holy Codexes; relics of the first order from Their temples. If we are to face the Infidel and his legions, we will need more.
Obtain $MinAmountName Minor or Major Home Systems
All empires stockpile the treasures of the Glorious in their capital systems...

These fragments of the great Truths… The voice of the Glorious, echoing through the millennia, urging us forward in faith and power! By the Dust and with the Codexes, we will see the Infidel crumble and the galaxy bow to serve us!

You have rejected traditional ways, yet the Senators in your government are the same. Develop new political trends in your government. Decrease the status of Religious Senators, and increase the Science and Military political trends.
The [religiousColored] #D9C282#Religious#REVERT# ideology can have no active laws for a period of $Amount01Name [turn].

If the [religiousColored] #D9C282#Religious#REVERT# ideology is elected, it automatically votes in a law. Prevent that from happening and don't pass other Religious laws. Also, remember that you can cancel a law at any time

It is a wrenching process, and I fear we have thrown out some of what was good in eliminating that which was bad. But change is always painful, and those who are gone represented all the worst of our old ways. Now we can move ahead, unworried, to rewrite our future.
Final Chapter. Hope in Heresy - Part 1

It was a painful necessity. Had Inquisitor Lyne and his fanatics followed their instincts, my implication with the Tabernacle and the search for my brother's whereabouts may well have come to light. It is a difficult thing to cripple one's flagship and send a few hundred carcasses of innocent faithful into the cold of space, but fate is a cruel taskmaster. At first I assumed that my brother, Isyander, broke the Tabernacle after the truths were too much for him. The more I study and the more I read, however, the more I believe that he has left a trail of breadcrumbs. At each turn, following each hint, more data is revealed and more lies are undercut. Would the entirety of the information drop on me at once I may well have reacted in the confused rage that he demonstrated. But he remains a step ahead of me. "Seek the old places, eliminate those who refuse to listen, learn the truth..." He is seducing me into his heresies, indoctrinating me into his new religion. For I now believe that this is his goal: To bring back those who lived before the Endless. There was another... people? Race? Group of sentient beings? The images and impressions I see are of Dust-golden things the size of trees, or of planets, or of systems... Beings of majesty and contemplation, beings whose very bones and flesh were nothing but Dust. Primordial Dust. The original Dust, that the Endless imitated with their technologies. And Isyander would bring them back? Is this even possible for beings who were harvested to extinction during the dark years of the Dust Wars? There is so much that I must know, so many things that I must ask my brother. Before I either embrace his faith, or kill him.

More must be eliminated if any sort of balance is to be redeemed. The Endless, first in genocide, will see their culture treated as they treated the Lost. What right do they have to live on in our memories as gods, when they were demons who butchered the god-like for their bones?
Destroy $Amount01Name planets of Type Hot. Endless Ruins and their precious Dust will be destroyed as well.
You will need the "Core Cracker" module to destroy planets.

It is only a start, and I am the first to admit that it is a rough and ugly justice. But I will pray with a calmer spirit, knowing that those who butchered for gain will have their memories turned to rubble.
Final Chapter. Hope in Heresy - Part 2

I cannot rest; I find no solace in Essence. I begin even to question our way of life, our hierarchy, our source of sustenance. The glyphs and images of the Tabernacle have carved relentless patterns into my mind, disrupting my peace and rendering me incoherent and indecisive. This cannot last. This level of distraction is not acceptable. Regardless of Right and Wrong, regardless of the truth or falsity of these historical relics, I am the leader of a church and a people and I owe to them everything that I can give. Until the day that I die or am removed from office, I am obliged to execute my powers. Though even without the weight of oaths and traditions, I care that the Vodyani survive and thrive in this galaxy of complexity and contradictions. So I must take the next steps to determine our fate and the future of the Vodyani. It is a simple decision, really. I will go and visit my brother. At the head of a fleet.
The Academy has too many secrets and hides too many things. Assign a loyal Hero as governor in order to learn its secrets.
Assign a Hero of at least level $MinimumLevelName to govern the Academy system.
To level up your Governor, you can build Improvements and Ships.

Strangely, it is good to see Isyander in spite of his new garb. He has survived these many decades, so I have hope that the Vodyani will find some source other than Essence for our own sustenance. But that is secondary to the greater purpose: The future of my people and their church. I stare grimly into the future, unsure but unbowed. All must obey my laws.
Final Chapter. Hope in Heresy - Part 2

The glyphs and images of the Tabernacle have carved relentless patterns into my mind, disrupting my peace and rendering me incoherent and indecisive. This cannot last. Until the day that I die or am removed from office, I am obliged to execute my powers. Though even without the weight of oaths and traditions, I care that the Vodyani survive and thrive in this galaxy of complexity and contradictions. So I must take the next steps to determine our fate and the future of the Vodyani. My control of the Academy system and its secrets must be unquestioned. My brother must step down from his position, and I will appoint a Hero that I can trust in his place. I do not look forward to the conversation, but his precious store of knowledge lies within my borders. Here, I am the Hierarch, and he is subject to my will.
Only with the Academy under Vodyani control, can peace be found--and the future of the Church secured.
Possess the $AcademySystemName System where the Academy is located.
Re-assign a Hero or hire one from the Academy and assign them as Governor to the system with the Academy

I have placed my boot firmly upon the Academy, and my brother will explain in depth what his plans are. But that is secondary to the greater purpose: The future of my people and our Church. I stare grimly into the future, unsure but unbowed. All must obey my laws.
Final Chapter. The Church Triumphant - Part 1

Brother Olep committed the unthinkable. He obtained the works of the Infidel -- "..in order to disprove the lies…" -- and began asking questions of those who were unprepared to respond to the Infidel's meticulously structured fallacies. Olep shall be entombed in lead and left drifting in the void of space. All will obey. The acts of the Infidel leave us little choice. He began by attempting our destruction, then went on to create this Academy; a pulpit from which he spouts his lies and fallacies and preaches against us. He has subverted Heroes to oppose us, and ceaselessly striven to destroy the Church. Though the Church, of course, abhors the eradication of intelligent life (for only intelligent life can aspire to the state of the Virtual) we see no other options. The works of the Infidel must be utterly disassembled. It is ordained, then, that I continue to struggle against the evils wrought by my brother. But I view this as an honor to our family. I will not have the memory of the Infidel stain the name of Erad-Gaiheyal.

It falls to me to erase the blot on our name -- and to one day remove my brother's name from any history of the galaxy. I must place the Church in a position of power, and let our glory radiate across the galaxy. All beings must learn to acknowledge our purity and accept the glory of virtuality. There is no other truth.
Exert $MinimumPressureName Positive Pressure on at least 1 Major Empire.
Diplomatic pressure is generated by expanding your sphere of influence, sending ships into another empire's territory, making demands, etc.

For now the galaxy yields before our virtue; one day they will kneel before our glory. To do this, we must remove the influence of the Infidel. Isyander. My brother. That future has not yet come, but the clock ticks, and I find myself eager for the confrontation.
Final Chapter. The Church Triumphant - Part 2

He obtained the works of the Infidel -- "..in order to disprove the lies…" -- and began asking questions of those who were unprepared to respond to the Infidel's meticulously structured fallacies. The lies of the false Academy and Isyander cannot be tolerated. We must build a new Academy; create a true center of learning of Dust and legend that tells the story as it should. That story is of the glory of the Virtuals, the rise of the Vodyani, and the state of virtuality as the ultimate goal of any sentient species. We shall destroy the false Academy, and build the true one.
Build $ConstructibleAcademyName on one of your Systems.
Build the unique System Improvement "Academy of the Virtual Saints"

For now the galaxy yields before our virtue; one day they will kneel before our glory. To do this, we have removed the influence of the Infidel. Isyander. My brother. The Church will survive the storms that come; I will lead it into a greater future. Glory to the Virtual Saints! All must obey the laws.
Chapter 1. Business as Usual - Part 1

I chewed Arden out after that fiasco. He managed to upset all three of the other families, not to mention a few of my Meos siblings. How much clearer can instructions be than, "Do what you gotta do, and don't get caught?"
The kid had promise, but more *papilla* than propriety. Brash is good, but brash and canny is better. As the current head of the Families I wanted to keep the others off balance, not start a war. "It doesn't matter," he said. "They don't understand Dust any better than we do. They'll be back, one by one, to do business with us. New business. Galactic business. Measured in Dust, not sakan." What do you know. First was Oros Oros'Arrakyo herself, in a wheelchair but with eyes that glinted like harpoon tips. She pointed a limb toward the sky and said, "Up there. We're going to go there, build there. No zoning laws, no building codes. Give me access." When she leaned forward it was like she was ready to spear a fish. "Let's get rich. The Meos. The Arrakyo. Together." She left, and Arden and I had barely started discussing the possibilities when Irio Fer'Barda strode in, worth three trillion sakan but looking like his clothes cost ten. "No detritus. Here's the deal. Developing space means stations, ports, docks, factories. We know there's cheap labor out there, and no workplace safety hassles and whiny environmental regulators. The Omokar can develop the galaxy. You bring us in, we cut you in. Everybody wins." And late at night, some time after their evening services to their whale gods, Jodan Kurn Ade'Lancellum arrived, ready to sell seawater to squid. "You know what you need, but I'll tell you anyway. Exploration. Protection. Freight. Tourists. You need ships. Ships, you say? Who do I go to? Yeah, that's right. Lancellum. Us. Colonies and outposts means trade, travel. Ships. Let's do this thing." He pointed out the window. "Boom!" Arden and I were grinning at each other when he left, but for different reasons.
"So who do we work with?" I mulled. "Doesn't matter," he said. "This is just the start of the game. We can pick and choose. But you know what the endgame is gonna be?" He leaned in. Expensive cologne. I wondered who else was paying him. "Dust. It's all gonna come down to Dust..."

The Arrakyo want to develop some greenfield colonies far from the eyes of taxmen and regulators. That means markets for Meos cigars, brandy, and algae oil. Why not? It means land for them to develop, and more farms and markets for your products.
Arrakyo
Assimilate $Amount02 Minor Civilizations.
Assimilate the Minor Civilization through the actions on the Minor Faction Diplomacy screen
Now that's how you create opportunity! New systems and new customers ready for our high-end products. This whole "outer space" thing is looking highly profitable.
The Omokar own construction on Jenes, and want to own it in space, too. Cheap labor for their sites means cheap labor for Meos farms and refineries, too.
Omokar
Be present on at least $Amount01 planets.
You can be present on several planets on the same system or in different systems. The planets can be either Outposts or Colonies.
These guys look strong, eager, and not that smart. What else could you want in your factories?
Collaborate with the Lancellum by prospecting across the galaxy for some prime undeveloped real estate. They'll get business, and you'll find markets.
Lancellum
Discover at least $Percentage % of the Systems in this Galaxy.
You will need both exploration ships (Arrakyo-class) and probes to do this.
There's nothing quite like an untapped market to make a Lumeris heart beat faster. And with the right ships, we can be sure to control them.
Chapter 1. Business as Usual - Part 2

So far, business with the Arrakyo seems good. We have new outposts, and that means new development opportunities for Arrakyo moguls--and plenty of buyers for our Meos products. But we still need trustworthy management.
Management
A firm and clever hand is required to run Family business. Assign a Hero as governor to a System and let them impress you.
Assign a Hero as governor on a System, then raise them to at least level $MinLevelName.
Discover the Academy or build the Academy Embassy to enable Hero recruitment.
Now that's what I call talent. A leader that can pull things into shape and get us ready for the next step. The big one: Making sure we had the contacts to keep everything going smoothly.
Business is Unusual

These Minor Civilization rubes look like they've never seen civilization before. They're happy to have a steady job, and we're happy to help them spend their paychecks. It's win-win, but there are more opportunities out there.
Payoffs
Some dissident starting organizing the Minor Civilization workers -- that's a low blow! It's going to take some payoffs to get things moving again.
Reach $DustAmountLoc [dustColored] per [turn] in one of your Systems.
Dust production can be increased through Planetary and System Improvements.
That's not a pretty scene. Expansion is going nicely, but we need to make sure there are no more political hiccups. That'll be the next job for the kid, Arden.
Business is Unusual

The Lancellum sure came through on the deal, so the Kid couldn't have riled them too much (though rumor has it he robbed one of their shuttles a couple months back). But now that we have ships, it's time to get them out there making money.
Muscle
We found a few worlds out there off the cosmic string lanes; undiscovered and ripe. Now it's time to conquer new markets--literally. There's no use finding a market if you can't force it open.
Build $Amount03 Ships with $Amount04 [offensiveMilitaryPower] Offensive Military Power.
Military Power is increased by adding Attack and Defense Modules and by using larger Hulls.

And now the paper-pushers are mumbling about using military vessels for civilian purposes! It's time to start making waves in the government. Without the right influence, you can't do business anywhere.
Chapter 2. A Matter of Influence - Part 1

I was filtering the reports, and the reports were good. Our sales were up, the Meos clans and affiliates were happy with business, and all the regulatory inspectors were three jumps behind when it came to keeping up. Still, Arden looked like somebody had sugared his cod. "Nobody gets it. This is just the same old stuff. Old chum in new packaging. That's not the big opportunity. You know what is?" He opened his mouth to say it but I beat him to it. "Dust. Sure. But right now it's good as a currency standard, and I don't want to get crazy about it. When the opportunity comes, we'll move. But I'm not going to kill the sweet deals we have going for something risky--something that might cause bad blood." He was fuming, pacing, just a fish who wanted to swim with the sharks before his teeth were even formed. "Right now, we have two things going. The Meos and the Lancellum are allying to grow the trade routes, capture resources, and expand our markets. The Omokar and Arrakyo are going full exploitation--real estate, commercial buildings, entertainment complexes. And we can go with either one, as soon as we solve our problem . . ." He leaned in. He didn't like that word, either. "See, the politicos and paper pushers are screaming for attention--new laws, restrictions, inspections, all the stuff we wanted to leave behind. It isn't fun, but it's critical as oxygen. Regulations. Politics. Influence." I gave him a list of names, addresses, vulnerabilities, secrets, and lobbyists and told him to get to work. He was about go digging in the smelliest parts of the Lumeris bilges . . .
Industry Friendly
The Omokar and the Arrakyo see the galaxy as planets, not routes. Help them gain political influence so they can minimize labor and workplace safety problems and exploit the galaxy more efficiently.
Reach $MinimumScoreName % [industrialistColored] #DF8269#Industrialists#REVERT# in $Amount01Name Systems.
Industrialist ideology is increased by constructing Industry-oriented Improvements and colonizing.
Plenty of workers and fewer whiners. If that doesn't give us the galaxy on a platter, I don't know what will.
Trade Friendly

The Lancellum and the Meos have a common cause in expanding Trade Routes and extending the markets for Lumeris agricultural products. See that pliable politicians are in place to remove restrictions on the passage (and consumption) of Meos goods.
Reach $MinimumScoreName % [ecologistColored] #B0C65d#Ecologists#REVERT# in $Amount01Name Systems.
Ecologist ideology is increased by Food and Approval Buildings, civilian ships, new population and Terraformation.
Now there you go! We'll keep the oceans clean and our hands dirty--that's just the way the Families like it.
Chapter 2. A Matter of Influence - Part 2

The kid is dealing pretty well with the Omokar and the Arrakyo. His returning stolen funds might have helped, but he also pitched a pretty good story about "performance enhancing ingestibles"--most of which grow on Meos farms. Or, as he puts it, "pharms from farms". So what we need next is clear--the more laws we can get passed, the more amendments and riders we can slide in there to protect our business.
Industrial Policy
No matter what laws get passed, we're in a position to make money off them. Let's get a few more going…
You need to have an Industrialist-friendly political party in the Senate to enact Industrial Laws

The Omokar and the Arrakyo are even thicker than thieves. The Kid got a whiff of their big plan: Resorts and casinos all over the known galaxy. I got to give them credit for dreaming big. In addition they want to go legal--mostly--so they'll be pushing us for labor, systems, and buildings. It's time to think . . .
Reach $AmountLoc Active [industrialistColored] #DF8269#Industrialist#REVERT# Laws.
Chapter 2. A Matter of Influence - Part 2

You can name a law whatever you like--as long as we own the people that write and enforce them, we get what we want. The Lancellum and the rest of the Meos are behind us; maybe because that kid Arden came up with the idea of insuring the other Families' vessels and using "independent security specialists" to hijack them. But we owe the Lancellum something for their cooperation, and they're asking for extra budgets. Hey, you clean my gills, I clean yours . . .
Porkbarrels
The Lancellum need some laws passed -- any laws! -- so they can add some riders and amendments and get their personal projects funded.
To enact Laws you need to collect Influence.

Working with the Lancellum isn't too bad; for whale-worshipping sky pilots they're pretty good allies. And now my family and the Lancellum want to go all-out to the stars--trade routes, intergalactic commerce, a network of deals and influence across the galaxy. Kinda gets me all tingly just thinking about it . . .
Reach $LawAmount Active Laws.
Chapter 3. A Question of Dust - Part 1

Arden was at it again. The Kid keeps letting his enthusiasm get the better of him, and I keep getting angry visits from our partners. Some people say the new pharmas they're coming up with are causing everything from addiction to violence to hospital visits; others are telling me the unions are up in arms over the cheap labor we're getting from the minor civilizations we've been co-opting into the work force. Now I have rumors in from out of system that a group of mercenaries got drunk, busted up an orbital, and then laughed at the police because "Arden would take care of them." As long as business is good that should keep the selachimorpha sated, but if trouble keeps popping up like this someone is going to have the take the Kid down -- hard. But if the Families are wrapped up in big projects they might ignore these minor issues. So it's either going to be exploiting planets and shipping Meos goods via Lancellum ships, or building big Omokar platforms on big Omokar planets thanks to clever Arrakyo colonization techs. The Kid better move fast and at least cause some new problems, or they'll net him once they start to investigate the old ones...

It's pretty clear where we need to go -- big ambitions require big platforms to build them. We need big, wealthy planets full of folks who just love our forms of recreation -- whether they're in a casino or an emporium. If we can make the people happy, the people will be happy to make us rich.
You may need to learn new colonization technologies for this.
Fat, dumb, and happy. That's just how I like my voters. All we need to do now is give them something to goggle at, and the final step will be within reach.
Possess at least $MinAmountName Huge Planets.

The warehouses are full to bursting, and there isn't a palm in the galaxy that hasn't been greased to let our goods through. It's time to expand the trade routes and start scoring some serious sakan!

The only thing booming more than business is my headache -- the Kid spiked the punch at the Families' celebration, and now all that good will has sunk deeper than whale detritus. Whatever comes next, it better be good or it's his funeral.
Bring a System to Level $MinLevelName.

There are many ways this can be achieved. Through diplomatic channels, extending zones of influence, buyouts, or simply invading.
Fat, dumb, and happy. That's just how I like my voters. All we need to do now is give them something to goggle at, and the final step will be within reach.
Take over $MinAmountName Home Systems of Minor or Major Civilizations.

Blockaded or active Trade Routes all count towards the total.

The only thing booming more than business is my headache -- the Kid spiked the punch at the Families' celebration, and now all that good will has sunk deeper than whale detritus. Whatever comes next, it better be good or it's his funeral.
Possess at least $TradeRouteAmountName Trade Routes.
Final Chapter. A Question of Honor

There's only one thing the Families like more than money -- okay, almost as much as money -- and that's theater. It's our species' pastime and passion, and more deals have probably been struck in VIP seats during intermission than anywhere else. The Kid knew that. Parks, churches, restaurants, hotels, and aquariums got nothing on theaters; the Barda-Omokor feud ended in a VIP box, and the Meos cut loose from the Arrakyo and became a full Family via a negotiation conducted during intermission at the bar of the Ormandi Hall. But last night, unless I got something wrong, the Arden and his troops violated the oldest unwritten line of our codes: they took out a Rada councilor to the Lancellum during "Sanglarotti". And they didn't even have the decency to let the poor girl hear the end of the aria. So somebody is at war with somebody, and I gotta quick figure out who I can point at who and whether or not I can make everybody rich enough to forget what the Kid did. That, or tell them where he is and let Arden float belly-up with the birds.
Hostage
The only way to keep Arden alive is to show I can work miracles. Grab a shovel and start digging, Kid. This one is on your back.
Colonize Desert planets. You may need to discover the technology for this first.

Every time I thought I had the Kid figured or cornered, he'd turn around and pull something out of his… hat. And this one beat them all. Using his charisma, cash, and cunning he's come up with his most ambitious scam yet -- The Casino at the End of the Galaxy. If we get it built we'll all die richer than rich! I'm on board for the ride, and I'm guessing that getting there will be way more than half the fun.
Possess at least $MinAmountName Desert Planets.
Unmade

Oh well, Kid. You went from being "made" to being muck. Not only that, but the Arrakyo insist that your Trade Routes bring in more than just Dust. I'll miss your efficiency, but not your sloppy excesses.
Increase the amount of Science from Trade Routes.

Ah, Kid. If you could have seen what else those trade routes could bring us. With the knowledge to exploit the Dust we're collecting, it's looking like even a galaxy is too small for the Families. I've already bought a planet that's going to be my personal getaway. And guess what? The troublesome local wildlife have been officially classified as "procyon ardensis". Sleep well, Kid.
Arden had it all wrong -- Reach $IncomeAmountName [scienceColored] thanks to Trading.
Takedown

That was a dive too deep, Kid. You forced me to choose between you or the galaxy, and only one of them is going to make the Families trillionaires. Don't worry, I'll name a branch office after you - and send our troublemakers there.
Produce a minimum of 250 Dust from Trade Routes.

Arden never quite understood that this is chess, with corporations and empires as the pieces. He only ever saw one move ahead, and that got him killed. I'll avenge him, eventually, when the time is right. Because firstly, I put him up to it, and secondly, I am a master, and there is no greater game.
Back to business. Produce $IncomeAmountName [dustColored] from Trade Routes -- and use some of it to give Arden a decent burial.
Fugitive
Deaths have happened before, though this one was gratuitous. With luck we can buy off the Lancellum with luxuries. Without luck, it's war.
You need to colonize a planet to possess its Luxury Deposits.

I almost wish the Lancellum hadn't let themselves be bought off. When blood gets that thin, you wonder if they still deserve a place at the table -- not to mention a box at the theater. But Arden came through for me enough times that I figured it was worth a little pressure here and there to clean things up properly. So I gave him plenty of Dust and a one-way ticket to wherever he wanted to go. So he's out there somewhere, caught between his oversized dreams and his oversized ego. He can cause all the trouble he wants, because now he has to clean it up all by himself. Here's to no longer looking at you, Kid.
Possess at least $SixName [Lux00Luxury] Luxury Deposits.

But last night, unless I got something wrong, the Arden and his troops violated the oldest unwritten line of our codes: they took out a Rada councilor to the Lancellum during "Sanglarotti".
