So somebody is at war with somebody, and I gotta quick figure out who I can point at who and whether or not I can make everybody rich enough to forget what the Kid did. That, or tell them where he is and let Arden float belly-up with the birds.
Hostage
The only way to keep Arden alive is to show I can work miracles. Grab a shovel and start digging, Kid. This one is on your back.
Colonize Desert planets. You may need to discover the technology for this first.

Every time I thought I had the Kid figured or cornered, he'd turn around and pull something out of his… hat. And this one beat them all. Using his charisma, cash, and cunning he's come up with his most ambitious scam yet -- The Casino at the End of the Galaxy. If we get it built we'll all die richer than rich! I'm on board for the ride, and I'm guessing that getting there will be way more than half the fun.
Possess at least $MinAmountName Desert Planets.
Unmade

Oh well, Kid. You went from being "made" to being muck. Not only that, but the Arrakyo insist that your Trade Routes bring in more than just Dust. I'll miss your efficiency, but not your sloppy excesses.
Arden had it all wrong -- Reach 250 Science thanks to Trading.

Ah, Kid. If you could have seen what else those trade routes could bring us. With the knowledge to exploit the Dust we're collecting, it's looking like even a galaxy is too small for the Families. I've already bought a planet that's going to be my personal getaway. And guess what? The troublesome local wildlife have been officially classified as "procyon ardensis". Sleep well, Kid.
Arden had it all wrong -- Reach $IncomeAmountName [scienceColored] thanks to Trading.
Funeral
It's not like I had a lot of choice. It was either Lancellum ships and the galaxy, or the Kid and a bunch of headaches. Sorry, Arden. I had to tell him that it wasn't personal, just business…
You can find the resources on some planets or buy them on the Marketplace.

You can't imagine what the galaxy looks like from the bridge of a starship. I'll raise a glass to the view and to the Kid. Maybe name a star after him. With an ego that big, I think he'd be pleased if he were still around. The Families are on the move, and even the stars aren't the limit.
Send the Kid off in style - Build a Ship, using at least $FiveName Strategic Resources of each type, with Arden's body as cargo.
Fugitive
Deaths have happened before, though this one was gratuitous. With luck we can buy off the Lancellum with luxuries. Without luck, it's war.
You need to colonize a planet to possess its Luxury Deposits.

I almost wish the Lancellum hadn't let themselves be bought off. When blood gets that thin, you wonder if they still deserve a place at the table -- not to mention a box at the theater. But Arden came through for me enough times that I figured it was worth a little pressure here and there to clean things up properly. So I gave him plenty of Dust and a one-way ticket to wherever he wanted to go. So he's out there somewhere, caught between his oversized dreams and his oversized ego. He can cause all the trouble he wants, because now he has to clean it up all by himself.
Here's to no longer looking at you, Kid.
Possess at least $SixName [Lux00Luxury] Luxury Deposits.
Prologue: TO THE STARS!

The Empire is ready to expand into the galaxy, and bring its mighty civilization to new worlds, maybe even new patriots. The first starship yards have just finished building their inaugural vessels, and now is the time to send them out into the waiting cosmos.
The Empire must bring its civilization to the stars. It is our destiny!
Discover and colonize another star System by bringing a [colonizer] Colonizer Ship to a System that harbors a colonizable planet.
To build other [colonizer] Colonizer Ships, a Ship Design is now available in your System construction list.
The Empire spreads among the stars! Even better, word of our exploits reached a famous United Empire Hero, Dmitri Lenko, who has elected to rejoin our cause!
Chapter 1. A Hidden Rebellion - Part 1

It's like a knife through your heart. "You joke, Hadri," you say, knowing the Sheredyn never jokes. He shakes his head. "The weapon signature leaves no doubts." You stare out at the starfield, anger growing. A United Empire fleet fired upon by a fellow UE vessel of obsolete design . . . "How old--" "Twenty-five solar cycles at least, Your Imperial Majesty. We think there must be an outpost out there somewhere." The knife twists. This is no reactionary rebellion. This is something fomented decades ago, meticulously planned, kept hidden with a military-like focus. Few would possess the courage, the resources, the sheer iron will to see through such an undertaking. Who would do such a thing? You thought the uprisings were a thing of the past, crushed forever when you disposed of Duke Anatov and finally united the empire all those years ago. Your heart chills. Could Lena, bitter ungrateful Lena, have hatched such a diabolical plot? Or maybe it was Hadri, so called First Protector Hadri Lenko, so near and yet so far from the seat of power? Or perhaps it was Petra Mandzukic, she who could trace her line to the great Mezari clans, who lusted over a greater power . . . No, no, no! This way lies madness. They are loyal subjects. I will find the perpetrator. Slowly. Methodically. You cling to the thought, a lifeline in an ocean of dark musings. Hadri coughs. "What is your command, Your Imperial Majesty?"
The moral response, the effective response, is to turn to violence. Or at least its threat. We will grow our glorious armies, march across the stars, and the enemy will know we come for them.
Intimidate
Reach $ManpowerAmountName [manPowerColored] Manpower stock in your Empire.
Empire Manpower begins accruing after System Manpower is full. To raise capacity unlock new Stages of the Military quadrant of the Technology Tree, or possess more Systems.

Victory! Without even a single weapon fired in anger. Balking at the build-up of your military forces, the rebels surrendered their fleet. Although their ships were too archaic to be useful, they had developed an interesting new technology. The biggest shock, however, was the identity of the rebel leader. Your sister, Lena wasn't blessed with only one child, Viktoria. She had another. An identical twin. Julinka.

The leaders will need punishing, but the foot soldiers of this rebellion would be better treated as weak, misguided souls. Souls who should learn of the financial inducements the Emperor is offering for information.
Bribe
Stockpile $DustAmoutName [dustColored] in your Empire.
Raise Dust through Trade Companies, Marketplace activity, and Economic Unlocks, among other methods

Dust. Buys armies, builds fleets--and gets tongues waggling. The rebel outpost fell easily. You named it Traitor's Reach as a warning to others. The biggest shock, however, was the identity of the rebel leader. Your sister, Lena wasn't blessed with only one child, Viktoria. She had another. An identical twin. Julinka.
Outpost: Traitor's Reach
Traitor's Reach
Traitor's Reach
Better to keep this matter private, or else be made a laughing stock. Sending a small fleet to locate and deal with the rebel outpost--discreetly and efficiently--is the right response.
Locate
Explore $LoopCountName Curiosities.
Send Explorer ships to Systems with Curiosities and use the "Start Expedition" Fleet Action or add the Curiosities to the Construction Queue if you own the System.

Success! Your exploratory fleet found--and crushed--the rebellion. Not much was worth keeping, but the records did provide some interesting insights. The biggest shock, however, was the identity of the rebel leader. Your sister, Lena wasn't blessed with only one child, Viktoria. She had another. An identical twin. Julinka.
Chapter 1. A Hidden Rebellion - Part 2

Julinka, the traitor, refuses to speak. She is too young to be the true mastermind behind the rebellion, but of that individual's identity there is no clue. You will not sanction any violence against your sister's blood, so she languishes in solitary confinement in the deepest depths of your Inquisitors' redoubt. Lena claims to have never laid eyes upon the girl--claims she must've been rustled away at birth and raised by those who plotted against the empire. Of her twin, Viktoria, there is no sign, the girl going to ground as soon as she heard news she wasn't a lone child. Out of shock or something more you do not know. You need time to untangle this dark web . . . The rebellion might be no more, but the fact it ever existed in the first place haunts your days and disturbs your nights. Who can you really trust? Every day you grow a little older, get a little closer to the day you will no longer be able to lead this great empire. You decide now is the time to name the Emperor-elect, and consolidate your power while you still hold it. The three candidates are obvious. First Protector Hadri Lenko, stalwart bodyguard for so many years, and a hero among the empire hawks. Lena Zelevas, your own flesh and blood sister. A woman who, despite her smoldering anger, would make an iron leader--and keep a Zelevas on the throne. Or should it be Petra Mandzukic? The brilliant head of Advanced Research, a woman who'd pioneered several chilling technologies that had transformed your army's fortunes, somebody who could grasp the opportunities of this new star faring era . . . The choice is not easy. Peace of mind is hard to find. Until you learn the identity of the rebellion ringleader, though, you will have no real peace. It could be one of them. But choose you must.
Hadri

The Sheredyn is the right choice for Emperor-elect. Strong, respected, and a man who will surely echo your own style given the length of time he has stood by your side. To celebrate his naming, you should build a fitting ship.
Build a ship with at least $MinimumAttackName [offensiveMilitaryPower] Offensive Military Power.
Design ships with additional offensive modules
The people were happy to hear Hadri named Emperor-elect. He will need to play a larger role in events now.
Hero: Hadri Lenko
Lena

When you can no longer lead this great empire, a Zelevas should remain in the seat of power. Lena will be Emperor-elect. A fitting tribute should be constructed to mark this great honor you have bestowed upon her.
Produce at least $DustAmount [dustColored] per [turn] in your Empire.
Boost Dust production through System Improvements, Trade Routes, colonization of new Systems, or other means.
They cheered loudly when you announced Lena as Emperor-elect. Not unexpected perhaps, given her name. She will need to play a more prominent role in proceedings now.
Hero: Lena Zelevas
Petra

Only Petra can truly do the empire justice as we travel the stars. Scientist, realist, leader, and not one to shy away from hard decisions. You will strengthen the empire's science base to honor her naming.
Produce at least $ScienceAmount [scienceColored] per [turn] in your Empire.
Build new planetary, system, or empire-wide constructions that boost science or increase your population or colonize new planets
The people's reaction to Petra's naming as Emperor-elect is muted. You will need to prove that she is a deserving choice over the coming years.
Hero: Petra Mandzukic
Chapter 2. Looking to the Future, Excavating the Past - Part 1

The trail runs cold. Julinka rots in the cells, silent. Nobody knows anything about the ancient rebellion. Or nothing they're prepared to admit, at least. The knowledge eats away at you, day after day after day. You torture yourself, knowing how many countless thousands of patriots it must've taken to enact such a betrayal. Hidden shipyards, empire funds siphoned off official accounts, redacted records, double lives. Some of the snakes must still be among the masses here on Raia, lying over and over to preserve their skins. Will you need to search every lead yourself to know the truth? Who can be trusted? You try to put the matter out of your mind, and instead think of the millions of true patriots. Now the matter of Emperor-elect has been settled, it is time to turn your attention to their futures--and your legacy. What course should the great United Empire be set on before your rule ends? Should you heed the warnings of the warmongers in your ranks, epitomized by the Sheredyn name, and militarize? Or should you hark back to an earlier age of scientific invention, when your Mezari forbears sailed the great darkness? Or perhaps, you should stay this course, let the United Empire fulfil its true potential as an industrial powerhouse? This may not necessarily be your final legacy, but you should give your empire a taste of the future nonetheless.
Sheredyn

In this age of uncertainty, when the stars harbor the other, your empire will benefit from embracing its Sheredyn-side. The Emperor-elect $HeroName should witness and understand the might of your military fleets.
Win $BattleRequieredAmountName Battles.
Enemy fleets do not have to be eliminated, just defeated.

Your empire has proved itself more than capable of holding its own in a galaxy beset by fighting. $HeroName has learnt much, and your fleets even have a new toy to play with. Will you make this your legacy when the time comes though?
United Empire
You have held this empire together for nigh-on forty years by maintaining the United Empire values of order, labor, and prudence. Emperor-elect $HeroName must see how an empire is built.
Hold at least $MinSystemAmountName Systems of Level $MinLevelAmountName or higher.
Reach Stage 3 of the Economy and Trade quadrant of the Technology tree, acquire Luxury Resources, then begin a System Development Project. Afterwards enact the project on the required Systems.

Your glittering systems are jewels in your empire's crown. $HeroName has learnt much, even bringing a very useful industrial boost to the table. Will you make this your legacy when the time comes though?
Mezari

The ancient Mezari clans sailed the stars by understanding the great beyond. As your empire spreads through the galaxy, you should do the same. Studying the full range of worlds would be a good start.
Possess planets of every climate-type (gas-type not required).
Hot, cold, and temperate climate-type planets must be possessed via an outpost or colony.

With footholds in many different worlds, your empire's understanding of the galaxy has never been greater. Better yet, your population is ripe for embracing development that is in harmony with scientific thinking.
Chapter 2. Looking to the Future, Excavating the Past - Part 2

The empire grows, a picture of its end state slowly emerging. It will be glorious, there is no doubt of that. What troubles you though, is whose glory it will be? The betrayer is still at large. Julinka is still silent, despite being "encouraged" to speak. Now your empire spans light years rather than light minutes, the scope for uprising seems greater than ever. You fret, pace the palace, demand updates from distant fleets night and day. The people are happy though, are they not? They live in an era of unrivalled prosperity, do they not? And those that have joined the empire, have they not come to understand that their old ways were inefficient, backwards, and ultimately leading them to destruction? Who are you kidding? Revolt is always on your mind. You obsess about a distant system turning against Raia . . . The idea of $HeroName as Emperor-elect gains more support with each passing season, but you will have no true peace until the betrayer is uncovered, caught--and neutralized. "Harness the mood of the empire," $HeroName counsels, "and cement your power." "What do you mean?" "I mean impose your will by enacting more laws." You give a puzzled look. $HeroName continues. "Men are strange creatures. They will rail against spoken words, but give those same words permanence in writing and they will obey to their dying breath. Never forget the power of the rule of law, Your Imperial Majesty." $HeroName is right. You can tighten your control of the empire by strengthening its laws.
With the Sheredyn flank of the empire in the ascendency, enacting military laws should be straightforward.
Have at least $AmoutName [militaristColored] #B82738#Militarist#REVERT# laws active in your Empire.
Unlock extra Law slots by changing governments or reaching higher Stages of the Empire Development quadrant of the Technology Tree. Ensure Militarists are in your Senate to enact Militarist Laws.
Military laws keep your empire in an iron grip. The betrayer may still be at large, but for now you feel some degree of comfort that any kindling of revolt will not catch alight.
The industrial base of the empire has never been stronger. The time is ripe for passing industrial laws to cement your grip.
Have at least $AmoutName [industrialistColored] #DF8269#Industrialist#REVERT# laws active in your Empire.

Unlock extra Law slots by changing governments or reaching higher Stages of the Empire Development quadrant of the Technology Tree. Ensure Industrialists are in your Senate to enact Industrialist Laws.

Powerful industrial laws shape and control the empire. If the betrayer--or anyone else--has designs on fomenting a second uprising, they will find it difficult. You enjoy the moment of respite--for now.
A period of enlightenment illuminates the darkness; now you should strengthen your scientific laws.
Have at least $AmoutName [scientistColored] #52C9E7#Scientist#REVERT# laws active in your Empire.
Unlock extra Law slots by changing governments or reaching higher Stages of the Empire Development quadrant of the Technology Tree. Ensure Scientists are in your Senate to enact Scientist Laws.
Through the instrument of science, you guide and control your empire. For the time being, you sleep a little easier knowing rebellion is unlikely.
Chapter 3. No Turning Back

The time has come. Your grip on the empire has never been tighter, your laws never stronger. The restless nights that plagued your last few years now seem like a bad dream. Every night you lay your head down on your imperial pillow you quickly drift into a deep sleep, waking well-rested and content. What musings thread your dreaming mind are not concerned with paranoia or rebellion or the fate of a young woman slowly growing old in the depths of the imperial prison. The question of who masterminded the rebellion all those years ago no longer vexes you like it did. You'd be lying if you said it no longer troubled you in the slightest, but like your aging body, it is something you will grow to accept. What occupies your thoughts more is what the historians will make of your legacy. Before you hand the reins of power over to Emperor-elect $HeroName, you must decide the fate of the empire. Decisively. Will you steer the empire into the hands of the Sheredyn hawks? Or will you give power to the Mezari traditionalists who exalt science? Or perhaps you believe in staying the course, seeing through the project to conquer the galaxy as the United Empire. Whatever you choose, there will be no turning back. The fate of the empire rests in your hands.
Sheredyn
Only pure military power can underpin the necessary realpolitik that will see the empire victorious. Lead the empire into a Sheredyn future by strengthening your military.
Raise the number of [commandPoint] Command Points across your Empire to $MaxCommandPointsAmount.
Some technologies in the "Military" quadrant of the Technology screen can help you to increase the number of Command Points.

The transition to a Sheredyn empire is complete. Military figures decked in Sheredyn gold occupy positions of power across the empire, and your military strength has never been stronger. You smile, satisfied. All that remains to do is ensure a smooth transfer of power to Emperor-elect $HeroName.
Become Sheredyn
United Empire
Your strength has always come from the industry of your people and their willingness to bring the fruits of their labor to others. The empire should continue its path as the United Empire.
Set up $TradeRouteAmountName or more active Trade Routes.

Trade routes always start and end with Trading Companies built on two of your systems connected by one or several lines. Look at the "Trade and Economy" quadrant of the Technology screen to find these building technologies to research.

Wealth and materials flow between your systems, cementing your industrial heartlands. The identity of the empire as the United Empire has never been stronger. It is a fitting legacy for your rule. Now your attention must turn to overseeing a smooth transition to Emperor-elect $HeroName.
Stay as United Empire
Mezari

Only through embracing the ancient Mezari clans' adoration of science will the empire survive the coming struggles. The industrial age is over. It is time for the empire to return to its Mezari roots.
Produce $ScienceAmoutName [scienceColored] or more Science in your Empire per [turn].
New Star System Improvement dedicated to science can be unlocked by researching the right technologies in the "Science and Exploration" quadrant of the Technology screen.

When the first Mezari clans created their vast starfaring vessels they achieved something wonderful with the power of their minds. Your empire follows in their footsteps, your people's scientific invention never greater. Great technologies will follow. You are proud to be Mezari once again. Only the matter of the coronation of Emperor-elect $HeroName remains . . .
Become Mezari
Final Chapter. The Cult Of The Strongman - Part 1

You couldn't leave it alone, could you? With your Sheredyn commanders running more and more of your new empire, each day you find yourself with more and more time to kill. Do you sit back, enjoy the view and marvel at this world you have wrought? No, of course you don't. You dwell on the past. You stew in your shame and anger. Who betrayed me? Who betrayed me? It becomes a whispered litany, invading your thoughts, tormenting you. You begin poring over the old transcripts, seeking anew clues to the identity of the betrayer . . . Impatient for power, the Emperor-elect, $HeroName, tells you to stop wasting your days on a fruitless task. But then? Miraculously, you find something they all overlooked--a single word that unravels the entire wicked tapestry. You've found the shipyard! The shipyard where the traitors' colony ship was built. It's continents away, in the middle of vast, empty landscape, but surely . . . "Let go of the past," $HeroName says. "Your abdication ceremony is only days away." Your abdication. Their coronation. You don't have the heart to tell them there won't be any abdication. No one can lead this new Sheredyn empire like you can. You will stay Emperor until your dying breath. The only question is do you attend the ceremony in-person and announce that you're not relinquishing your duties? Or do you miss the ceremony to pursue this shipyard lead, and let $HeroName announce your decision?
Attend
Your people should hear it from your own lips that you will remain their Emperor. A special vessel should be built to carry you to the ceremony. The shipyard can wait a few more days.
Build a ship with the "Emperor" Module.
The "Emperor" module is now available to be equipped in the Ship Design screen.

You give a rousing speech to your people, announcing that you will remain Emperor. As you leave the platform, the crowd roars their approval, the noise deafening. Streamers fill the sky, and a Sheredyn Cruiser screams by overhead. Your ears ring, and your skin tingles. You feel more alive than for you've felt for a long time. Reborn. You are certain you will lead this Sheredyn empire to many more glories. $HeroName sulks, furious, but they will come round. You are the Emperor, after all. None disobey. The only blemish on the whole affair comes later when you finally visit the site of the rebel shipyard. Somebody must've got the word out that you'd discovered something; the whole place has been torched. Ash swirls, and the stench of smoke is overpowering. It is time, you think, to finally let go of your obsession. It is time to be consumed by the task of leading the Sheredyn instead.
Investigate

You cannot let this chance to learn the truth go. You will let $HeroName announce that there will be no abdication, that you will remain Emperor. It will be a chastising experience, but they will learn from it. Meanwhile, you will explore this lost shipyard . . .
Search the quest Curiosity on the Planet $OnePlanetName once you have gathered $Amount01Name [Strat03adamantianColored] Adamantian.
You can search for the Curiosity while orbiting the planet's star system with an Exploration ship or any ship equipped with the right module.

As you arrive at the derelict shipyard, a thousand klicks from the nearest settlement in a desolate, windswept landscape, $HeroName is just beginning their humiliating address to the capital crowds. You watch as they inform the assembled masses that you will remain Emperor. At first, an eerie silence greets the words, but soon the plaza is united in rapturous applause. "For the Emperor!" $HeroName cries, punching their fist skywards. Satisfied, you head into the decayed shipyard. The place is vast and dark. In puny pools of light from your hand-torch, you spend the better part of three days scouring its length and breadth. Mess halls, dorms, stockrooms, engineering galleys, foundries . . . the number of souls who must've contributed to the project staggers you. Their collective betrayal stings deep. Then you find the mass graves. You recall Mezari legends from the original homeworld of greedy kings who had the builders of their treasure-lined tombs murdered . . . Aside from promising tech designs, the place has been scrubbed clean. On the third day, exhausted and defeated, you climb to the top of the viewing tower, listen to the winds through the tunnels. You are about to descend when you catch something glinting underfoot. You stoop down, pick it up. It is an instamatic picture, crumpled and dusty, but still clear. It is a picture taken from this very platform. In the background is the rebel's colony vessel, almost finished, gleaming and imperious. In the foreground stand two figures. An engineer in a hard hat, grinning. And $TraitorName. Unsmiling. You are staggered. You steady yourself on the platform railings. All these years $TraitorName orchestrating a coup the likes of which had never been seen before. A grudge born in the last days before the empire became united . . . You know what will you do. One day $TraitorName will disappear, never to be seen again. And no one will ask any questions. That is the power of the Emperor.
Final Chapter. The Cult Of The Strongman - Part 2

You wear the Sheredyn colors with pride. Wherever you set foot in your empire--in the fiery heart of a foundry, in a barracks' dormitory, in far flung orbital--your people regard you with a calm deference. You are certain their respect comes from you, your leadership, your protective wing under which they've thrived. Not the presence of your Sheredyn entourage. Of the rebellion that troubled you so, you barely give a thought these days. You even set Julinka, the rebel outpost leader, free. After all, she was only an instrument of the true mastermind. You are at peace with the past. But the future? You still grapple with the future. What the galaxy needs to know is that Sheredyn diplomacy is different from what they knew before.
The time for compromise, for backing down and rolling over like dogs is over. You are Sheredyn. You will demand what you want, and if you don't get it you will take it by force.
Exert $MinimumPressureName Positive Pressure on at least 1 Major Empire
The level of positive pressure you exert on each Empire can be seen in the Diplomatic Status screen.

The galaxy learns. If anyone thought the old United Empire was too soft in its approach to diplomacy, then its new incarnation as a Sheredyn empire must satisfy the hardest of hardliners. Even $HeroName seems to have fallen into line after the bitter disappointment of not becoming Emperor. Perhaps one day they will command, but that day is not near. The transition seems to have gone down well with the rank-and-file of your population too. Strongarm diplomacy and aggressive posturing has led to an upsurge of military recruitment. More patriots than ever will lay down their lives to defend the mighty Sheredyn empire! From here, victory should be a formality . . .
Final Chapter. The Day That Never Comes - Part 1

An engineer in a hard hat, grinning. And $TraitorName. Unsmiling. You are staggered. You steady yourself on the platform railings. All these years $TraitorName orchestrating a coup the likes of which had never been seen before. A grudge born in the last days before the empire became united . . . You know what will you do. The empire is in crisis.

With the rain lashing down, you arrive on a promontory close to the bunker's location. Your scout steps out of the shadows, leads you down a windswept path to the bunker entrance. From the command hub to the dorm to the living quarters, anything to help identify the people who worked in this bunker is gone. The bunker's personnel are sat around, like they're waiting for something--or someone. Then a young-looking $TraitorName comes in, begins addressing the audience. You are stunned. I claimed to be, of course; every bit as beautiful and as smart as either of the other two. That had to be the case, for we were the most perfect copies--biological, psychological, developmental--that the most advanced cloning science of the galaxy could make. No scientific test existed that could tell us apart; each one of the three of us a microcosm of Horatio perfection. Yet only one was the real Horatio, Horatio Prime.
I wondered what parents had brought that Horatio up, had developed that magnificent brain into what it was. And I wondered how Horatio managed to imprint that upbringing as if it was a technical issue, like replicating DNA. Can a thing from a test tube have daddy issues?
We aligned ourselves with each other, Five and I, determined to avoid the fate of One, Two, and Three.. They had died in the lab, once Horatio Prime realized what we were thinking. Subtly we knew who was who, and he gave me his support when I claimed to be Horatio, the Original, Horatio Prime, the Light. And so I was crowned emperor, the gorgeous leader of a gorgeous empire. And Prime was put in chains.
But I know Five as well as he knows me--or Horatio himself. The minute he is out of my sight, he will scheme against me. As I, of course, will scheme against him. And as Horatio will scheme against both of us.
