I shall bow my head to him, briefly, before I remove his own. For he has created not merely the greatest web of deceit imaginable, but he did so when faced by the most redoubtable foe in the galaxy: Us. This is not some excess of ego; speaking of ourself in the first person plural is only right, as we speak for all Horatio and for the galaxy we will soon come to rule. Singular as we are, the scope of our genius cannot be contained by such a limited pronoun. The Horatio empire must continue to gain power and strength; our factories and universities shall create things of beauty in unstoppable quantity. But as we proceed with this we must also remember that Prime--or Five, as he was calling himself--will stop at nothing to stop us. My machine of perfection requires the most expensive and difficult resources, and we shall continue to seek and develop them. But under cover of this great operation of exploration and industry, my agents will begin to disassemble the web of Prime's machinations. And, when all is finished, I shall invite him for a glass of wine, and explain that I know his secrets. Then, in his moment of despair, I shall poison him.
Dominate

This drive for beautification is difficult work, requiring not merely my personal resources of charisma and brilliance, but strategic resources as well. Beauty must be strong if it is to last forever.
Have at least $Amount02Name Strategic Deposits in your Empire.
Strategic Deposits are gained by conquering or colonizing planets that have them.

Ah. Home again. It seems ages since all this madness began. Clones, clowns, and curiosities have been relentlessly bothersome. But I sit once again in my palace, drinking my wine from my goblets. A poor, dead Horatio watches me, but such is the price of attempted regicide. The beautification shall continue, for the good of the galaxy. Horatio is back, and here to stay.
Chapter 1. Beachhead - Part 1

The universe is utterly unlike our own. Burning orbs of fire, scarred balls of rock hanging in the void, vast realms of nothingness. Empty, pitiless, terrifying. Some of the worlds are more than barren, airless rocks. Cloaked in dirt that seems fertile ground for tenacious, foliaged forms, they choke the surface and deny the light. Strange things stalk and shuffle and slither through the undergrowth. We were fortunate to avoid settling on such a world. Our world, the world we named Vanguard on account of us being the spearhead, is a white wilderness broken only by still and silent forests, icy brooks, and perpetual grey skies. In its near-ceaseless white embrace, where the sky can sometimes be mistaken for the land, it is reminiscent of the homeland but if you look closer it cannot hide its grotesqueness. Things scurry under the snow, others open dark wings among the shadows; chilly waters crash and shriek against rocks; worst of all bursts of color sometimes burst forth unexpectedly--sunlight on fish scales, winter meadows blooming with flowers, sweeping curtains of green and purple light in the starry night. No words can do the horror justice. My forces suffer, but they are resolute. Their suffering is nothing as next to the plague that spreads through the homeland, Coroz. Every message from the Communion speaks of the blight growing, more and more of the world becoming dead and blackened. There are many paths we might follow to end this nightmare. Even in the little time I have spent in this world, I have begun to form my own ideas for what is best. But I am merely an instrument of the Communion, faithfully relaying the situation here to the best of my ability. They decide. I await their orders.
Explore

Vanguard and its neighboring systems are only one small corner of this universe, and yet they are brimming with mysteries. We would be foolish to expose ourselves to other dangers before we have learnt some of their secrets, and reaped some of their bounties.
Explore $Amount01Name Curiosities with a Hero of Level $Amount05Name or higher.
Use the Fleet Action "Start Expedition" to explore a Curiosity

Through brave expeditions we have mapped and catalogued Vanguard's horrors, from vast frozen caverns pierced with spears of ice to great floating glaciers that drift through cold, dark seas. With stockpiles of frozen fish, briny seaweeds, haunches of wild animals--putrid organic matter that goes for sustenance in this hostile universe--we have acquired useful commodities should we encounter other races. We are more certain of ourselves here now, but I, the Grand Viceroy of New Coroz, cannot help thinking that the Communion wasted precious time by ordering us down this path . . .
Strengthen

Here, in this universe, we are far from our homeland, our kin, our strength. For now, we are vulnerable to the monsters that lurk out there in the void. We must build a world that will become a fortress.
Have a System with $Amount02Name System Improvements in total.

Research Technologies to unlock new System Improvements. Notice that some buildings are probably already built on your system. Use the button near the System Upkeep to see the complete list of its improvements.

Feelings of strength sweep through my forces on Vanguard, making them even more determined in their mission. In their fields, their words, their very bearing I see that they are fearless, that they will defend Coroz--both the Old and New--to the death. We have our fortress. I wonder though . . . are we misplaced in our confidence? Did we build a stronghold from which to conquer the galaxy, or a prison to entrap ourselves for eternity? Did the Communion make a grave mistake?
Reach Out
The situation in Coroz is so bleak that we must put our trust in the other races of this galaxy. Surely they will understand our plight and help us?
Reach $Amount04Name points in relations with $Amount03Name Minor Civilizations.
Relations with other civilizations can be improved by trade, respecting borders, and peaceful interactions

It cannot be denied that some of the creatures who call this universe home have treated us well. But I have my doubts that they will always remain friendly. If the blight turns out to be unstoppable... We are invaders here, and the Communion would do well to never forget it.
Chapter 1. Beachhead - Part 2

Today, one of my patrols made a startling discovery. A curious, pitiful creature was found living in a windswept hovel on the edge of a great frozen lake far to the north. This universe, with its ugly forms, its soul-shuddering sounds, its perpetual downwards grasping, is difficult enough to understand at the best of times, but this creature was another level of enigma. With rags for garments, garbled speech, and erratic movements of its slender, serrated limbs, I wondered what possible worth this thing could possess? Over long, painful days, though, I came to appreciate that this creature, Anax-Jink, could be very valuable to us. Although Anax-Jink is a damaged soul, half-mad, half-delusional, its mind driven down dark, rarely traveled paths in its prolonged isolation, I found islands of clarity, even brilliance. Slowly, I learnt its story. It is a member of a race called the Virus. Well, maybe "race" is too generous a word for the smattering of creatures scattered across the galaxy who loosely share Anax-Jink's biology. The Virus, you see, are escaped viral lab experiments, hyper-evolved by a mysterious substance called Dust. Anax-Jink once lived with others, a commune of Eyder on an abandoned moon, but after it stole a great haul of Dust for research they fell out and Anax-Jink was banished. The Virus tells me the end-times are coming. I struggle to fathom whether its reasoning is genius or deranged, but knowing what I know of the blight destroying Coroz I cannot help but think its words are prophetic. It has the capacity for greatness, I believe. I have forbidden anybody mention Anax-Jink's existence to the Communion back on Coroz. To begin with that was because I needed to know more before I reported back, but too much time has passed for that to be true any longer, and now I must confront the truth. The truth is that the Communion are ill-equipped to lead in this universe. They are remote and out of touch, insulated from the seeping horror of this place. How can they make the right choices when they have no experience of here? They can't. So I, the Grand Viceroy of New Coroz, will decide the fate of Anax-Jink. One day, the Communion will thank me for it.
Kill

The Virus will teach us nothing more--at least not while living. Like a wrecked piece of machinery, it is damaged beyond repair. Even a liability. But dead we can slice it up, study it. My forces here will need a morale boost though. Many have grown fond of the Virus.
Maintain an Empire [happinessColored] of $Amount01Name or higher for $Amount02Name [turn].
Avoid Overpopulation and Overcolonization to keep the Population Happy

I confess to feeling a pang of guilt, but the Virus was a pathetic creature. Its suffering is over. Given the choice again, I would make the same decision. Besides, we learnt much of its biochemistry, its cellular structure by slicing up its brain. This may be priceless knowledge in our fight for survival. Life in this world still disgusts me, but I am the Grand Viceroy and I have my duty. Of Anax-Jink the Communion will never know.
Recruit

The Virus could become our greatest asset in this hostile universe. A scientific mind without parallel to study the rift. It just needs the right tools, the right environment. I will build it a cutting-edge research facility.
Colonize a new System and raise its [scienceColored] to $Amount03Name.
Construct Science-promoting System or Empire Improvements to raise Science production

Anax-Jink has proved itself a valuable ally of the Riftborn. It is not without its eccentricities, but there can be no doubt as to its capabilities. It will help our cause immensely over the difficult times ahead. I hope it is not too late. The Communion must never know of its origin, of course. They wouldn't understand.
Reunite
The humane thing to do is clear. The Virus should be brought back to its Eyder companions--with its debts paid by us.
Raise $Amount04Name [dustColored], then explore the Curiosity in $Planet01Name.
Creating Trade Companies and making Trade Routes is an effective way of generating Dust

On the moon where the Virus once lived with the Eyder we found a scene of desolation. Someone or something had attacked the commune, left Eyder corpses strewn through the facility like they were nothing more than discarded puppets. Witnessing the carnage, something broke in Anax-Jink. It lashed out at two of my personal guard, then scuttled deep into the shadows. We searched for it for the rest of the day, but found no trace of the Virus. Perhaps it is better this way. This world grows more terrible by the day. I have my duty, but I don't know how much more horror I can endure.
Chapter 2. A Plague on Coroz

The news from Coroz isn't good. The blight worsens. Every day I receive reports of new areas of our world becoming diseased, new casualties succumbing to stasis. I picture black, serpentine tendrils choking everything I once cherished. Even in this place, with my capacity to crush and stretch time like it is nothing more than a spring, I cannot escape the brutal, heavy truth of our plight. The Communion press for a full evacuation into this world. They imagine it a safe haven, where they might find refuge. They are mistaken. This universe is far from a sanctuary for us. It is a dirty, fetid place, awash with violence. The only thing they will find here is distress, and eventually death. Despite their suffering, we are just not ready for them. They should stay. Fight to the end to save Coroz. But they will not. I beg. No matter how hard I persuade them not to venture into this universe, my pleas fall on indifferent minds. All the horrors that I communicate--the blinding light, the fierce cold, the vast abysses--are merely meaningless words to them. They have no conception of this place. And as I am only the Grand Viceroy of New Coroz, as my authority stops where this universe ends, I cannot forbid them from coming. Eventually, though, I manage a minor victory of sorts. I convince them to delay the evacuation, give my forces enough time to prepare for their arrival. What can I do though? I might as well be seeking the end of the primes. Staring up at the starry night, I feel the weight of the universe crushing me, suffocating. From time to time, I think of Anax-Jink, wonder what it would've counseled. But the Virus is gone, and now I must decide for myself.
Acquire
Perhaps if we win power over another race, we might gain the servants we need to handle the evacuation of Coroz. A slim hope, I know, but we must do something.
Reach $Amount01ObjectiveName Non-Riftborn Population in your Empire.
Assimilating a Minor Civilization is one means of adding new Population types
Our new allies may or may not prove useful to the evacuation of Coroz. It is too early to tell. What is clear is that this delay has helped to clarify my own duty . . .
Secure
When they come, the least we can do is make sure they are safe from our enemies. The universe itself will provide enough of an adversary.
Ensure your Systems are not Blockaded or Guarded by rival Empires for $Amount02Name [turn].
Prohibit empires you are in Cold War with from entering your territory using the "Close Your Borders" diplomatic action, and use the Fleet Action "Guard" to intercept enemy fleets.

We have established an effective perimeter around our systems. The Communion press for the evacuation of Coroz to begin, but I am not so sure. Perhaps it is time to re-evaluate our priorities in these dire times . . .
Chapter 2. A Rebuke From On High

The horrors of this world grow daily. Its starry nights and fecund worlds, its so-called intelligent life born of evolutionary laws that pit every organism as winner or loser--everything horrifies, everything scars. The worst though, living in this artificial shell, is that slowly, but inexorably, I grow immune to its bleakness. Or perhaps not immune, but numb. I wonder . . . should Coroz ever be cleansed of the blight would I be able to return? Or am I forever changed? Am I destined to live out my years here in this universe? A moot question, perhaps. News from Coroz suggests no breakthrough in slowing, or even understanding, the blight. Perhaps if the Communion invested more of their energies on investigating the rift and less on spying on me, they might've made more progress. Yes, they learnt of the existence of the Virus, Anax-Jink, and their reprimand was severe. Keep anything else from us, they said, and you will be stripped of the title of Grand Viceroy and ordered to return to Coroz immediately. They didn't need to say what fate would await me there. I will not be so careless in the future. The Communion wish our efforts to be focused on the rift. The presence of the Virus affords us an opportunity to study it in detail, so that is certainly possible. We already know that some type of rupture in this universe precipitated the emergence of the rift, but we don't know the details. Anax-Jink will help rectify that. Or, I can focus my efforts on cementing my own authority, being ready for unforeseen events . . . the construction of a supremely powerful vessel would be a rational choice to fight off our enemies--without or within. What should I do?
Consolidate

The savages of this universe should witness the majesty and superiority of the Riftborn. A vast vessel befitting of our station will help gain their respect--and give me some useful leverage should the Communion try to relieve me of my post.
Assign $Hero01Name to a Fleet with $Amount01Name [offensiveMilitaryPower] Offensive Power minimum.
To raise a Fleet's OP, create new Ship Designs using new modules. Strategic Resources are often required.

The vessel is complete, a stunning example of our capacity to master this hostile universe through the sheer power of reason and intelligence. The Communion questioned my priorities, but they understand that strict admonishments may not serve them best. They are not the only ones who are watching--my spies in Coroz tell me they are weak and divided. I wish with all my being that our homeworld is freed of the taint, but we may have to face a new reality. One where hard choices will need to be made.
Investigate

Every day we hesitate in our efforts to understand the blight is a day Coroz comes closer to eradication. The Communion might not always know best, but on this matter they are right. Anax-Jink should lead an entire trading system in studying the rift.
Assign $Hero01Name to a System with a Trade Company HQ
Research the "Commercial Frameworks" Technology to unlock the Trade Company HQ System Improvement.

Every day is a struggle, but my faith in the Virus has paid off. Its eccentric yet profound thinking, allied with the logistics provided by the system's trade company, has driven much greater understanding of the cause of the blight. There was a vessel. The Grey Owl. Aboard it carried a Dust artifact of enormous power. Somehow it became unstable, exploded. The rest was inevitable. Worse, Anax-Jink tells me there is no hope of arresting the blight; the plague is a manifestation of the physics of one universe strangling the physics of another. Soon, inevitably, Coroz will be an endless blackened wasteland, devoid of life. My title is Grand Viceroy of New Coroz. If Coroz will be no more, where does my allegiance lie then?
Chapter 3. A Test of Loyalty

The day has finally arrived. The Communion have given the order for a full evacuation of Coroz. I haven't witnessed it firsthand, but the reports show our once beautiful home rendered into a corrupt wasteland, the population corralled into smaller and smaller zones of safety. Those that venture into the blight, I am told, never return. I feel their plight, I truly do, but I am torn. This universe is no sanctuary. It is a hellish realm of vast voids and burning suns, settled by strange creatures each striving to be the dominant species. To survive any Riftborn must cast off their old ideas, harden themselves, be ready for suffering. I fear most will not survive here. Worse, I fear that their presence might doom us all. The arrival of the Communion is another matter. Are they worldly enough for this universe? Or will they lead us into oblivion? During a battle in some far-flung system whose name escapes me, I once saw a Craver get pinned by a falling comms tower. Its arm must've been crushed, useless. Unable to move, it would've shortly been executed by our approaching forces. What did it do? It severed its own arm and kept fighting. Perhaps we must do the same.
Evacuate

Even if this universe will scar them, even if the evacuation will strain us, I cannot leave my people to the mercy of the blight. But that doesn't mean I need surrender power. Coroz will be evacuated, but the Communion will be incarcerated. Systems need to be prepared . . .
Possess $Amount02Name Systems of level $Amount01Name or higher.
Use System development projects (Economy screen) and Luxuries to improve your Systems' levels.

We are a race of refugees. Billions of souls live enshrined in near limitless virtual realms, ready to be embodied in our quasi-robotic forms to become true Riftborn. As to the Communion, they have been made incarnate and shipped away to an impregnable prison where they lack for nothing except their freedom. Only a handful know their fate. They rail against me, but they are impotent. I will show them this is the right way.
Disobey

The blight is a terrible thing, but it is swift in its judgment. This universe, on the other hand, will only prolong their suffering. And it might well cripple our chances of survival. The humane thing to do is lockdown the rift. We will strengthen our forces. None must leave Coroz.
Raise your Empire Manpower capacity to $Amount04Name [manPower].
Obtain new Systems or advance to higher stages in the Military quadrant of the Technology Tree.

The rift is under lockdown. Military forces guard the portal with strict instructions to use any means necessary to stop any more leaving Coroz. We already have enough stored consciousnesses to build our race anew. My fleets obey, but there are murmurs of discontent. I don't know if I'm a savior or a murderer. All I know is that this universe is not our home. Perhaps it never will be.
Cooperate

My allegiance to the Communion must come first. Without unity, without obedience, we are nothing, and not deserving of survival. I will fulfill my duty, no matter the consequences. Coroz will be evacuated, and the Communion respected. We must ensure peace for a smooth transition.
Ensure the Riftborn are not at War for $Amount05Name [turn].
You can be at Cold War, at Peace or in Alliance but not at War with a Major Empire. Any wars with Minor Civilizations will prevent completion too.

Coroz has been evacuated. Billions of consciousnesses are ready for embodiment. One day I hope they will all make the transition, but for now we manifest them as we need them. As to the Communion, they are the true authority in this universe now, but they have asked me to continue in my role and lead the Riftborn. I don't think they were ready for the assault on the senses—and mind—that embodiment entails. I don't think anyone can be. My burden grows. I wonder what will become of us in this forsaken place.
Final Chapter. Who Are We?

The Riftborn living under my leadership wonder of the fate of the Communion, but they are sensible enough not to directly ask. Rumors spread that I left them in Coroz, or eliminated them during their transit to this universe. The rumors are useful tools for control, and I do little to dispel them. Sometimes I wonder if this universe has changed me too much. Sometimes I wonder if this place of constant conflict and bargaining and deceit has altered the very character of the Riftborn. I often wonder if survival is enough. The Communion might be hidden from sight, gone in the minds of my people, but that doesn't mean they don't exert their influence. Every day I grant them an audience, and we enjoy lively discussions about the future. With little to do in their gilded cage except absorb news from across the galaxy, they make a circle of most insightful advisors. With Coroz gone, dead and blackened, they have convinced me that we must begin to take steps to resurrect our cosmos in this universe. Only then will we truly remember who we are. The Communion might be dead to all, but that doesn't mean they won't have a legacy. None will know this, of course. None, except me.
In order to win support for the plan to cast this universe in the image of Coroz, I must raise ecologist thinking across our worlds.
Pass $Amount01Name [ecologistColored] #B0C65D#Ecologists#REVERT# laws.
Increase Ecologist support by constructing Civilian vessels, diversifying Populations, and building [foodColored] or [happinessColored] generating constructions.

Ecologist thinking is strong across the empire, and the desire to see Coroz made anew is growing. The news that our home is a blackened shell, corrupted and uninhabitable, only strengthens feelings. Riftborn researchers make great strides understanding the fundamental nature of matter in the universe, but still struggle to render Corozian artifacts here. One day it will happen though. One day it has to happen. The Communion, forever locked in their impregnable fortress, have come to accept their station. They are the ones I am closest to, the only ones I can speak entirely freely with. Through their collective wisdom, my influence over my citizens has never been greater. Despite the seasons that have passed, I still find this universe an infernal wasteland. But at least it is my infernal wasteland now.
Final Chapter. Backlash - Part 1

Perhaps I should not be surprised. Some have seen my actions as genocide, when the truth is they are a mercy. A vocal but powerful minority stoke the feelings of the masses, encouraging them to move to a full-blown rebellion. They want passage from Coroz re-opened, even if it might cost us everything. These protests are not the Riftborn way. They are another sign that we are losing our identity to this universe. Perhaps that is the only way we will survive though. By forgetting who we were, and embracing this place of chaos and conflict. I don't know. The free exchange of ideas has always been a cornerstone of our way of life, but if I permit these dissenting voices to carry on challenging my authority I fear all might be lost. Compelling evidence has come my way that the ringleaders of this incipient mutiny are meeting for critical talks aboard a secret fleet at the borders of Riftborn space. This might be a perfect time to flatten the rebellion.
Crush
The Riftborn cannot survive if civil war breaks out. The secret fleet must be engaged and destroyed—and its ringleaders captured. One day I want them to understand my actions.
Destroy the ringleaders' marked Fleets.
Build an efficient army, reach the ringleaders' location and destroy them in space battle.

The rebellion is over, its leaders incarcerated. Let them call me betrayer, tyrant, murderer. I am at peace. The stench of this universe seeps deep into my shell, but it is a burden I can carry if it means salvation for my race. I was the Grand Viceroy of New Coroz. Now I am the Communion. Alone.
Appease

We will tear ourselves apart if nothing changes, but that doesn't mean I must act with violence. I will stand true to our values of tolerance and acceptance. I will relent and do as they ask. I will order the blockade of Coroz to stop. Passage through the rift will be re-opened. Before that happens though, I will ensure New Coroz is strong.
Raise [industrialistColored] #DF8269#Industrialists#REVERT# support to $MinimumPercentageName % in $MinimumSystemAmountName Systems.
Increase Industrialist support by colonizing and modernizing Systems, and building [industryColored] generating constructions

Our civilization is now an industrial powerhouse, but it wasn't enough to satisfy the Communion. I have been stripped of the title of Grand Viceroy, and had all privileges revoked. Although I am still in operational control of the Riftborn in New Coroz, I am under guard at all times. How history will judge me, I do not know.
Final Chapter. A Poisoned Chalice

This universe still terrifies. The Communion remain happy to let me lead. I think they are all still shell-shocked by the reality of this universe. They don't want the responsibility of command, and I cannot blame them for that. What they knew--what we all knew--in Coroz is gone. Tranquility, beauty, truth . . . all lost to a cosmos that values conflict above all. Perhaps they let me lead because they see that I have changed. I--among all of us that have called this universe home--understand best what we must do to survive. We must strive. We must fight. We must kill. Every day. Every hour. Every second. We have mastered time, and we will use that strength to master the galaxy. Nothing living has emerged from Coroz for days, but that doesn't stop many calling for us to return. I have cautioned against raising hopes that we might return, but the Communion instruct me to organize an exploratory party. I am sure they will only find blackened ruin--that is, if they return to tell the tale--but perhaps that will be the spur that will harden us, inure us to this harsh cosmos. Once more, we traverse the rift.
Powerful repulsive forces flex across the surface of the rift. Huge quantities of Dust will be needed to overcome them, and that's not even mentioning the cost of the whole enterprise.
Explore the Quest Curiosity on Vanguard when you're ready to sacrifice $Amount01Name [dustColored].
The amassed Dust will be deducted from your Empire Dust reserves when the Curiosity is explored.

The exploration party breached the rift three day-night cycles ago. Seven Riftborn went out. Yesterday three returned. One was mind-dead, the second was delirious, and the third, while coherent, was infected by a virulent strain of the blight. All were kept in separate isolation facilities. The first shows no signs of recovery and will likely be deactivated soon. The second killed itself, executing a proliferation script in its core which we were unable to counteract in time. The prognosis for the third looked bleak, but somehow it survived the night. Still focused on its mission, it ignored its own suffering and damage, and relayed to us as much as it could about the party's expedition and the state of Coroz. The short version is that not only is our old home uninhabitable, it is also evolving in dangerous and unpredictable ways. Alive some might say. Return is impossible. We are stranded in this universe. Not without hope though. Not only did the sole survivor bring back much valuable analysis. In its infected state it also brought back secrets of Dust. And with more Dust we might yet win this galaxy.
Explore the Quest Curiosity on $OnePlanetName when you're ready to sacrifice $Amount01Name [dustColored].
Final Chapter. Backlash - Part 2

Any lingering dissent is long gone. My inner circle fear me, and they transmit this feeling onto their own subordinates. We are a colder race now, but we are also stronger for it. Our survival in this universe depends on it. The ringleaders of the rebellion remain in an incarceration singularity, their physical forms held aloft in stasis for all to see like flies trapped in amber, while their minds roam time and space. Their example helps keep my grip iron. A strange thing happened with one of the prisoners. Seventeen day-night cycles ago, 534628634's vital parameters spiked. The Custodians brought it out of the singularity, and quickly sent word that I must come. Once stabilized, 534628634 claimed to have a detailed vision of the future. That two cycles hence, a phalanx of Riftborn from Coroz would try to breach the rift, escape into the Endless galaxy. Intense hallucinations are not uncommon when under a singularity, but the visions are always mangled fragments of imagination and reality, giving more insight into the dreamer's mind than any objective reality. Everything 534628634 described came to pass. And thanks to its words we were ready. Since then every one of its premonitions has come true. For its candor, I give it certain comforts the other prisoners are denied. We have an understanding. How long it can endure though, before descending into madness I do not know, but until then I will heed its words. Now it tells me the Riftborn must spread among the stars to stave off calamity. And so that's what I will do.
To counter unseen threats, both internal and external, the oracle, 534628634 counsels the capture of more systems.
Control $Amount02Name Systems.
Systems are considered controlled when at least one Colony exists in the System

The Riftborn straddle more stars than ever. 534628634 is gone though, the strain of the visions on its mind finally becoming too great to bear. It is a loss, but 534628634's sacrifice taught me something important. Every Riftborn can give more. Of course, finding another oracle of 534628634's caliber will be difficult, perhaps impossible, but that doesn't mean more cannot be extracted out of every Riftborn who sheaths themselves in a robotic shell. I will work them harder. And they will not complain because they will understand they are securing their race's survival. No cost is too great for that aim. I will make sure they understand that. And if any forget that lesson I will bring them to the singularity where the other flies are still trapped in the amber, and offer them the chance of becoming my new oracle.
Final Chapter. Backlash - Part 2

I may have relented and allowed the exodus from Coroz to resume, but the Communion was not in a forgiving mood. Even with the industrial power of our rogue civilization never greater, I have been ordered to stand judgment in a covert trial. The Communion will decide my fate. In the meantime, I will continue making all operational decisions from the austere comfort of the Breach Provisional Authority's main base, upon condition I am not to leave the structure. I am under guard at all times. For the sake of our race's survival I will obey. The Communion have given me the strategic aim of promoting a doctrine of peace. They are new to this universe and haven't yet developed the passion for violence that seems to be endemic to survival here. Perhaps it gives us a chance to start again. Or perhaps it heralds our demise. In any case, I will respect their wishes--at least outwardly. To this end, I will concentrate Riftborn exploitation ventures on securing the strategic resources necessary to defend ourselves. Singularities will help us to arrange the pieces of the galaxy as we see fit, while stronger fleets will allow us to patrol safely. Specialists will be sent to the strategic mining sites tasked with one objective: maximizing yields. I don't know what the Communion's judgment will be. I don't know what fate awaits me. But I will play along. The Endless universe has taught me that much.
I must demonstrate my obedience now. Controlling the flow of strategic resources will be vital for empowering ourselves, and carrying out the Communion's pacifist aims.
Colonize $Amount02Name planets with [Strat03adamantianColored] Adamantium deposits and $Amount04Name planets with [Strat04anti-matterColored] Anti-Matter deposits.
Deposits can be hidden by Curiosities which might be undetectable until you research the required Technology.

The focus on strategic materials has paid dividends. With enough sites under our control, we were able to run many experimental studies aimed at boosting production, and we made stunning progress. Even more than I led my Communion judges to believe, in fact. Despite my careful stewardship though, the Communion, in their infinite wisdom, have decided to tarnish me with the title of Outsider for my previous sins. If we were in Coroz I would be banished to travel the Nothing, the great expanse devoid of all meaning, but here I wear the name of Outsider like a badge of honor. Here, I became something other than Riftborn, and by doing so I gave my race a chance of survival. The Communion understand this fact, and in recognition they have given me their consent to remain as leader. They give me the name Outsider, so that none forget. They are wise, but I will never let myself be at the mercy of their judgment again. The extra riches I squirrel away every cycle will see to that. Soon I won't need their consent. Soon I will be in complete command. And this time I will not waver.
Heartfire
Chapter 1. Fire and Light - Part 1

We awoke, ages ago. The first of us came to life fully conscious, as if from one day to the next the dawn changed us. We did not worry ourselves with this, however; for ages, we simply grew and thought, listening to the Heart and learning about our world, Koyasil. We sunk our roots deep into the soil to see what lay beneath, we gazed at the stars and tracked their passage across the sky. Why seek anything else? What more is required of life? Then these Others came, bringing their conflicts and their violence, driving us into self-doubt and confusion. To ask, "Where did they come from?", is a brief step away from asking, "And where did we come from?" We hear the murmurs of the Heart, and it soothes us. It speaks to us of serenity and strength. But the old reassurances are no longer enough; they fade with the old vision of the universe. It seems we are one small clod of dirt in an unthinkably vast galaxy, and now we must raise up our limbs, shake out our roots, and look beyond Koyasil. Some say we do not need to look outward; we have Koyasil and the Heart, and they will protect and guide us. Some say that the new knowledge is critical to our future, that the violence and aggressive science of the Others must be controlled. I do not back either side in this debate; I would not see us limited to Koyasil, nor would I see us enslaving the Others.
Know
Some Unfallen insist that we must grasp the new sciences, the new ways, to understand ourselves. Thirds become ships, and ships explore.
Possess $Amount01Name Anomalies in your Empire.
Anomalies can be found by studying Curiosities.

We begin to understand the shape of the galaxy. The mysteries of the stars are like winter branches; dark traceries against a gray sky. We absorb the knowledge of the anomalies and study their strange nature. We will consider, and grow, and perhaps even change.
Random [technology] Technology
Grow
The Unfallen can reach across star systems, linking them together by the will of the Heart. Some Unfallen insist that only these old ways can guide our new future.
Possess $Amount02Name new Star Systems.
Send a Rootship to an uncolonized System and use the "Implant Beacon" Fleet Action. Tendrils can only be used to colonize adjacent Systems.

The tendrils grow like new limbs, like the antennae of insects. As they extend they also feel, and sense, and listen. They live. We learn much from them, even if much of it is confusion. But we are patient; all answers come in time.
Chapter 1. Fire and Light - Part 2

When the Unfallen awoke, and began to study our world, we learned many things quickly. The greatest lesson we learned, however, was Fire. As siblings of the trees, we have an intimate understanding of Fire. It was initially treated as a dangerous if desirable force; necessary to burst the seeds open but jealous and hungry if ignored or taken for granted. As our wisdom grew we saw that it was merely excited electrons and some now belittle Fire, calling it a tool that we should exploit. They say that Fire and its descendants--fossil fuels, fission, fusion--are, like Fire, dangerous but useful. But some look to the sun and the wind for power, seeking to use natural forms of energy rather than those that rely upon destruction. This is an old debate, and one that will not finish in my lifetime. But the basic philosophies of the Unfallen are simple: Everything begins, and ends, with Fire. As we extend into the galaxy many questions will arise, and some will find answers. But this fundamental question remains: Are we Light, or are we Fire?
Light
For those who are uneasy with Fire, there are other ways to extend the power of the Unfallen, and to maintain our security against the violence of the Others.
Reach a stock of $Amount01Name [prestigeColored] Influence in your Empire.
Some Influence is produced by the population. It can be increased through Planetary Improvements, System Improvements, Hero Skills, etc.
Our tales and discoveries are things of wonder. How grand, how stunning this galaxy is! How fortunate we are to live and breathe within its bounteous limits! And, yet, how very dangerous it is…
Fire

For many, Fire is the way to open the door that is the future. Energy must be consumed to create power, as it is by all living things. For some, the use of Fire and ships is as organic as driving down roots.
Use the fleets of the Unfallen to destroy the Pirates.
Build new ships or use your existing ones to destroy all the ships of the marked Pirate fleets.

If we have learned little else, we have at least learned that the galaxy is a strange and marvelous place. Some see the future as a series of threats to be contained; others, as storms to be weathered. We will see which side has the truth of the matter.
Chapter 2. The Trees of Lives

Mafaza, an aging Second who would doubtless be dormant by now had the others not arrived, has come forward as the champion of tradition. Once a Firekeeper, she is now a steady voice for calm and introspection. Her greatest foil is Atelata, who has raised his limbs under distant suns and met many other peoples. One argues for continuity and the other for adaptation; one preaches adhering to custom and the other insists on radical evolution of government and society. The Heart speaks to us, as she always has. Our conscience and our guide, she is a voice within all Unfallen that is both god and counselor. As we share what we have learned of our cosmos the words of the Heart are clear: Our role is to understand the Other and speak with the Other. The passion of the Heart is clear in this, for we have felt tremors in her that have never before been sensed--even in the memories of the oldest of the Thirds. We must study other species as we have studied ourselves, for the Heart will not accept anger and conflict when dialogue and harmony are possible. The Heart accepts the need for Fire, but only for the Fire that renews. The Fire that destroys has no place among the Unfallen. Yet some speak of our new knowledge as something like the Fire that destroys, for if we must adapt and grow and change, the oldest among us will be lost and left behind. What is the value of a Third, who has lived centuries in an unchanging world, and whose store of life wisdom becomes less and less valuable? These questions drive to the foundations of our civilization, and even the reassuring pulse of the Heart does not soothe us.
Integrate
Bring other species within our boundaries, that we may study them and learn to live in harmony.
Increase the number of non-Unfallen [population] Populations in your empire to $Amount01Name.
Assimilate Minor Civilizations to add new population types to your Empire. Some Curiosities may give new Populations too. Spend Luxury Deposits to make them grow instead of Unfallen

The stories of other species fascinate us; they have their own tree of life and history, as we have ours. They speak often of the Endless, but they do not see what lies behind the tales of the Endless and Dust. Long before the Endless, other powerful entities existed—creatures of Dust and light who have since disappeared.
Understand
Prepare to travel and explore more widely, that we may meet with Others and be seen as friends.
Grow enough Systems to Level $Amount02Name or more so there are $Amount03Name Spaceports in the empire.
Unlock Stage 3 of the "Economy and Trade" Quadrant to gain access to System Development projects.

The stories of other species fascinate us; they have their own trees of life and history, as we have ours. Most importantly, we have seen what other, less contemplative peoples have missed: Long before the Endless, there existed other entities who thrived in this galaxy. One day they, too, must be studied and understood.

Unlock Stage 3 of the "Economy and Trade" Quadrant to gain access to System Development projects. Then, design your upgrade with Luxury Resources in the Economic Screen and build it on your Motherships
Improve $Amount03Name systems to level $Amount02Name.
Chapter 3. The Flood - Part 1

Technology, civilizations, history... We are unused to seeing and learning so much, to absorbing this quantity of information. Or "data", as some now call it. Events, discoveries, and artifacts fall upon us like torrential rain; it is all we can do to not be swept away. The Heart beats more strongly now, as though driven by our concern. New knowledge is absorbed as quickly as it can be, and when it is too great or too complex it drains like water into our subconscious and is captured there by the Heart, biding its time to resurface and be integrated and understood at a pace more natural to the rhythms of the Unfallen. Maintaining our reason and equilibrium becomes more and more difficult, but the Unfallen are nothing if not hardy and resolute. Still, the new knowledge brings a challenge we had not considered, one that digs at the corners of our society. Do we grow, change, and evolve, or do we fall back upon the ways we know and ride out the turmoil? Is the chaos of the galaxy simply a new analogy for Fire, and if so, is it the Fire that renews, or the Fire that destroys? It would be good if we could discover these answers before this Fire becomes too powerful for our control. It does not escape us that the analogies we use are Flood and Fire—agents of cataclysm.
Revolution
Curiosity burns, but it is a renewing Fire. Study and investigate the new ways, for if we do not the next Fire that burns the galaxy will not be one that renews.
Produce $Amount01Name [scienceColored] in your Empire.
Some Science is produced by the population. It can be increased through Planetary Improvements, System Improvements, Hero Skills, etc.

We have some answers. However, as seems to be the case in these days, they only lead to more questions. We feel the Heart beating more strongly, gaining force to guide us. Or so we hope. It is only in silence and isolation that we consider the other possibility; that the more fervent beating of the Heart is a sign of its weakness...
Tradition

Knowledge must be the Fire that renews, and the answers must be found within our people. If we flourish and remain strong, we will have the time and strength even for the most difficult of the new knowledge.
Maintain [happinessColored] at $Amount02Name or better in your Empire for $Amount03Name [turn].
Approval can be increased by certain System Improvements, Hero skills, and Luxury Resources.

The Unfallen thrive, and as we grow we absorb and learn. We feel the Heart beating more strongly, gaining force to guide us. Or so we hope. It is only in silence and isolation that we consider the other possibility; that the more fervent beating of the Heart is a sign of its weakness...
Chapter 3. The Flood - Part 2

The deluge of change does not abate. The Unfallen move like a forest in the wind, sometimes leaning in one direction and sometimes the other. In the noise and the confusion, I think that the Heart is beating louder in order to get their attention. When I try to listen to the Heart, to understand it as the Thirds do, I think that Mafaza and Atelata may both be correct. We must sway other peoples to see things the way we see them, and perhaps reach out to them, and change ourselves in doing it. I have no true conviction, other than that when this is over, the Unfallen will not be who we once were.
Convince
Show other peoples the calm strength of the Unfallen.
Reach $Amount04Name Positive Diplomatic Pressure with another Empire.
Increase this pressure by increasing your Influence with Improvements, Hero Skills, Luxury Resources, etc.

It seems we have come full circle. As the Unfallen better understand others, our questions are increasingly directed to ourselves. The next step seems strange, but inevitable. I will use the new sciences to investigate our oldest phenomenon: The Heart.
Control
Prepare to impose the pacifist unity of the Unfallen on those who would rather fight than listen.
Reach $Amount02Name [manPowerColored] Manpower in your empire.
Manpower can be increased by building certain System Improvements and using certain Luxury Resources.

Those who watch us grow comment on our newfound strength. They also question what we do, and why. To answer this, the Unfallen must look at the deepest elements of our own history, and question the things that we never before thought to question.
Final Chapter. Head and Heart

It may be blasphemy, or madness, but I desire to know the nature and the power of the Heart, and what she is trying to say. I believe that we need to study the past, but with the new tools of the present. Mafaza claims that the Heart is a living spirit, older than the Endless, that has watched over the Unfallen since the birth of our world. Atelata, on the other hand, refers to the Heart as an artificial proto-consciousness trapped within the mechanical interior of the planet – an interior whose existence has only recently been affirmed by Sophon scientists. And I? I would that the Heart were a repository of knowledge, a god, and a reliable ally in troubling times. But the crutch of religion has been removed from me, and I now believe that the Heart is anything but mystical. Still it is also not imaginary. It is there, it throbs, it whispers. But we do not know if it is an aspect of the collective consciousness of the Unfallen, or an some entity external to our people. But we are all agreed; until we have this answer, we cannot know who we are, and what our destiny is. Is the Heart spirit or technology? Are we Light, or are we Fire?
Fire
We will push the new sciences to their utmost, and use their secrets to unlock the truth of the Heart.
Reach the fourth Stage in one of the quadrants of the Technology tree.
Three technologies of the third Stage in a quadrant must be researched to unlock the fourth Stage

Hypothesize, test, and theorize. We have uncovered the truth: The Heart is a wounded survivor of the Lost, a damaged spirit who has lain hidden within Koyasil for ages. It has rested quietly, building and strengthening the Unfallen, giving us sentience and power. And though we are forever in her debt, we do not yet know her purpose. We see now, however, that we are both ancient and young, born of both nature and technology. We do not choose between Fire and Light. We are the Unfallen. We are both.
Light
To see if the Heart is within the Unfallen or an outside entity, we will terraform and colonize a hostile planet, then listen for her voice.
Terraform $LavaPlanetName into a Jungle or a Monsoon planet.
Terraforming technologies are found in Stages 3 and 4 of the "Science and Exploration" Quadrant of the Technology Tree.

On a once-lifeless planet, the Heart does not speak. It is indeed tied to Koyasil, living within the core of the planet from a time before the Endless. The Heart has spent ages cultivating and uplifting the Unfallen. Our affection and respect are now tempered with some caution, for even though we know what, we do not know why. We see now, however, that we are both ancient and young, born of both nature and technology. We do not choose between Fire and Light. We are the Unfallen. We are both.
Your Bag, Please

Your System, $SystemName, has been selected as the host venue for a major diplomatic summit. In the coming months, all eyes will be on you: Watchdog groups across the galaxy will be monitoring $SystemName's infrastructure, stability, and security in preparation for the summit.
Make sure the event goes off without a hitch, and you may find surprising new opportunities open up for your empire.
Protect your system from intrusion while the diplomatic summit is held.
The event went off perfectly. There were the usual small scuffles that accompany cross-species diplomatic debate, of course, but overall you find yourself breathing a sigh of relief.
The summit was a disaster. Sightings of hostile ships in the galactic neighborhood caused a diplomatic panic in $SystemName and ended the summit ten days early.
You can use the Fleet Actions "Guard" or "Intercept" or use a Diplomatic Action to close your borders. Visits from Allies and friendly factions are allowed.
For 10 [turn], keep your $SystemName system clear of enemy ships.
Those Darn Kids

One of the problems with having Sophons in your empire is that the little eggheads seem to have a particular genius for goofing off. Hardly a week goes by without news of neuro-hopped Sophon youngsters rampaging through town, or explosions of increasingly exotic colors and smells bombarding your residential areas.
Either these guys need to get a job, or you need to find a way to put them in their place.
Generate more jobs in the sciences.
Science Up!
The quest will fail if a System in your empire completes construction on a ship or non-Scientific Improvement in the next 10 turns.
For the next 10 [turn], build only Science-focused Star System Improvements or Wonders.
What happened?! Some Sophon kids caught wind of the non-science construction programs, and decided they had a better future elsewhere. Naturally, it started a movement . . .
You've managed to put that Sophon gray matter to great use. Now that those Sophon kids are mired in student debt and slogging through their doctorates, life is a lot better for everyone. Sort of.
Step up police efforts.
Garrison
The quest will fail if one your Systems' hangars contains fewer than 2 military ships at the end of the 10th turn.
Within 10 turns, garrison at least 2 military ships in each of $SystemName01 and $SystemName02's Hangars.
The streets are in disarray! Roving bands of Sophon youths get up to all manner of hijinks from hacking centralized timekeeping servers to spiking domestic fuel. Where were the riot police?

Your managed to quell the more unruly elements of your Sophon population. All over your empire, streets are quieter, buildings are cleaner, and lawns are strictly kept off of. When did you become one of those people?
10/10 With Spice

As the Lumerian population of your empire increases, so does the demand for goods from Jenes, the Lumerian home planet. Lumerian trading companies all over your empire are scrabbling to get their hands on stock of a certain type of seaweed-derived spice, the price of which has skyrocketed.
Rumors of an illegal Lumerian black market cartel are already circulating. Lumerians are notoriously hard to regulate once their crime organizations get rolling, so you would do best to cut off this chain of events before it gets out of hand.
Colonize
Colonize additional water planets (Ocean, Toxic and Atoll) before they come under the control of the Lumeris Families--and their "entrepreneurs".
Acceptable water planets are of Ocean, Toxic and Atoll planet types
Possess 2 new watery planets to improve the supply chain.
What happened?! The black market has cornered the seaweek-derived spice. This is going to be one unregulated market. Buckle up!

The prices of Lumerian goods all over your empire have normalized, and the influence of the black market is dwindling. Anyone can rule with an iron fist, you ruminate, but at times it is better to rule with an invisible hand.
And Out Of The Smoke . . .

Managing a population of Cravers is no easy feat. Craver Bishops, the mentally advanced leaders of Craver society, orchestrate their hivemates through feeding, hatching, and the rearing of young. Careful balance must always be kept so that the swarm does not grow out of control.
Around this time every year, adolescent Cravers go through a mutation, determining their future roles in Craver society. One of your Craver Bishops has just presented you with a host of newly mutated soldier-class drones. Perhaps you could put the eager youngsters to use somewhere.
New Ship Design
New Craver recruits are eager for action--build attack ships to make sure these idle hands have something to do.
The role of the ship's Hull should be "Attacker".
Construct 2 "Attacker" ships in the $CraverSystem System with at least $FakeMinimumAttackName [offensiveMilitaryPower] Offensive Military Power.

The young Cravers' eyes shine a little brighter when you introduce them to their new craft, and you suppose it might be interpreted as gratitude. But it is always difficult to know what a Craver is really thinking.
Bug Fixing

One of the Bishops overseeing the Craver swarm on $SystemName has just passed away. A frequent enough occurrence, except for one thing: she was the last one. Bishops are critical to keeping a Craver population under control--you must quickly grow your Craver population to induce the mutation of a new Bishop.
Population
Cravers run leaderless in one of your systems--grow their population until a new Bishop leader appears.
Produce more Food to increase Growth. Note that customized Craver factions may not be able to complete this objective.
Within $Timer [turn], increase your Craver population in $SystemName by 2.
The system runs amok, no Bishop to channel the Cravers urges!
Thanks to your efforts, a Craver adolescent in $SystemName has spontaneously morphed into a female, setting it on the developmental road to becoming a Bishop. Life, you suppose, finds a way.
Lifting The Lamp

Opening your empire's doors to new population types has its challenges, but also its rewards. Each new group adds to the strength and flexibility of a society, contributing to the maturity of your empire as a whole.
New Population
Nurture a new population type within your empire, and reap the benefits.
This population could come from a Minor or a Major Faction.
Capture, assimilate, or attract a new [population] population type into your empire.
Chalk one up for the bigots. No new xenos welcome here apparently!
A small immigrant community is forming. Your heart swells, seeing them go about their daily business. Your empire is growing, in more ways than one.
An Excess of Devotion

The Vodyani citizens of your empire have celebrations of their Virtual Saints, and at certain times expect alms and donations to support their faith. Given the quality and expense of the Cloth they wear and the rigidity of their religion, these donations are not simple--or cheap. They are requesting you tithe holy Dust to their cause, and the "request" has been delivered in somewhat blunt language.
Gather the Dust you need, then visit the Curiosity
Gather $Amount01Name [dustColored] amount and search the Curiosity on the planet $MyPlanetName to make your donation.
The quest will fail if the planet is destroyed or there are no longer Vodyani citizens in your empire.

You are too busy to attend the rituals, but the intensity of their devotion and the sacrifices they make are quite impressive. You are much happier to have the support of this grim people than their ire.
There is no longer any Vodyani population in your empire
Lord of War

Black markets have always existed in dense urban centers within the empire. As long as they're monitored and kept under control, they have their uses. Criminal elements can be kept busy, hidden taxes can be skimmed, and interesting contraband can be smuggled into the nation for the leadership's pleasure. However, black markets for illegal firearms is another matter. Especially when it enables enemy civilizations to get their hands, tentacles, or other appendages, on some of the empire's most effective weaponry. The unfortunate truth is that some of your undercover security forces have unearthed compelling evidence that a gun smuggling ring is operating out of three of your systems. The leader is suspected to be the nephew of Duke Groltz, a bad apple with a history of criminal activity. What should you do?
Shutdown Ring
A healthy black economy is one thing, but arming your sworn enemies in the process is unacceptable. Besides Duke Groltz's nephew shouldn’t be free to acquire so much Dust.
Assign a Hero of at least level $Amount01Name on the $StarSystem01Name, $StarSystem02Name and $StarSystem03Name Systems.

Obtain Heroes through the Marketplace or the Academy. Raise a Hero to the required level by assigning them to a Fleet or System first. Quest is failed if United Empire Population falls to zero, or one of the Systems are lost.

The illegal gun dens are no more. Your Hero saw to that, personally. Duke Groltz is frustrated that his nephew has been hung out to dry, but public opinion means he cannot air those grievances. Even better, the clampdown led to a sizeable haul of Dust that'll be good for the imperial coffers.
Let Them Stay

You'll pay Duke Groltz a visit, make sure he understands the stakes, but this little venture could help you sow unrest in your enemies' ranks. You just need to make sure the local populations remain content.
Reach $Amount02Name [happinessColored] on the $StarSystem01Name, $StarSystem02Name and $StarSystem03Name Systems.
Construct [happinessColored] promoting buildings, avoid overcrowding, and make political decisions that satisfy your populations' natural political leanings to raise Approval.

The local populations were beginning to mobilize against the illegal gun shops in their midst when you discovered them, but since your fake "crackdowns" the protests have died away. Now with the gun smuggling operations truly underground, it's time to flog inferior arms and make some quick Dust.
Oh dear. The black market business is alive and well--but you're not seeing any benefits. Chalk this up as a learning experience.
The Ugly Plague

You have Horatio population in your empire, and they come with a certain preconception as to what beauty is. In fact, they are throwing down their pens and makeup kits in frustration at having to live alongside all these other, uglier species. Whether it is a refusal to work or simply a moment of pique, they are insisting that you remove all other species from planets that have Horatio population. Though it is unlikely that they will riot in the streets (they are not generally that rowdy), they are perfectly capable of staying at home and crippling your production. The unhappy Horatio are mainly located on the $StarSystem01Name and $StarSystem02Name systems.
Resettle
In hopes of avoiding unrest and improving your public image, you agree to let the Horatio population have their own planets.
Have $Amount02Name Systems with only Horatio [population] Population.
Population can be moved physically using the Spaceport for all Level 2 Systems.

You didn't get quite the production boost you hoped for, as the Horatio are now spending more time than they should trying to determine which one is the most gorgeous. They are happier, however, and more willing to work.
Refuse
You are running an empire, not a kindergarten. Horatio have to work like everybody else. Improve the tools of production, and they'll get back to it.
Reach $Amount04Name [industryColored] on $StarSystem01Name and $StarSystem02Name in less than $TurnAmountName [turn].
Hero Skills, Improvements, and Luxury Resources can all be used to improve Industry production.

It ended up being a compromise, as the Horatio were allowed to design their new offices and plants. While there is a bit more green and gold than you might like, the unrest is over and they are back at work.
Riftborn Blues - Part 1

The Endless universe is taking its toll on the valiant Riftborn who have travelled through the rift and embodied their spiritual essences in strange robotic shells. They thirst for a taste of Coroz, and long for a reprieve from the organic horrors of this universe. Their minds desire the ordered lines and perfect symmetry of the home dimension. Sadly, the blight still spreads through Coroz. Any return, no matter how short is too risky and not an option. The Communion have forbidden it, ordering that all those who have crossed must stay in this galaxy and give everything to their race's survival. But there is an answer--or at least, a partial one. You may not be able to return to Coroz, but that doesn't mean you can't bring Coroz to here. First you need to find a suitable system where the Riftborn can begin to relax . . .
Only a system harboring the most barren and meager planets will suffice as a place of rest for the Riftborn. You don't want to stumble across any loathsome organic matter, after all.
Possess $Amount02Name [temperatureCold] Cold planets.
In Galaxy View, when zoomed-in on a System, mouse over each planet and check if the cold icon is listed. You can colonize, invade or terraform.
Mission accomplished. With one of the most lifeless systems in the whole galaxy under your control, you can begin to send stressed Riftborn to this island of tranquility for recuperation.
Riftborn Blues - Part 2

Well, it was never going to be paradise, but $MyColonizedStarSystemLocalizationName is still not even adequate for Riftborn recuperation. Sunrises and sunsets, algae and microbes, wind and rain--even in the most barren places of this universe the Riftborn can't get away from its tortures. For $MyColonizedStarSystemLocalizationName to become a true sanctuary for this galaxy's most far reaching visitors, much more work needs to be done. The environment needs to be completely transformed into a real echo of their home dimension, Coroz. Only then might they gain respite.
The secret ingredients for $MyColonizedStarSystemLocalizationName's transformation are Luxuries. The substance is critical for numbing the senses and tricking the mind.
Increase the System level of $MyColonizedStarSystemLocalizationName.
System Development is enabled by unlocking the higher stages of the Economy and Trade quadrant of the Tech Tree. Luxuries can be obtained via the Marketplace.

Finally, $MyColonizedStarSystemLocalizationName is a place the Riftborn can see as a home from home! Perhaps the Endless universe will now begin to see Riftborn mathematics, culture, and outlook truly flourish.
Dust To Dust - Part 1

In the midst of a small asteroid belt, your scouts have discovered a unique crystalline building, a fractal-like lattice whose sheer intricacy boggles the mind. As your probe stops to gather a tiny sample, a massive chunk crumbles off, rotating slowly in place. The sample has some very strange properties. It appears to have some sort of weak directional resonance, like a needle in an undetectable magnetic field. Your scientists have never seen anything like it. Your fleet has its orders, of course. But you wonder if diverting your mission to seek out the source of this strange crystal-affecting field could prove profitable.
With your scientist baffled, this is too good a chance to learn something potentially revolutionary. Even if it's out of the way, orbiting the asteroid field is the smart choice.
Send a fleet to the Quest Marker.
Even a fleet composed of a single ship will be adequate.
This Quest has failed

Using your crystal sample as a guide, you've led your fleet to a large, barren planet, apparently rich in minerals. But your scanners pick up no signs of life. Your team sets up a temporary camp on the surface, taking the opportunity to gather some potentially useful resources while a smaller group makes an exploratory sweep.
Dust To Dust - Part 2

After performing a brief survey, one of your geologists has come to you with astonishing news. This planet is littered with thousands of small pockets of Dust--not Dust in its natural form, but Dust scattered in clumps and jagged patterns in the crystalline bedrock: almost as if the planet had once been violently struck by thousands of Dust-bonded meteorites. A simple piezoelectric test confirms your geologist's suspicions. She advises that it will take months of further study before the Dust can be extracted in any usable form. You do not mention it to her, but the planet gives you a strange feeling--you feel as if you are treading over a long-forgotten graveyard. But a spare cache of Dust could be useful . . .
The dead are dead, and even if this might be a somewhat disrespectful act, your empire needs the Dust.
Send an Expedition to the indicated Curiosity on $PlanetName. Dust deposits of this magnitude may have already attracted salvage gangs, so it might be best to go ready for a fight.
Use the Fleet Action "Start Expedition" with a fleet in orbit around $PlanetName. If someone colonizes the System, the quest will fail.
This Quest has failed

Your expedition has managed to extract a fair amount of Dust from the landscape, along with a large number of lumpy crystalline geodes. But despite your early misgivings, you are no closer to answering the planet's mysteries than before.
Dust To Dust - Part 3

As your ships ascend, kicking clouds of dirt up from the planet's surface, a small warning lamp illuminates the communications station in your capital ship. Before you know it, you are receiving panicked transmissions from the rest of your fleet. You are under attack . . . from . . . rocks?!? An explosion makes your ship lurch, snapping you out of your confusion. There is no time for contemplation. The battle is in full swing.
The expedition to the planet's surface has awoken something--something angry. Even if it's only rocks, you're going to need to keep your wits about you. Prepare for battle!
Destroy those pirates!
Analyze the enemy fleet before the battle begins, and select an appropriate strategy. They must have a weakness!
This Quest has failed

The dust settles and your ships limp, smoking, out of the atmosphere. During the battle, you caught a glimpse of one of the attacking ships: a ship made of bright blue crystal, hidden beneath a layer of rock. Your thoughts flit to the first thing that comes to mind: an ancient race called the Harmony, who were supposedly wiped out centuries ago by a plague created by the Endless. But your historical knowledge is lacking. You make a mental note to read up more when you have the time. On your ship's bridge, your geologist and you share a look of relief. The majority of your crew has survived the day -- perhaps, for the moment, that is the most important thing.
The Good Life

While exploring this planet, you come across a small, harmless community of Horatio. Apparently the survivors of a crash-landed spacecraft, these people have lived on the planet for over a decade, enjoying the tropical climate and adorning their habitations with rocks, shells, and other useless objects. They seem quite surprised when you tell them their little conclave is just one or two years away from being wiped out by a natural cataclysm. Help them find a new place to live, won't you?
Given the imminent cataclysm, the need to relocate the Horatio enclave is clear. Fortunately, the "beautiful" ones should bring some useful benefits too.
Bring the Horatio vessel to one of your Systems with at least $Amount02Name available population slots.
The Horatio ship must survive.

The Horatio seem pleased with their new homes. As you watch them wander around, hanging up artwork and woven decorations brought from their previous homes, you ruminate that there is more than one route to finding satisfaction in life.
Add 3 [population] Horatio
A New Hoce
Pirates

A group of archaeologists from your exploration party has come to you with a bizarre report: they claim to have seen a ghostly airship, made of balloons and solar panels, silently traversing the planet's skies. You are initially skeptical, but one of your historians insists that the airship matches the mythical description of Hoce, an ancient Endless who watched from the skies as her home planet, Kyros, was converted to a gray goo by a nanoplague. Hoce is long dead with the rest of the Endless, and this planet could not possibly be Kyros. But the story seems to have captured the imaginations of your crew, who are now speaking of founding a colony here.
Create an Outpost on the planet $PlanetName or colonize its System.
The myth of Hoce is strong among the crew. They believe a new colony of $PlanetName would be an auspicious event for the empire.
Use a Colony Ship to settle an Outpost.

New Hoce, they call it, though none of the new colony's inhabitants have ever reported another sighting of the ghostly ship. It is said that Hoce perished aboard her lost airship, mourning the death of her mate and waiting for the gods to come and transform Kyros back into the paradise it once was. Perhaps, so many years after Hoce and the fall of the Endless, the gods have finally come.
This Quest has failed
The Ripple Effect

A preliminary exploration of this ocean planet reveals only one thing: a screaming band of Hissho fighters, who fire off an opening salvo of rockets before even attempting communication. Your repeated warning broadcasts do nothing to slow their advance. Your ships are entering defensive formation even as you give the command. Fight for your life!
The Hissho have no interest in a dialogue. They're going to need to be eliminated.
Destroy the Hissho in battle at $QuestPOI.
At the end of the battle, the enemy fleet must be destroyed, not defeated.

Your surviving ships circle the floating wreckage of smoking Hissho vessels. Superior firepower has won you the day, but as the oceans recede from your view, you can't help but ponder what kind of barbaric culture these wild warriors hail from. And what were they doing on this planet all alone?
This Quest has failed

On the lonely, wave-swept surface of this planet, you've found the home of the mysterious Cartographer, a wizened old Sophon whose passion is for making incredibly detailed maps of the galaxy. She claims to have located the mythical planet Sykagoja, a ruinous place where the Endless once built massive arenas for all manner of dangerous aliens to do battle. She agrees to exchange this information for a few luxury goods from your empire.
You've heard that Sykagoja is a place of many secrets and storied legends. Getting some luxury goods together shouldn't be a problem...
Exploit Deposits, search Curiosities or trade on the Marketplace to obtain new Strategic Resources.
The Cartographer gratefully accepts your contribution, and reveals Sykagoja on your map. Good luck.

Search the curiosity on the planet $QuestPlanetName when you're ready to give up $Amount03Name [Strat01titaniumColored] Titanium $Amount03Name [Strat02hyperiumColored] Hyperium $Amount04Name [Strat03adamantianColored] Adamantian and $Amount04Name [Strat04anti-matterColored] Anti-Matter.
Sykagoja Location

Your scientists have detected a heavily-damaged ship of unknown design entering your home system. The ship is unresponsive to hails, and sensors have detected that the engines are in critical overload and it will soon self-destruct! Scanning the ship, you discover that it contains not only a dense computer core containing untold secrets, but also passengers in stasis who have been infected by an unknown plague. You can only save the core or the passengers before the ship explodes...
Save the Core
You will need to increase your Industry and Science to create the special tools and machines to extract the core.
In the System $HomeSystemLocationName produce at least $Amount01Name [industryColored] and $Amount01Name [scienceColored]

Whatever information the core--and its dead crew--once had is now in your hands. It will take some time for your scientists to analyze and understand the data.
Save the Inhabitants
The pursuit of science and knowledge is important, but sentient beings come first. You will need to increase Industry and Food to be able to extract, house, and feed the aliens.
In the System $HomeSystemLocationName produce at least $Amount01Name [industryColored] and $Amount01Name [foodColored]
You can increase production of a resource by building appropriate System Improvements and Planetary Improvements, setting Hero skills, etc.

You are content to have taken the morally correct action, and the aliens are even more content to be alive. They are eager to share what they know about their world, and the strange situation in which you found them.
Civilian Faction
The Living Plague - Part 2

After analyzing the core, you learn that the aliens' homeworld was attacked by a malevolent race of extraterrestrials who conquer planets, quickly strip them of their resources, and then move on. In addition, the core gives you algorithms to predict their next target. They move fast, though, and won't stay at the site of their last victory for long. If you hurry, you can intercept them before they leave... or you can head to their next destination and lay a trap for them.
Set a Trap
They are dangerous, and a carefully planned trap may be a wiser move than dashing in and attacking them.
Orbit around $FirstSystemName until enemy fleet appears ( $Amount01Name [turn] )
Patience is a virtue.
Your fleet is ready, maintaining radio silence, waiting for its prey...
Intercept
There is no time to waste; traps take effort and planning yet this extraterrestrial plague needs to be stopped now.
Reach $SecondSystemName in less than $Amount02Name [turn] to intercept the evil guys.
Make haste!
Your sensors confirm your command decision--the enemy fleet is about to leave. It is time to stop this menace.
The Living Plague - Part 2

After working out how to communicate with the aliens, you learn that their homeworld was attacked by a hostile race of extraterrestrials who conquer planets, quickly strip them of their resources, and then move on. The aliens were trying to reach a certain habitable system that would both provide a new home as well as a resource to cure their plague when their ship was attacked. Although they desperately want to save themselves, they are also concerned that if you don't deal with the hostile extraterrestrials quickly they will move on to destroy other planets
Intercept
Help the aliens settle in a new home and cure their illness--before their nemeses arrive!
Set up an Outpost on the $FirstSystemName System.
You will need a colonization ship for this.
They are settled in their new home--or at least as settled as they can be while they constantly watch for their aggressors.
Reconquer
Teach the hostiles a lesson--the civilizations of the galaxy don't put up with that kind of behavior!
Reach $SecondSystemName in less than $Amount02Name to intercept the evil guys.
Time is of the essence!
It is a good thing you moved quickly, as it seems the hostiles were about to leave and seek new prey.
The Living Plague - Part 3
You arrive at the planet, only to find that the hostile extraterrestrials have started preparing it as a base for future attacks. Defeat the aggressors and secure the system by colonizing it.
Colonize
The only way to get rid of them is to colonize the system in order to eradicate the last of the hostiles.
Turn your Outpost into a Colony on the $FirstSystemName System.
You need to use Outpost actions if you want to Colonize this System quickly
This threat, at least, has been taken care of. Your empire expands, you have gained good will, and one more threat to the galaxy--or at least to your domination of it--has been dealt with.

Defend

Defeat the fleet at $FirstSystemName.

This threat, at least, has been taken care of. Your empire expands, you have gained good will, and one more threat to the galaxy--or at least to your domination of it--has been dealt with.
Dust to (More) Dust

There has been talk, among the more peaceful empires, of a galactic trade agreement: a clever arrangement in which all participants would benefit. However, the galaxy's commercial infrastructure is not quite up to the level required for such a project. Collaborate with others to build up the galaxy's economic productivity.
Increase the galactic level of Dust generation
Raise the total amount of Dust produced per turn in the galaxy to $DustAmount.
You can increase Dust production through System Improvements, Hero Skills, Trade Routes, Luxury Resources…
Thanks to your combined efforts, the galaxy is thriving economically. Talks are in progress to push the galactic trade agreement forward.
You failed to produce enough Dust. Quest failed.
An Ounce of Prevention

A recent tragedy involving a large space station and a virulent plague has made ripples throughout the galaxy, and turned peoples' attention toward the importance of medical advancement. A coalition has offered a large reward to all who contribute to a push forward in medical technology and scientific readiness, so that a tragedy like this never happens again.
Increase the galactic level of scientific research
Raise the total amount of Science produced per turn in the galaxy to $ScienceAmount.
You can increase Science production through System Improvements, Hero Skills, Luxury Resources...
Thanks to your combined efforts, the galaxy is thriving scientifically. Habitation centers throughout the galaxy are already benefitting from better medical staff and new preventative techniques.
You failed to produce enough Science. Quest failed.
Founders Keepers

The system $SystemName has recently become a flashpoint in the galaxy-wide struggle for dominance. Due to its unique history, position, and resource distribution, it's caught the eye of multiple other empires, some of who are reportedly eyeing it as a potential new base.
