Now's your chance to beat them to it, and deny them a valuable strategic foothold.
Be the first to control the target system
Found a colony on $SystemName before anyone else.
Make sure you have researched the right technology to colonize a planet on $SystemName
You have staked your claim on $SystemName, undoubtedly thwarting the plans of many. Your fledgling colony has won the day—but will it survive the test of time?
Another empire has beaten you to colonizing $SystemName. Quest failed.
Food Fight

Nearly all sentient life in the galaxy depends on food. An empire that controls the flow of foodstuffs possesses more than just sustenance; it holds a decisive edge in matters of trade and politics. Claim this advantage for your empire, and reap the rewards.
Produce the most Food in the galaxy
In $Timer turns, own the System producing the most Food in the galaxy.
You can increase Food production through System Improvements, Hero Skills, Populations, Luxury Resources…
Your System produces the most Food in the entire galaxy. The benefits are yours for the taking.
Another empire owns the System that produces the most Food. Quest failed.
The Means of Production

An empire's ability to react is proportional to the volume of its production. If one can build quickly, one can strike, defend, or strategize with ease. Slower-producing and thus slower-moving empires are inevitably caught on the back foot. Claim this advantage for your empire, and reap the rewards.
Produce the most Industry in the galaxy
In $Timer turns, own the System producing the most Industry in the galaxy.
You can increase Industry production through System Improvements, Hero Skills, Populations, Luxury Resources…
Your System produces the most Industry in the entire galaxy. The benefits are yours for the taking.
Another empire owns the System that produces the most Industry. Quest failed.
Invisible Chains

While your navigators are wise enough to maintain distance from the terrific gravitational forces of the neutron star, it appears that another was not so lucky. You receive weak signals from an ancient buoy, indicating that a Virtual Endless is imprisoned in the powerful magnetic field of this astronomical anomaly. The buoy transmits with its distress signal a series of plans for massive platforms for scientific research; if you build enough of these on your planets they will automatically coordinate to trigger a disruption in the neutron star’s field and free the trapped Virtual. While this sounds great, it appears that the Virtual has also used your comm system and its knowledge of the galaxy to beam this same message to every other faction in the galaxy.
Build $Amount01Name “Gamma Analysis Platforms” in order to trigger a hyperspace anomaly that will free a trapped Virtual Endless from the gravitational pull of a neutron star.
These are Planetary Improvements that give Science bonuses, particularly on Large and Huge planets.

The platforms have been built, and apparently the hyperspace signal has been sent. At first you do not notice anything, but you receive a word of thanks from the Academy and something in the empire’s communication network is glowing…
Build $Amount01Name $BuildingName.
Your effort was unsuccessful. Another empire has successfully built all three Gamma Platforms, triangulated, and freed the imprisoned Virtual. You will not be able to recruit this Hero.
There is nothing left there.
Rumor of an Academy

There are heroes, and there are Heroes. Legends of prowess, familiar to all yet witnessed by none--the heroes of these tall tales are a dime a dozen. But in the leaders you have met and in the murmurs of your crews and colleagues, there are stories of other heroes. Living Heroes, whose actions and efforts have changed the course of battles and bureaucracies, whose actions and decisions have been pivotal in the rise and fall of empires. And when one speaks of these Heroes, masters of Dust and its vast powers, one also speaks of the place where they studied, where they learned these feats of strength and genius. It is simply referred to as "The Academy". Some seem to present it as a center of higher learning, while others mention it in tones more suitable to worship and epiphany. It would be good to know the truth of all this; it would be good if your ships were the first to make formal contact with it and meet its leader, shrouded in mystery.

They are as few in number as they are great in power, the Heroes of the galaxy. They learned their skills at a place simply referred to as "The Academy". Be the first to find this place, and some of its secrets will certainly be yours.
Backtrack the paths of Heroes by exploring $CuriosityAmount Atmospheric Curiosities
Use the Fleet Action "Start Expedition" to explore Curiosities. You have to search at least $MinimumName Curiosity to have a chance at a reward.

Cross-referencing signal information and known Hero movement indicates the Academy is likely in one of three systems. It is time to find out exactly where it is, and meet the puissant being who founded it ages ago.
Another empire has discovered the location of the Academy. This quest is no longer relevant.
The Academy has been discovered. Where your efforts failed, another was successful.
Find The Academy

No one is even sure of the origin of the being that founded the Academy--whether they are human, Endless, alien, or some unknown form. All stories agree, however, that any being touched by Dust who finds that secretive place and survives its rigors emerges deeply changed--and greatly enhanced. A visit, a word with the leader, an understanding of why the Academy exists and what purpose it serves . . . There are many mysteries surrounding the Academy, and claiming it is either a place of research into Dust or a profitable services business seems somehow a bit glib.
The Academy appears to be located in one of three systems. Visit them with a fleet and you may be the first to discover it.
Explore the three indicated Systems with a fleet in order to find the Academy and visit its leader.
At least 1 ship has to orbit around a system to discover it.

The location of the Academy has been revealed! There appears to be a bonus for the faction that first made contact. And now, it is time to both take advantage of its services and discover its mysteries. The first mystery solved is the name of its leader. He is a Vodyani, named Isyander St Shaiad, who founded it centuries ago.
The Academy has been discovered. Where your efforts failed, another was successful. Through diplomatic channels you learn that its founder and leader is a Vodyani.
Preserve the Academy

The Academy and the Heroes who refine their skills there can turn the tides of battles and vastly enrich systems. It is not surprising, therefore, that all civilizations in this galaxy secretly desire insight into and control over that powerful establishment. There are also, however, some peoples for whom the Academy is an insult and an abomination. Chief among these are the hardline conservatives of the Vodyani, for it is said that the leader of the Academy has an ancient religious dispute with them. These rumors appear to be true, as splinter fleets of Vodyani extremists are appearing around the galaxy to come together and attack the Academy. If they succeed, the place and its founder are likely to be destroyed, and its secrets lost.
Protect the Academy by destroying the rogue Vodyani fleets.
In $Timer turns, clear the galaxy of the $FleetAmount Vodyani rebel fleets.
Be wary - the fleets can spawn anywhere

This wave of attacks has failed, and you have learned valuable lessons. First, that the leader of the Academy is in fact a Vodyani renegade named Isyander, and second, that the primary purpose of the Academy is not necessarily the training of Heroes…
You have been unable to destroy the marauding Vodyani extremists. The quest has failed.
Build the Academy

The Academy and the Heroes who refine their skills there can turn the tides of battles and vastly enrich systems. It is not surprising, therefore, that all civilizations in this galaxy secretly desire insight and control of that powerful establishment. Word has come out from the establishment, however, that they seek additional growth and recruitment from the lesser civilizations of the galaxy. Apparently the secretive leader of the Academy feels that these less powerful communities of sentients are underrepresented and underserved on the stage of galactic diplomacy. His request seems a bit odd, but there is advantage to be gained and knowledge to be gleaned.
Encourage the growth and progress of Minor Civilizations
In $Timer turns, ensure that population from Minor Civilizations reaches $PopulationAmount at minimum in the whole galaxy.

Improve Minor Civilization growth by assimilating them, using Luxury Resources in the Population screen, or displacing Major Civilization population with the Spaceport to make room for Minor Civilization population.

The mysterious leader of the Academy is apparently a Vodyani dissident named Isyander. Once the Hierarch of their church, the reasons for his secession are unknown. He thanks you for your aid and encourages your efforts.
Time has run out before the lesser civilizations flourished as Isyander, the leader of the Academy, desired. The quest has failed.
Ghosts and Heroes

The purpose of the Academy is unknown to you. But it was built atop an ancient archaeological dig that shows signs of destruction and ruin. Whatever cataclysm occurred there, it involved not only the Endless but also another great power. Was it war? A foolhardy experiment? A terrible accident? Nobody but Isyander appears to know, and you cannot get him to respond to your diplomatic summons. But as you hear the stories that circulate about the Academy, ancient gods, and upcoming cataclysms, it occurs to you that you might want to boost your approval and your empire's productivity. If there is an apocalypse brewing, you need your people to rally behind you, and your industry must be roaring at top efficiency.
Maximize Empire Approval
In $Timer turns, ensure that you have the highest level of Empire Approval in the galaxy.
You can increase Approval through System Improvements, Hero Skills, and Luxury Resources.

Isyander is pleased with your progress, and speaks to you as an equal. There is an ancient wrong that he would right, an ancient tragedy that he would reverse--or atone for. It happened on the site of the Academy, and it was perpetrated by the Endless. Before you can gain further information, your discussion is closed as other urgent matters take Isyander's attention.
The quest has failed; other empires have won greater support of their people. Your only consolation is that you learn more about Isyander, and his fanatical desire to right an ancient wrong.
Ghosts and Dust

The purpose of the Academy has yet to be determined. But it was built atop an ancient archaeological dig that shows signs of destruction and ruin. Whatever cataclysm occurred there, it certainly involved the Endless but also another great power. Was it war? A foolhardy experiment? A terrible accident? Nobody but Isyander appears to know, and you cannot get him to respond to your diplomatic summons. But there is one sure way to get all the attention you desire from the Academy: Dust. As the old saying goes, "Dust talks". If you can control both starlanes and Dust with a powerful Trading Company, you will certainly merit an audience with Isyander.
They who control the Dust ask the questions.
In $Timer turns, make sure you own the Trade Company producing the most Dust in the galaxy.
Trade Companies and their Subsidiaries, which together form Trade Routes, can be researched in the Technology tree.

Isyander is pleased with your progress, and speaks to you as an equal. There is an ancient wrong that he would right, an ancient tragedy that he would reverse--or atone for. It happened on the site of the Academy, and it was perpetrated by the Endless against another people. But before you can gain further information, your discussion is closed as other urgent matters take Isyander's attention.

The quest has failed; another empire has built a trade route that captured the attention of Isyander. Your only consolation is learning that he is driven by a fanatical desire to right an ancient wrong.
Part 1. Isyander’s Gambit

You are cursed to live in interesting times. The leader of the Academy, and those who follow or trust him, have decided to put their endgame plan into motion. The “what” or “why” of it is no longer debatable; it is happening. Some will side with them in their crusade to bring back the Lost, a race of beings harvested and eliminated by the Endless. Others will oppose them, for it is rumored that the Lost, when congregated in large numbers, had the power of gods. Which are you? The time has come to choose, for Isyander’s words have been heard by all civilizations in the galaxy. ”The time of penance has come. Wrongs must be righted, the innocent restored, and evil purged. None of us were actors in the original crime, but all of us bear the curse of knowledge and responsibility. Those of us who would see justice done will act. Are you with us, or against us? Will you see the Lost restored, or tacitly condone the act of genocide?” His words are chosen with care. Choose your actions accordingly.
REJUVENATE

The galaxy is corrupt and brutal; the return of the Lost is the only chance to alter it forever into something more harmonious. The doors of the Academy are closed during the crisis. No Heroes can be hired, or even get healed.
Find and orbit a majority of the "Lodestone Systems" before those who condone the genocide find and control them
Fleets need only arrive at the identified system first in order to "win" the system.

These systems contain sites known as Lodestones—places built to pray to the Lost that were used to lure and trap them. With them under the control of the Rejuvenator faction, one last summons can be made to bring back these dead gods.
The faction of faithless opportunists controls the Lodestone systems! Your backs are against the wall if you hope to bring about justice for the Lost.
DEFEND

The leader of the Academy is either mad or simply megalomaniac. Take control of the critical sites that he needs to use to execute his insane plan. The doors of the Academy are closed during the crisis. No Heroes can be hired, or even get healed.
Find and orbit a majority of the "Lodestone Systems" before the fanatics of the Academy find and control them.
Fleets need only arrive at the identified system first in order to "win" the system.

These systems contain sites known as Lodestones—places built to pray to the Lost that were used to lure and trap them. With them under the control of the Defender faction, you can prevent the fanatics from launching their plan to summon their so-called deities.
The faction of fanatic apocalyptics controls the Lodestone systems! Your backs are against the wall if you hope to save the galaxy as you know it.
Part 2. Collaboration or Cataclysm

The challenge has been made and the opponents, like mystical astrological planets, align themselves. The Rejuvenators seek to control the Lodestones, and at those three sites execute the Dust ritual that would instill life back into the spirit of a Lost. Their goal is justice and retribution on a cosmic scale; wiping the slate clean and starting over with a less corrupt galaxy. The Defenders refuse this usurpation of their own destinies; whether the Lost are benevolent, malevolent, or indifferent they will not summon other beings who are capable of meddling in their future. The first phase has passed, for the Lodestones have been discovered and occupied. The places are set, the cards laid out, the opponents identified. The end begins.

Control of the Lodestones is paramount. The Collaborators cannot despoil them; we must control these sacred sites and begin our ritual. The doors of the Academy are closed during the crisis. No Heroes can be hired, or even get healed.
With Hero-led fleets only, clear Collaborator fleets from around the identified Lodestones. Orbit them until the rite is complete.
It is no longer a time for hints; it is a time for action.

We do not know what will happen, we only know what we have done. The ledger has been re-balanced, the memory of evil cleansed, and the ancient order of the galaxy restored. We have done what we set out to do, and that is what matters. Let the gods and fate do what they must, for history will judge them as well. The Lost shall return. We have won.
The empires built on blood and murder have won. Ignorance has trumped integrity, and justice is drowned in a flood of self-serving excuses. The Lost shall remain dead, and the galaxy, corrupt.

We must keep the Fanatics away from the Lodestone sites. They seek to enact some ancient ritual that will turn the future of the galaxy over to unknown and potentially vengeful beings. The doors of the Academy are closed during the crisis. No Heroes can be hired, or even get healed.
With Hero-led fleets only, clear the fleets of the Fanatics from the identified Lodestone systems. Orbit them and maintain control until the last of the fleets have been destroyed.
It is no longer a time for hints; it is a time for action.

Reason and rationality have prevailed; the mad dream of an unbalanced fanatic will not come to pass. The forces of Isyander have been defeated and their plan to return powerful, alien entities to the galaxy has been shattered. The Lost will remain Lost, and the galaxy will remain predictable.

Those of us who chose to defend reality as we know it have failed. The Lost have been summoned, though even those who wanted this cannot predict what those "gods" are, or what they will want. Defeat and humiliation are accompanied by confusion, and we are no longer the masters of our fates.
Obtain the Minor Civilization
Safety In Numbers

The $MinorFactionName representative stares at you, the sneer unmistakable. "We are a proud race. Our culture forbids us from bowing down to those whose strength is inadequate." You begin to describe your empire's power--its vast industrial bases, shining fleets, disciplined armies--but the $MinorFactionName interrupts-- "Those things are only reflections of an empire's true strength--its people." The $MinorFactionName looks dismissively at your surrounding retinue. "Grow your numbers and we might begin to consider you a worthy master."
That the $MinorFactionName equate strength with raw population numbers feels primitive in many ways, but it is an easy enough challenge to handle.
Reach $TargetAmountName [population] population excluding your main population inhabitants
Produce more Food to increase the rate of Population growth.

Accompanying the $MinorFactionName representative around one of your most populous systems, you show them the thriving communities full of the young. The $MinorFactionName nods approvingly. "They are your future. And now ours too."
Interstellar Kidnap

"I'm sorry, master, but the $MinorFactionName were most insistent you hear this message personally."
You nod. Go ahead.
A grainy holographic begins playing. Interference periodically interrupts the $MinorFactionName representative and his words are rushed, but you understand the gist. A prominent $MinorFactionName has been abducted, and they want you to help.
With your sophisticated forensics, analysis of the circumstances of the kidnap enables the kidnapper's vessel to be identified and tracked. Now it just needs to be caught!
Intercept the kidnapper's vessel.
Any Fleet can be sent to intercept the kidnapper's craft. If you destroy the fleet, you will fail the objective

A curious story emerges once your soldiers have the kidnapper in laser shackles. The $MinorFactionName believes that the representative he kidnapped was in secret talks with a shady organization named "The Academy". You say nothing. All you really care right now is the addition of the $MinorFactionName to you growing empire.
A Prophecy of Doom

It might seem quaint or even childish to you, but the $MinorFactionName hold a deep belief that a great catastrophe is soon to wreak havoc on their homeworld. The nature of this coming catastrophe is unclear, and they refuse to enter into any dialogue as to its origin. What they ask from you is to give them adequate engineering expertise so they might survive the catastrophe in the vast subterranean halls that they want to build.

It seems doubtful there is any impending catastrophe, no sign of asteroid collision, environmental collapse, or any other extinction-level event. Providing them with the necessary knowledge to construct shelters, however, is a small price to pay for their allegiance.
Raise Science production by building appropriate Constructions and passing relevant Laws
Generate $Amount01Name [scienceColored] per [turn] in one of your Systems before $Timer [turn].

Clearly proud, the $MinorFactionName leads you around the vast underground complex. Huge artificial arches support ceilings of natural stone, while minerals glitter in the rock. $MinorFactionName individuals come up and thank you profusely. You feel good that these people will soon be part of your empire.
A Cry For Help

"We picked up the signal three days ago," says the $MinorFactionName representative, looking apprehensive. "May I?" You wave a hand. Yes. The audio is distorted, and an unholy wailing din can be heard in the background, but the speaker's whispered words are clear. "S-s-something escaped from the labs. And none of the others have come back." Their words suddenly become louder. "Somebody has to help us! For all our sakes!" The audio stops. "How old is the signal?" you ask. "We have no idea," the $MinorFactionName says.
The signal is of $MinorFactionName origin, but where it hails from is uncertain. Whatever escaped from the labs should be no match for your experienced explorers, though. You just need to locate it.
Explore Curiosities until you discover the lab.
Send an Explorer vessel to Systems containing Curiosities and then use the Start Expedition action.

Entering the lab complex, your expedition leader reports some grisly findings. Fluid trails, desiccated bodies, wholesale slaughter. The advanced state of decomposition of the victims suggests this happened long ago, only the sealed environment preventing complete deterioration. Whatever--or whoever--did this is long gone. You instruct your team to recover the dead to return to the $MinorFactionName.
Benedictions In The Church Of Dust

Truth be told, the Dust-obsessed religious fanatics of the $MinorFactionName splinter group are an unnerving crowd. Unnerving but powerful. The opinions of this small group can easily tilt the balance in the decision to join your empire. So when the leader looms close, eyes intense, and asks, "Will you help us?", you don't really have much choice. They worship Dust and they want you to send a Hero to cement their political influence among the population. It could be a good move for making the $MinorFactionName more accommodating . . .
Dust, the most powerful substance in the universe. No wonder they worship it. Sending a Hero on the splinter group's behalf would certainly make a powerful statement. Why not?
Assign a Hero to a Fleet, then send the Fleet to the $MinorFactionHomeSystemName System and orbit for $AmountName [turn].
Fleets must be in a friendly System for a Hero to be assigned.

Parading your hero through the streets of the $MinorFactionName capital made a considerable impression on the population. The splinter group's power rocketed overnight. They offer many blessings. Their victory is your victory.
All Those Yesterdays

"Please help me." The $MinorFactionName slumps in the sand, sobbing. Waves break on the shore, the wash racing up the beach, soaking his lower half. You stare out at the endless ocean, thinking on his incredible story over and over again. He told you that on this very same beach, twenty of his years ago, a strange being in a strange craft landed here, took away his son. He was powerless to stop it, but he remembers one word the being said: Iskvola. He carried the word for years, never giving up hope of one day being reunited with his son. And then he heard it uttered by another visitor--a being who called himself a member of the Vodyani. Iskvola was the name of an ancient ruin somewhere among the stars. He wants you to find it-- and learn what you can about his son.
The $MinorFactionName has risen to become a powerful player in his society. Helping him might give you leverage--as well as giving him a chance of peace.
Explore Ruin-type Curiosities until you discover Iskvola.
Send an Explorer vessel to Systems containing Ruin-type Curiosities and then use the Start Expedition action.

By a miracle of miracles, your expedition team do indeed find an ancient site known as Iskvola. But in the decrepit, sand-blasted ruins they make a grim discovery--the dead husk of young $MinorFactionName, drained of Essence. You return the dead child to his father, who only gives the slightest pause before embracing his lifeless son.
Predators of the Kazinka Cleft

For years isolated settlements of the $MinorFactionName have suffered at the hands of a predatory band operating out of the Kazinka Cleft. They are not without a sense of humor, though. Despite pillaging hardware, fuel, foodstuffs, and domesticated animals, the pirates often grace their captive victims with a theatrical show before making off with their stolen goods. Plays, musicals, even slapstick comedies have been known to be performed, and they have a reputation as excellent players. Now, however, their luck has ran out as they happened to rob kin of one of the $MinorFactionName leadership.

It is somewhat of a shame to help shutdown this merry band of thieves, but their actions are creating hardships for many on the fringes of $MinorFactionName society. Plus, of course, your interest is not entirely motivated by concern for others . . .
Send a military fleet to the mercenary fleet system to engage
Destroy the mercenary fleet somewhere in a nearby system.

The thieves won't be troubling the $MinorFactionName fringe dwellers again, their ships obliterated, their leaders imprisoned. Perhaps one day they can be fully rehabilitated and become theater directors.
The Hidden Cabal

The $MinorFactionName leadership are adamant. A shadowy group are plotting to overthrow their government. Pressed on the identity of these revolutionaries, all the leadership will say is that they think their society has been infiltrated by a collective of alien races who have posted a number of operatives on the world. They believe that these operatives meet periodically in deserted locations, and soon plan to assassinate the leaders and take power for themselves. To protect themselves, the $MinorFactionName would be happy to come under you wing--provided one condition is satisfied: you prove that you are a race that abides by the rule of law.
The $MinorFactionName would be very useful for helping you achieve your goals. Adding another law to the statute books wouldn't be too arduous.
Have $Amount01Name or more Active Laws in your Empire.
Ensure you have the necessary Support and Influence to enact any given law

The secret cabal was probably nothing more than paranoia based off groundless rumors, but the outcome has been very beneficial to your empire. You look forward to directing your new population's efforts.
The Cosmos Unborn

A powerful cult within the $MinorFactionName civilization believe that eldritch, nightmarish kin once traversed the galaxy. Although these kin have now ascended to a higher plane of existence, the cultists are convinced that relics of their culture still exist in ancient ruins scattered across the stars. Fossilized remains. Umbilicals. Placentas. Cerebral cortices. One especially maniacal cultist confesses that the relics aren't simply dead heirlooms. They are artefacts of great--and deadly--power. The relics are likely worthless scraps, but if you acquired them for the $MinorFactionName, they could give you a great deal of influence . . .
Ancient relics certainly still exist among the stars. An expedition with a sufficiently experienced Hero should be able to bring back remnants that will convince the $MinorFactionName.
With a Level 5 or higher Hero, search all "Quest" Curiosities on the indicated Planets in the systems $CloseSystem01Name and $CloseSystem02Name.
Click the "Compass" icon in the corner of this notification window to highlight the Planets

The expedition did well. Although cautious at first, the $MinorFactionName cultists soon believed they held the remains of ancient kin. In turn, this bolstered their political standing, and they soon came to power. Assimilation into your empire followed.
At The Altar of Ancient Gods

Ever since they can remember, the $MinorFactionName have attached divine significance to a distant blood-red star in their night sky. To some the star is a symbol of the crucible of fire that will one day consume the universe, to others it is a symbol of the fire of creation. In either case, every year the $MinorFactionName celebrate the star's existence through the Burning Light Festival which last three whole days and nights. Now that the age of contact has come upon the $MinorFactionName, they would be grateful if you could send a pilgrimage to the star, so that their most learned scholars can pay all their respects.

It is true that we sometimes forget the incredible power of the fiery beacons that light up the endless darkness, that are the ultimate origin of all life. A pilgrimage for the $MinorFactionName would be an honor.
Search the curiosity in the $CloseSystemName System when you're ready to sacrifice $Amount01Name [dustColored].

Ensure you have $Amount01Name [dustColored] in your Empire Treasury, then bring an explorer ship to the indicated marker and use the "Start Expedition" action. Note that you will lose $Amount01Name [dustColored].

The $MinorFactionName pilgrims are returned to their people possessing a deep spiritual connection with the cosmos. They vow to carry the flame through the generations--and are deeply thankful for the part you played.
The Lost Battalion

The soldiers died long ago, but their sacrifice is not forgotten. Two centuries past, the $MinorFactionName were visited by a starfaring race. Descending in elegant craft possessed of powers indistinguishable from magic, the alien beings stepped onto the $MinorFactionName homeworld. Though communication was difficult, the visitors explained very calmly what they wanted of the $MinorFactionName : Two hundred soldiers destined to battle on a distant toxic world far from their loved ones--and die a certain, but honorable, death. It is necessary was all the visitors offered by word of explanation. Generations later, with your help, the $MinorFactionName are finally able to visit the fields of war.
With Titanium protective suits, a $MinorFactionName party will be able to visit the battlefield where their ancestors fell. It is the least you can do.
Search the Curiosity on the planet $CloseSystemPlanetName with at least $AmountName [Strat01titaniumColored] Titanium.
Send an Explorer vessel and use the Start Expedition fleet action to search the Curiosity

The $MinorFactionName dignitaries return to their homeworld somber and reflective. You can tell how much the visit means to them by the way they clasp your arm and the look in their eyes. You are sure they will be useful allies.
Patient Zero

A devastating disease outbreak is currently running rampant through the $MinorFactionName home system. Thousands have already succumbed to the infection, and tens of thousands more are sick. Everyday life is close to breaking point: critical industries are scraping by with skeleton crews, medical facilities are overrun with the unwell, and food shortages loom. Civil unrest is likely to soon spillover into outright rebellion. As $MinorFactionName leaders attempt to manage the outbreak, one vital question remains unanswered: where did the disease originate? Tracing the outbreak back to its inception and identifying patient zero could well be the discovery that breaks the plague's stranglehold. While $MinorFactionName scientists establish the identity of patient zero, the $MinorFactionName have asked if you can provide immediate relief for fleeing refugees.
A swift building program to house, employ, and care for the $MinorFactionName refugees will be greatly appreciated, and could be useful for the future in any case.
Build $Amount01Name or more Buildings in your Empire within $Timer [turn].
All Buildings have a particular cost and each system has its own production power [industryColored].

The building program was a success! Thousands of $MinorFactionName escaped destitution or worse on account of the new constructions. The $MinorFactionName leadership are incredibly grateful for your help, and more than happy to be assimilated into your empire.
Flight of the Prototype

The $MinorFactionName government have a problem. They are adamant that sleeper agents of unknown origins--possibly Mavros or Pilgrim-controlled--have infiltrated their highest R&D facilities, and will shortly instigate strategic attacks on their most sophisticated spacecraft prototype. In a dimly-lit hangar in the heart of a top-secret underwater facility, the $MinorFactionName representative shows you the craft. "The only way we can ensure our technology is protected is by entrusting it to your care while we root out the spies." The craft is beautiful blend of aesthetics and engineering; it would be a tragedy if it was destroyed. And the $MinorFactionName would be extremely grateful too . . .
Protecting the $MinorFactionName's prototype craft shouldn't be too difficult. It might be best to merge it with a fleet though.
Ensure the $MinorFactionName's prototype ship survives in-flight for at least $Amount01Name [turn].
The ship cannot be sent to a Hangar, as this risks enemy infiltration.

The $MinorFactionName representative has sent word: all enemy spies have been captured. With the prototype craft still safe in your hands, the $MinorFactionName are happy to bring their whole civilization under your protective wing. And as a bonus, they tell you to keep the prototype craft.
My Superyacht Is Bigger Than Yours

Maybe it shouldn't be a surprise. The family dynasty that currently controls the $MinorFactionName empire are "new money", hailing from a trio of photogenic celebrity siblings who accumulated much power a generation ago. Now their spoilt offspring wield the reins of power like they're running a glitzy gameshow rather than a serious civilization. It does, however, reveal a chink in their diplomatic armor. An unhappy $MinorFactionName attaché, suffering the family's vanities in the Intrasolar Office, assures you that if you rock up to their system in a suitably militarily pimped-out vessel, you will gain their immediate respect, and probably their loyalty too. The attaché hopes that the assimilation of the $MinorFactionName into your empire will eventually lead to a change of leadership. He really is that desperate.
What harm can it do? Sounds like a win-win situation. Get a lean mean killing machine, and bring down some jumped-up $MinorFactionName dynasty in the process.
Create a ship with at least $Amount01Name Offensive Power and bring it to the System $MinorHomeSystemName.
Add Offensive Modules to a Ship Design to increase OP.

As your sleek attacking craft glides into the $MinorFactionName's orbital port, bristling with weaponry, swarms of drone cams flit around your vessel. As predicted, you're primetime--and the toast of the brattish leadership. Within a week the $MinorFactionName are part of the fold.
Diplomatic Chicanery

After the first official contact with the $MinorFactionName, you are somewhat surprised when you receive a crumpled note a few days later. The leader wants a secret meeting with you, away from any prying eyes. Curious, you agree. After your personal bodyguards have scoped out the location, you meet the $MinorFactionName leader in the shadows. "I'll get straight to the matter," the leader says. "I have a weakness. For gambling. Skimmer racing to be precise." The $MinorFactionName steps closer, stepping into a shaft of light. "I owe a lot of Dust." "And? What's this to me?" you reply. "Build me a new track complex--exclusive, opulent, high-spec. Somewhere close, but . . . well hidden--and I'll give you the keys to the kingdom."

The thought of an underground racing site on a virgin world in one of your systems appeals greatly. Especially if it brings the $MinorFactionName into the fold. Maybe you'll even have a flutter yourself.
Take control of a planet in a new system adjacent to $MinorHomeSystemName
You can set up an Outpost, trade for it diplomatically, or Invade to take control of a new system.

With the final touches being put to the skimmer racing complex, you give the $MinorFactionName leader a guided tour of the site. Afterwards, they cannot hide their excitement. "Your architects and course designers are among the finest in the galaxy. This place will give me much pleasure, and hopefully many winnings!" The $MinorFactionName presents an ornate key on a sequined cushion. "As promised, the key to the kingdom."
The $MinorFactionName have decided your assistance in this matter is not needed at this time.
Masters of the Arena

The sun beats down, sweltering, and sweat prickles your brow. The noisy bloodlust of the crowd together with the dry dust churned up by the combatants, suffocates too. For a dizzying moment, you wonder what possessed you to accept the $MinorFactionName leader's invitation to their bloodsports arena, but then you remember: you court their civilization, and hope these are necessary steps towards the $MinorFactionName's assimilation into your empire. Far below, a fighter in golden scale neatly rolls to one side through the sand, and impales the last of the tri-headed mechanical snakes. The beast slumps to the ground, electricity crackling over its metallic form, and the crowd roars their approval. The leader leans close, its smell powerful and unpleasant. "That's my Finance Minister. He lives and breathes economics--but first and foremost, he's a warrior." The $MinorFactionName lowers its voice. "Show me your passion for violence, and you will have our loyalty,"
Demonstrating your civilization's militarism shouldn't be too difficult--you just hope you don't have to go to war to prove your colors.
Raise your [militaristColored] #B82738#Militarist#REVERT# support to at least 30% in $Amount01Name Systems
Use the Political Sensitivity graph in the Star System Management view to track a system's political makeup.
The $MinorFactionName leader sends their congratulations upon learning of the swell towards militarism across your Empire. The $MinorFactionName are now happy to join your empire.
Happy Days

It has been a difficult few years for the $MinorFactionName. Civil wars, natural disasters, and industrial decline has led to a planet-wide feeling of melancholy among the population. Walking through the capital city, the place quiet and subdued, a lone $MinorFactionName approaches, but your guards block her way. "If you'll permit me, Your Excellency?" You nod. The guards step aside, and the $MinorFactionName joins your side. You walk on together. "You are the leader of a mighty empire, are you not? And you want us to join your empire, don't you?" "Perhaps." "Then what you must do, is show that your people are content." You stop at the edge of a great plaza, but rather than the colorful life you might expect in the heart of the capital, you find shuttered stalls, watching eyes, and silence. "A deep and strong happiness is what the $MinorFactionName seek most. Show us that and our masters will elect to join you. Trust me, I know." The $MinorFactionName slips away.

Later discussions with the $MinorFactionName leadership, together with analysis by your top xeno-psychologists, suggest that the stranger spoke the truth. Keep your own people content, and the $MinorFactionName will join you.
Reach $Amount01Name [happinessColored] in your Empire and maintain it for $Amount02Name [turn] Turns
Construct [happinessColored] buildings, choose appropriate Hero Skills, and avoid overcrowding to raise Approval

The enigmatic stranger was indeed right. After demonstrating the deep, abiding contentedness that sat deep in your people's souls, the $MinorFactionName agreed to join you. They are hopeful for a brighter future under your wing. One day you hope to meet the stranger again--you feel she could play a larger role in your empire's future.
The Light of Other Worlds

For centuries the $MinorFactionName have gazed at the heavens and wondered what mysteries their nearest star systems held. Did these worlds hold stunning natural wonders, riches beyond their wildest dreams, and weird and wonderful alien life? Or were they simply dead worlds filled the dusty tombs of long-gone civilizations and dormant monsters that should never be disturbed? The question still tightly grips the $MinorFactionName imagination today. In fact, one of the biggest schisms in their society is concerned with the question of what exactly resides in their own constellation. Some caution reticence, afraid of what demons they might unleash, while others agitate to learn more about their corner of the cosmos. Deadlocked, the $MinorFactionName are paralyzed. Perhaps you can help?

Exploring the constellation of the $MinorFactionName on their behalf should be relatively straightforward, and could generate some nice discoveries, not to mention earning the eternal gratitude of the $MinorFactionName people.
Search Curiosities until they feel content that the mysteries of the galaxy are not all harmful.
Send an Explorer vessel to each System containing Curiosities and use the Start Expedition fleet action

The galaxy is still an intimidating place to many $MinorFactionName but with the information you have relayed to them about the ruins, landscapes, flora and fauna, and hazards of their nearby star systems, they feel more confident about stepping out further into the galaxy. Especially as it will now be under your wing.
A Clever Fake - Part 1

One of the planets in the system at first appears to be lifeless and poor in resources. A second scan at higher power, however, reveals that the entire planet is a hologram, and in fact there is something hiding beneath the cleverly constructed camouflage. Perhaps you can figure out just how the camouflage worked?
Analyze the planet
Spend Science to try to learn more about what lies beneath.
Nothing happens
Ignore
Your explorers decide whatever might be there isn't worth it.
A Clever Fake - Part 2

One of the planets in the system at first appears to be lifeless and poor in resources. A second scan at higher power, however, reveals that the entire planet is a hologram, and in fact there is something hiding beneath the cleverly constructed camouflage. Perhaps you can figure out just how the camouflage worked? #F5F6CE#You've spent Science to maybe discover something more interesting.#REVERT#
Eureka!
For a bastardized DIY job mixing Endless and other technology, the ruse was fairly impressive. But its secrets are yours now, and the planet is revealed for what it is.
$TechnologyName unlocked
Friend or Food

Signals from this system indicate that it was once inhabited. Yet all that remains now are docile, roaming quadrupeds. They are well-fed, somewhat chubby, and relatively friendly . . . So what in all the stars are they?
Cattle
Without question they were a food source, and analysis proves that they are highly nutritious.
Pets
Psychologists insist that they were pets, and should be domesticated and introduced into the home.
Military Militants

A thread of discontent has been growing in the population, as some voters believe the galaxy is even more dangerous than it appears. You are under pressure to turn your policies and investments to more military uses.
Militarism!
Your increase of military propaganda and laws makes at least some of your people feel safer--and happier.
The Ghost of a Machine

There are ruins in this system, old enough and sophisticated enough that they must have come from the Endless. There are machines within machines, some of which are still running, and others that are so alien you are not sure how to tell if they are running or not. It will take time to investigate properly--that is, if you don't just take the Dust and run.
Investigate
Invest the effort required to understand the mysteries of this machine and - perhaps - learn how to make it produce more Dust.
Loot
The machines, the Dust, and the data have enormous value--the fleet crew will be happy to see their bonuses!
The Ghost of a Machine (Part2)

There are ruins in this system, old enough and sophisticated enough that they must have come from the Endless. There are machines within machines, some of which are still running, and others that are so alien you are not sure how to tell if they are running or not. It will take time to investigate properly--that is, if you don't just take the Dust and run. #F5F6CE#However, you could also try to put in the effort to understand the mysteries of this machine--and maybe learn how to make it generate Dust . . .#REVERT#
Success!

This is the unthinkable, in a factory, still running--a Dust Duplicator. Sadly the original motes of some special sort of Dust are long gone, but the blueprints and settings should allow you a few profitable years . . .
The Ghost of a Machine (Part2)

There are ruins in this system, old enough and sophisticated enough that they must have come from the Endless. There are machines within machines, some of which are still running, and others that are so alien you are not sure how to tell if they are running or not. It will take time to investigate properly--that is, if you don't just take the Dust and run. #F5F6CE# However, you could also try to put in the effort to understand the mysteries of this machine--and maybe learn how to make it generate Dust . . . In spite of your efforts, the machines were too ancient and too strange for your technicians to unravel their secrets. Perhaps next time.#REVERT#
Failure . . .
In spite of your efforts, the machines were too ancient and too strange for your technicians to unravel their secrets. Perhaps next time.
Nothing happens
Mapmakers Anonymous

Your crew follows a mysterious electromagnetic "ping" all the way to its source: a half-buried control center in the overgrown ruins of one of the System's planets. A quick raid of the surprisingly modern computer system reveals a detailed map of the Constellation--including a few Systems in unexpected places.
Take
Even if the map is slightly out of date, the information should prove useful.
The Dead

A distress signal of ostensibly Lumeris origin leads your fleet to a small frozen planet, where you find a wrecked Lumeris freighter still sending out its plaintive call out into the void. Everyone around the ship is dead, having starved or frozen to death long before the arrival of help.
Loot
They don't need it; why don't you take it? It's too bad to let all that tech and gear go to waste.
Lay to Rest
These people deserve to find peace. Pirates or no, the thought of leaving that distress signal echoing on a dead planet disturbs you deeply.
The Dead - Part 2

These people deserve to find peace. Pirates or no, the thought of leaving that distress signal echoing on a dead planet disturbs you deeply. The perished crew is at rest, and the distress signal shut off. You can tell the ruined ship is on your crew's minds even long after your fleet leaves the System.
Departed
The perished crew is at peace, and the distress signal shut off. You can tell the ruined ship is still on your crew's minds long after your fleet leaves the System.
Ring Lizards

Your fleet approaches a large, ringed planet. The planet's surface is uninhabitably hot and toxic, but to your surprise you find that there are colonies of small reptilian creatures living on the rings themselves. The rings, made of tiny asteroids of rock and ice, provide a hospitable environment that the planet lacks. The creatures are so numerous that you decide to take a few with you.
Study
Your scientists say that detailed study of the creatures may lead to small advances in atmospheric shielding technology. Unfortunately, this would also involve killing them.
Adopt
Keeping the creatures as pets or mascots aboard your fleet has great popular appeal. They are fairly attractive-looking things, and may serve to raise fleet morale on long trips between the stars.
Lunchtime

You enter the atmosphere of this planet to a wondrous sight: a migrating swarm of giant airborne creatures, soaring idly through the air like a fleet of dirigibles. Your wonder turns to fear, however, when the creatures start attaching themselves to your ships' hulls. The banging of mandibles off sheet metal echoes through the interior.
Run

You give orders to flee the planet as quickly as possible. However, the creatures remain attached to your ships for quite some time. If these enormous creatures are indeed parasites, as it seems, you shudder to imagine the beasts they usually feed on.
Eternal Sunshine

One of the planets in this System is tidally locked with its star: one of its hemispheres is constantly bathed in light. Some long-gone civilization apparently used the planet as an enormous farm--now lush jungle grows over neat, barely-recognizable rows of food crops.
Forage
After some jungle exploration, your crew comes away with a relatively large stash of nutritious, sour-tasting fruit.
Breathe Deep

The atmosphere of this planet has a strange psychotropic effect: when inhaled, the sweet vapor seems to allow the subject to see exactly four seconds into the future. Perhaps a concentrated dose might do even more . . .
Inhale

A brave volunteer, taking a heavy dose of the gas, may be able to convey valuable exploratory information to the fleet. However, your scientists predict a short, painful relapse for the subject after its effects wear off.
The Stars Their Destination - Part 1

As your fleet $Fleet04 orbits the System, a strange blip appears on the radar. Your crew watches in amazement as an ancient passenger ship of some bipedal species origin passes right across your fleet's sensors. Further scanning reveals that it is an antiquated generation ship: a sub-light craft inhabited only by cryogenically-preserved pioneers.
Let Them Be
The affairs of primitive peoples who can't even travel faster than light are none of your concern. Perhaps it's best to just let them be.
Interfere

Using your fleet's advanced scanning techniques, you may be able to follow alongside and gain access to the generation ship's onboard computers. It's none of your business, but since everyone's on board is asleep, perhaps a tiny peek wouldn't hurt . . .
The Stars Their Destination - Part 2

As your fleet orbits the System, a strange blip appears on the radar. Your crew watches in amazement as an ancient passenger ship of apparently human origin passes right across your fleet's sensors. Further scanning reveals that it is an antiquated generation ship: an automated craft traveling at sub-light speeds, inhabited only by cryogenically-preserved pioneers.
A cursory look at the computer reveals a shocking fact: the ship is headed straight into a nearby star. Apparently someone made a miscalculation somewhere.
Alter Course

With some deft reprogramming, you can alter the ship's course to make sure it arrives at a habitable, relatively comfortable planet. You feel a little sorry for the technologically-backward inhabitants aboard.
Loot

Since the ship is heading to its doom anyway, a little premature looting might be justified. The ship's engines seems to run on an ancient type of fossil fuel, now incredibly valuable. As for the cryo-preserved passengers, well . . .
Dig Deeper

The surface of this planet is tranquil, but a quick scan reveals that the ground under the surface is teeming with robots, diligently working to transform the barren wastes into fertile land. You have no idea who created them. It strikes you, however, that these robots could be put to good use on some of your less agriculturally-inclined Systems.
Borrow
The design of these robots is elegant and efficient. They'll be a great help on Barren planets across your Empire.
A Tremor in Time

Somebody has flicked a switch that should have been left in the "Off" position. There are stories of Doomsday devices created by the Endless, and judging by the quantum shifts in reality one of them has just been triggered. Fortunately the power supplied to the device appears to have been low enough that the effect is relatively minor.
It's a trap!
While engineers try to resolve the problems, it seems you're trapped . . .
Riled Researchers

It appears that an intergalactic congress of scientists has turned into a labor dispute. They have come to the conclusion that their work is grossly under-appreciated, and plan to halt all experimental efforts until their wages improve, their lab equipment is upgraded, and their work reported more professionally.
Ignore
Who cares about science? You prefer to spend your efforts on rewarding industrial workers and practical results.
React
OK, maybe it's time to do something. It's better to spend a little money than to see your knowledge and research talents dwindle and disappear.
Call a Spaceman a Spaceman

On some of your Systems, an antiquated classification scheme used to categorize Minor Civilization citizens has the religious community up in arms. The classification system is mostly meaningless at this point, but to officially accede to the protesters' demands would be a small bureaucratic nightmare.
Ignore
Ruling requires a firm hand. In times like these, the people need to realize that there are greater threats to the empire than linguistics.
Change
Sometimes words have to change with the times, too. It'll be a logistical nightmare, but the switch should be welcomed by all.
Bumper Crop

You've read the reports, and it looks like Luxury Resource generation across all your Systems is exceeding expectations this year. You can already anticipate the response from your advisors, though: the industrialists will advise you to quietly shore up the Empire's economy with the extra goods, while the religious contingent will want you to make a big show of thanking the gods for a bountiful harvest.
Save
Who needs flags and banners? Funneling resources stealthily into the economy without making a big fuss about it is the smarter choice.
Celebrate
If the people want to celebrate, who are you to stop them? Keeping the population happy from time to time often has a variety of good effects.
On The Shoulders Of Supergiants

A distant stellar giant, about 80 times the size of an average star, has just gone supernova. Capitalizing on the media attention drawn by the event, a Pacifist group within your empire has launched a campaign to bring home the fleets that were monitoring the event, rather than leave them on patrol.
Support
Even a star's life can seem short. Bring your troops home for some well-deserved time with their families.
Babies not Booms

There has been a noticeably increased birth rate in one of the systems of your empire, $MySystemName, that identifies as Militarist and Scientific. The trend is particularly strong among the Haroshem. Why? Your advisors say it's a cultural response to the instability of galactic warfare -- while a leading analyst claims it's a reaction to the prosperity of peace. Perhaps no one really knows.
Grow
Either way, your systems can look forward to a burgeoning generation of pacifists in the next generation!
Mind Matters

A brilliant inventor from the $SystemName System has created a wondrous piece of technology: a neural device that allows one to temporarily control the thoughts and actions of another. Unfortunately, the inventor only created one--and he apparently passed away shortly after testing it for the first time. There is a bit of hullabaloo over what to do with the device now.
Destroy
The people are calling for the device to be destroyed. A potentially mass-producible device that violates every personal liberty known to sentient life? Perhaps not the best for your empire.
Confiscate
A technology so potent should be put to good use, not destroyed. As long as powerful technology stays in the hands of the trustworthy, it's acceptable . . . right?
An Unexpected Guest

Out of the blue (literally), a new minor faction has abruptly moved onto one of your planets and have no intentions of leaving anytime soon. Whether they are friendly or not is yet to be discovered, but hopefully their intrusion won't be long. It's up to you to decide how best to treat them...
New comers!
Integration or Exclusion? Diversity or purity? The choice, for the moment, has been forced upon you.
Hear My Last Cry

What looked like a huge asteroid approaching one of your system's stars turned out to be a fragment of an ancient planet that burst ages ago. What makes it different are the remains of strange alien structures on it. What will you do before the planetary fragment flames into the sun?
Forgotten Science
Send a team of scientist to get as much information as they can from those structures.
Make Them Pay
While it is safe, make tours to visit and learn more about who lived there. And in the meantime, make some Dust out of it.
Respect the Dead
What happened in that planet was not a natural occurrence. Some things are better left undisturbed; it is better to learn what we can of what it from a safe distance.
Slingshot

Your fleet enters the System $OneSystemName, and has barely slowed from supra-light speed when a belt of rocks circling one of the planets starts to peel off and head towards you on a carefully calibrated collision course. With your current inertia and momentum, unfortunately, a course change is impossible . . .
Study
Study the effect, which will leave your fleet vulnerable, but may provide later benefits.
Destroy
Build up your defenses and pulverize the rocks; perhaps you will be able to gain some resources.
Flee
Do everything in your power to avoid, or limit, the impact.
Slingshot - Part 2

Your fleet enters an unknown system, and has barely slowed from supra-light speed when a belt of rocks circling one of the planet starts to peel off and head towards you on a carefully calibrated collision course. With your current inertia and momentum, unfortunately, a course change is impossible . . . #F5F6CE#Focusing on scientific investigation, you study the system and its effects to gain an Industry bonus, but doing so puts you in harm's way. Your fleet is damaged, but survives. The secret of the sophisticated magnetics and guidance systems will prove worthwhile in your own industries. #REVERT#
Science Pays
Your fleet is damaged, but survives. The secret of the sophisticated magnetics and guidance systems will prove worthwhile in your own industries.
Slingshot - Part 2

Your fleet enters an unknown system, and has barely slowed from supra-light speed when a belt of rocks circling one of the planet starts to peel off and head towards you on a carefully calibrated collision course. With your current inertia and momentum, unfortunately, a course change is impossible . . . #F5F6CE# Focusing on defending yourself, you try to destroy the incoming rocks, hoping to acquire useful resources. In an ironic denouement, the rocks turn out to be rich in useful minerals and are now floating in easy reach of your scoops. #REVERT#
Hard Rocks
In an ironic denouement, the rocks turn out to be rich in useful minerals and are now floating in easy reach of your scoops.
Trial By Fire - Part 1

A listening outpost on the far edge of your territory has picked up a garbled communication, and sends an urgent message up the chain of command. Someone is leaking military secrets to a rival empire, and could jeopardize upcoming offensive operations. The message and its origins are unclear, but a digital forensics team is able to pinpoint one clue: that the attached files contain metadata originating from the terminal of an artillery officer of one of your Minor Civilizations. The soldier's record is exceptional, but there have always been those who complained at allowing an outsider to rise so high in military command . . .
Start Trial
Justice must move swiftly and without mercy. For his crimes, the artillery officer will be tried before the entire people.
Refuse Trial

You take the officer at his word, and order a more thorough investigation into the leak--but as soon as word gets around that you won't prosecute the man, a number of your military quit in protest. Coincidentally, the intelligence team reports the traffic they were monitoring has suddenly gone silent . . . but with no more evidence, it will be impossible to root out the traitor.
Trial By Fire: Part 2

The artillery officer's trial spirals out of control. Nationalists within your empire argue it was a mistake to ever empower an outsider within your military. In turn, those accusations outrage minorities across your population and their allies who have pledged loyalty to your cause. The officer is convicted, but maintains his innocence and begs you to expand your investigation. He recalls reviewing the stolen intelligence as a routine operations check, and that he forwarded it to several other officers for review. Protests against the officer's arrest have begun on several worlds, and public action is needed to sway the mood of the public . . .
Shutdown Protests
Order must be brought to the empire--one man's fate cannot be allowed to put an end to all the hard work your military has fought for.
Pardon Officer

In a personal meeting with you, the officer tells you he resents the guilty conviction, and the way his people have been put on trial. He declines the offer to return to military service, but does state he will work to join his people in fighting for their place within the empire.
Trial By Fire: Part 3

The artillery officer has been convicted. He sits in a prison facility nicknamed "The Reaper's Penthouse," as his lawyers file petition after petition for his freedom. The minor factions in your empire live in a permanent state of fury. Things can't seem to get any worse, but somehow, they do. An intergalactically renowned journalist named Zolya Emily publishes an intrepid report damning your entire government, and exposing the real traitor as an Admiral who the officer consulted on the reports. Emily's work rocks the empire, ironically making allies out of the minor factions and their former enemies. Though the officer is happy to have his name cleared, there will be a price to pay for your administration's bumbling efforts.
Reap What You Sow

Your attempts to use strong-arm politics to force the issue have spectacularly backfired. Distrust of you and your government's increasingly militaristic outlook has never been higher, and the Pacifists in your empire have gained a significant boost. Healing these divisions will take time.
Boiler Room

Lobbyists for your empire's banks have been assailing your Senators for weeks with demands to ease some of the regulations on their operations. In particular, they're requesting looser restrictions on letting ordinary citizens in space travel ventures, and on insuring ships heading out for long distance voyages. They promise increased financial gains for your Empire, with minimal risks to your financial future.
Approve
A free market does benefit from being more . . . free, and space travel is a lucrative economy booster at the moment. Perhaps some relief for the bankers would be financially prudent.
Deny

These deregulations are maddening, and nakedly put the lives of the people at risk in order to possibly raise profits for the banks' financial systems. End this madness before it starts and raise taxes on their operations as a warning not to try this again!
Boiler Room - Part 2

It turns out allowing bankers to deregulate their own industry may not have been a fantastic idea. One of the larger banks tied up its clients' wealth in a set of risky trade voyages, but pirates intercepted the merchant fleets and stole everything they carried. Worse still, the insurance claims on the ships mean yet more Dust is funneled out of the public's funds, and the large shipping corporations are the only ones reimbursed for their loss. Your people are penniless, broke, and rioting. The bankers are begging for more time.
Grant More Time

You grit your teeth at reading the increasingly insane measures they propose to fix this economy without executive action. Still, jailing the bankers could just further destabilize this economy, and as much as it pains you, their work may be needed to fix it.
Jail Bankers
It's financially painful, but you opt to cut this problem off before it gets any worse. These idiots can't be trusted to run a small spaceport, let alone an intergalactic banking operation.
Smoking Gun - Part 1

With the elections approaching, you've begun to take note of the growing support for minority parties within your government. Your aides have given you conflicting reports on the causes. Some try to argue it's a matter of policy views, age gaps, and changing values, but the arrests of several high-profile legislators, charged with spying for the enemy, means there may be a bigger picture at stake. A group of mercenaries approaches you, spies who claim expertise in getting results done without getting caught. If you hire them, they claim they could root out the conspirators, and tip the election in your favor . . .
Hire Spies
Their prices are high but their information is good. You'll need all the help you can get to save your administration from the corruption within.
Arrest Spies
Your enemies may surround you but you will not stoop to their level.
Smoking Gun - Part 2

The mercenaries were able to bug the opposing party's offices and provide valuable intelligence, but things have taken a turn for the worse. On a repeat surveillance sortie, the group is spotted by an unarmed security guard, and law enforcement descends on the entire group. You've paid them well, so they don't out the entire administration, but ties to your party are published in the press. If heads don't start rolling, the people may begin to question your entire government . . .
Fire Leaders
Someone has to take the fall for this--eliminating leaders of your party will weaken faith in your administration but bring an end to this farce of an election.
Defend Leaders
Stun the people and use this opportunity to defend the needs of an aggressive government, one that will go to any length to protect its people from outside conspirators.
Smoking Gun - Part 2

The arrest of the spies creates something of a scandal, but during the public trial your skillful political testimony convinces the majority of your population that your government is a shining beacon of light in a sea of darkness. The subsequent execution of the spies demonstrates that, despite being bound by the truth, you are no soft touch either.
Honest Policy
Your blend of idealism and discipline resonates with the population, who sing your praises. You should make the most of this upsurge in your popularity while it lasts.
A Million Things I Haven't Done

Conflict has broken out between two of your trusted advisors. Two war heroes, once dearest friends, have nearly come to blows over the management of the Industrial party. They trade insults in the press, and don't print retractions. One, a young upstart who has made enemies and allies with his decisive decision-making, argues the party should adopt more taxes and tariffs in order to regulate the empire's debts. The other, a fine negotiator but dedicated opportunist, cautions against bold action and worries about the government's relationship with large businesses and foreign empires if such acts are taken. Their argument is as much personal as it is professional--whichever advisor you back will have plenty of ammo to throw at the other as their rivalry continues.
Back Upstart
This upstart believed for the longest time his only way to rise up was on the battlefield in glory--rewarding his plan will show the people there's more to life then being a martyr.
Back Opportunist
The opportunist's motives may consistently disgust you, but there is reason in his words. You might favor him on this occasion.
A Million Things I Haven't Done (Part2)

The upstart's success has only emboldened his political ambitions, and raised his standing with the public. He campaigns to run for head of the treasury, and wins in a landslide. Now one of the most loved and hated leaders in your empire holds the keys to the vault.
His rivals can't tolerate this. They've thrown everything they've got against him, but even infidelity charges don't stick. The opportunist, however, sees one last chance to bring him down.
In a rare stroke of boldness, he insults the upstart's family, in particular, the man's dead son, who was accidentally killed in a fight while military training.
The upstart is furious, and demands satisfaction in the form of a duel.
Encourage Duel
Let them work out this petty quarrel on their own.
Discourage Duel
What foolishness is this? You can't have two of your top officials killing each other over insults and pride.
The Division

The tense political rivalry between Militarism and Pacifism in the $SystemName system has risen to emergency levels: the Militarist faction has ordered the construction of an intricate, system-spanning barricade between $SystemName's inner and outer planets. Intra-system movement has been severely restricted, and many citizens have been cut off from their families and friends. The Pacifist "inner" planets have petitioned you for help.
Ignore

A blockade serves a useful purpose: it has put a stop to the infighting and congressional spats that have plagued $SystemName for years. Leaving the system temporarily divided will allow each half to do what they do best, without getting in the other's way.
Dismantle
Through experience, you know that this sort of division only leads to trouble. You must tear down this barricade.
The Division: Part 2

The situation in $SystemName, your divided system, has gone from bad to worse. The Militarist portion has implemented stringent and oppressive laws, and violent demonstrations have erupted in several major cities. Meanwhile, your Pacifist portion is suffering from a sluggish industry and economy. The two portions of your system have developed different flags and national identities. At this point, you have no idea what would happen if you were to forcefully take down the barricade.
Ignore

Perhaps it was a mistake to leave the barricade up, but it's probably best to leave things where they lie now. The independent halves of your system can work things out peacefully on their own--and the barricade may now be the only thing keeping $SystemName from civil war.
Dismantle
The political situation is very unstable, but you feel you must give orders for the barricade to be taken down immediately. $SystemName used to live in peace--how did this all happen so quickly?
A Two-Way Street

The recent switch to Industrialist politics in $SystemName has left many unhappy. Chief among the dissidents is a radical splinter group, who have begun raiding shipping lanes to disrupt economic activity. The governor has imprisoned the worst of the offenders, and plans to deactivate several established, historically-significant space stations to build a network of newer, cheaper, secure waypoint systems for intra-system travel. The people have voted against his proposal, citing historical and cultural value. The decision falls to you.
Approve

The orbital stations are indeed old, and the new waypoint network would give your system an economic boost, as well as discouraging terrorist attacks. The sentimental citizens of $SystemName will just have to accept things.
Veto

If the people voted to preserve the space stations, they should certainly not be destroyed. It will be a little harder for the governor to implement his plan, and perhaps the system but will suffer a few more dissident attacks, but ultimately the people should decide what their home system looks like, not you.
Down To Earth

Appointing a Religious Senator without popular support has proven to be a troublesome decision. The latest developments involve the controversial choice to ban moxotl, an aquiferous plant harvested across the empire and often added to drinks for its temporary gravity-altering properties. The trouble is, moxotl isn't just recreational--it's also used in industry and medical treatments. Banning it for religious reasons, lobbyists say, is nothing more than a flight of fancy. What do you say?
Uphold
You just recently installed this governor in office--you can't undermine their choices so soon. Let the ban stand.
Remove
Perhaps vetoing this particular ban will improve the people's Approval--and give the impression that you're actively listening to them.
Generation Gamma

Political disinterest among young people across the empire has reached an all-time high. The sons and daughters of a generation brought up with ideals of a perfect republic feel increasingly powerless and disenfranchised, as if they are just cogs in a machine. A common sentiment is that the electoral system is rigged against them. Having pulled a few strings in the last election, you know they are not exactly wrong. But how will you deal with the problem?
Conscript
One of the best remedies for a dissatisfied populace is war. By pulling a few more strings, you'll be able to unite the populace -- against a common enemy that may or may not really exist.
Entertain
By cultivating a consumerist, entertainment-oriented society, you'll draw your people's attention away from the things that really matter. Read, watch, play -- and don't vote.
Educate

So you cheated in the last election. That doesn't mean you'll do it again. By educating the people and encouraging them to exercise their rights as citizens, you'll empower the people -- and reap some other benefits as well.
Progress

The new Industrialist movement on $SystemName is causing more problems than you would like. Apparently, some political organizations have been spearheading a civilian movement to "tear down the old," destroying valuable cultural monuments and priceless artifacts in an attempt to usher in a new industrial era. If this is allowed to continue, intellectualism and innovation on $SystemName will be crippled for decades to come. Still, the near-fanatical energy of this movement is doing wonders for the system's industry. What will you do?
Stop
The movement is ridiculous, and must be put to a stop. It would be an awful waste if you allowed the people to cast off the lessons of history so carelessly.
Ignore
A certain casting off of the past is important for progress. Unless the movement reaches dangerous levels, it should be allowed to take its natural course.
The Food of Lab

Your scientists are making progress on an interesting research project: a type of gene therapy that permanently reduces a person's need for food. They have requested permission to start clinical trials immediately. It's risky, they say, and will consume a large amount of food stores, but could pave the way for a breakthrough within two generations.
Approve
Science takes investment; not everything pays off immediately. Go ahead with the experiment.
Farm
If food is the issue, your empire would be better served if you just put the scientists to work as farmers instead. A much more elegant solution.
Message from Coroz

You have received a message from Coroz, home dimension of the Riftborn. A group of scientists have had their facilities destroyed by the advancing blight, and are unable to continue their work. They have applied to join your empire in New Coroz as laborers until they can resume their jobs back home as scientists.
Rebuild

Instead of taking them on as laborers, you should divert some of your resources to help them rebuild as quickly as possible. Every moment not studying the blight is a moment it threatens more of your home.
Accept
You will miss the scientific work they are doing, but your empire could use a temporary boost in productivity. Utilizing your resources to the fullest is what the Riftborn do best.
The Quantitative Society

A cabal of scientists and visionaries from a prominent research group/think tank have come forward to your government promising to deliver the dream of a utopian society. They have created a vast super-AI that can watch and learn from all, and believe that all will benefit from its scrutiny. Like many who have come up with ideas to "fix" society, their dream is riddled with their own biases and hang-ups, including believing that life isn't worth living without a dependable chain of caffeine bars featuring semi-designer furnishings and "exotic" mood music. The fact their vision of a perfect society also involves mandatory science "fun" means that although your citizens will become more rational, they won't be as pliant. A more popular, less scientifically beneficial move, would be to ignore them.
Embrace
They might be over-trendy, but the visionaries have a point. An invasive, pervasive monitoring system ran by an AI supermind is a small price to pay for a boost to science!
Reject
By ramping up the focus on the infringement of basic rights that the AI system will entail, the rejection of the eggheads' plan can provide a major boost to your popularity.
Unnatural Wastelands

An undercover documentary concerning a makeshift community who live in one of your planet's biggest refuse facilities has become a loaded political issue. Many are scraping a living in the system's dumps, scavenging for recycled materials while setting up their homes in the very same places. Amenities have followed, and these places are now lively, if polluted and dangerous, hubs. Environmental groups demand that action is taken, that industries need to manage their resources better, and not fuel these communities. Others suggest going even further, and monetizing these places more effectively. In essence, they advocate greater ties between industry and the refuse sites.
Shutdown
These dumps are a stain on your civilization. Industry might suffer, but you have a moral imperative to ensure the welfare of your whole population. Forecasting suggests that happiness will increase.
Enhance

When in doubt, double down! Sure industry could throw away less stuff, but maybe they could throw away more stuff and be even more efficient. Then we get more thriving dump economies too, even if many don't like it.
Tete-a-Tete

$SystemName, a major industrial hub for your empire, is holding a fancy summit for industry leaders and politicians to mingle and "talk business" away from the scrutiny of the public eye. This year, ecological groups have organized a massive protest, condemning the summit as a secretive way to pass elitist, eco-unfriendly laws. You've just received your personal invitation to the party.
Condemn

Industry is important, but the people are right: sneaky politics are no way to run a system. The summit will go on this time, but not with your support, and speaking publicly against it will ease the hearts of many.
Attend

Business is business, and this is the way business has always been done on $SystemName. You'd be foolish to run off your mouth about it now. Besides—those industry leaders do know how to throw a good party.
In Memory Of

You've never heard of him, but a mystical figure, Kalant Alcor, has recently passed away and begun his ascent up "The Divine Ladder" to another plane of existence. A religious bloc in your Senate demand that Alcor's passing be given a full state funeral, with a hundred thousand votive candles lit in every city, special monuments constructed that feature his idiosyncratic writings, and three days of empire-wide mourning. It'll be expensive, but Alcor was a popular figure, and your population will be grateful. On the other hand, political models suggest that a rejection of the demand will boost scientific literacy even if it is unpopular. After all, much of Alcor's writings concern the truth that worlds are flat not round.
Neglect

Kalant Alcor was a fraud and a liar, gaining a cult reputation through manipulation and hatred. To give him a officially endorsed funeral of such magnitude would not only be costly, it would be a blow against progress.
Honor

So the guy had some interesting theories about the way the cosmos worked. Who cares? He probably inspired creatives. It might cost the treasury a little, but afterwards your citizens are going to be extremely grateful. And, more importantly, malleable.
Church and State

You are pleased, but not entirely surprised, to discover that one of your colonies has developed a fringe religion in which the central deity... is you. Though small, it has already drawn a following. One of their more charismatic leaders has publicly asked if you would bless them with an appearance at the inauguration of their newest cathedral. Meanwhile, others in that system are watching to see what your response will be.
Accept
You haven't visited $SystemName in a while; no harm taking in a little adoration while you're at it. Besides, it'll help cement your political influence over the sector.
Decline

Mixing religion and politics is a bad, bad idea. To ensure your empire stays on the proper path, you must decline. You want an empire that looks outward at the wonders of the universe, not inward at its own navel.
